The #peaceful #propalestine #protest that was to be held in #Rome on Saturday 5 October escalated into clashes between some demonstrators and the police. The police made extensive use of tear gas and stun grenades, causing several injured and serious psycho-physical reactions among those present. Protesters threw glass bottles, road signs, pieces of soil and cherry bombs. 
The clashes lasted for about half an hour, the gathering in the square - which was at first forbidden and then authorised - lasted several hours, and after the violent escalation, a procession, unsupervised but permitted by the police, was set off in the Rome area of San Saba, and ended, peacefully and spontaneously, in front of Ostiense train station. 

The clashes are the outbreak of a pressing atmosphere of police control that began days before the protest and across the whole country. Police in all regions blocked cars and buses heading to Rome and patrolled trains in search of activists who, although unoffensive, were detained in the barracks. The Ostiense square was barricaded by police trucks and hundreds of riot police with batons in hand and shields raised. 
It is important not to forget that according to the law enforcement manuals and suggestion on crowd policing, precisely in order to avoid making the protesters feel threatened, the police should not wear helmets from the start, nor holding batons in their hands as if the unit is ready to charge. Furthermore, vehicles such as water cannons should not be used to threaten a non-threatening crowd, but only to intimidate where there is a tangible risk of clashes.

AMEENA is now in 26th week . Like to share our friend Rakesh Jhunjhunnwala view 

Read carefully till the end!
The real truth of life!

Rakesh Jhunjhunnwala's last words before he passed away with a net worth of 45000 crores:

I have reached the pinnacle of success in the business world. My life is an achievement in the eyes of others. However, I had no happiness except work. Money is just a truth I use.

Laying in a hospital bed at this point and looking back on my whole life, I realize that the identity and money I was proud of, faded and worthless before death.

You can hire someone to drive your car or earn money. But, you can't hire someone to suffer and die.

Lost physical items can be found. But there is one thing that is never found when lost - and that is "Life".

Whatever stage of life we are in, in time we will face the day when the heart stops.

Love your family, partner and friends...üôètreat them well, don't cheat them, never be dishonest or treacherous.

As we grow older and wiser, we slowly realize that wearing a watch costing Rs 300 or Rs 3000 or Rs 2- 4 lakh - all tells the same time.

Whether we have a wallet of 100 or 500 - everything inside is the same.

Whether we drive a car worth 5Lacks or a car worth 50Lacks. The path and the distance are the same and we reach the same destination.

Whether we live in a house of 300 square feet or 3000 square feet - loneliness is the same everywhere.

You will realize that your true inner happiness does not come from the material things of this world.

Whether you fly in first class or economy class, if the plane goes down, you are going to go down with it.

That's why.. I hope you realize, you have friends, brothers and sisters, with whom you chat, laugh, sing, share pleasantries,.... That's true happiness. !!

An indisputable fact of life:

Don't educate your children just to be rich. Teach them to be happy. When they grow up, they will know the value of things and not the cost.

Israeli occupation troops blocked the call to Friday prayer from being aired from the minarets of the Ibrahimi Mosque in the occupied West Bank city of Hebron and stopped Palestinians from entering the Muslim shrine for prayers today.

The director of the Islamic Endowments in Hebron, Ghassan Al-Rajabi, informed the WAFA news site that the occupying troops had stopped broadcasting the adhan, or call to prayer, for Friday services, forcing many worshippers to offer their prayers outside in the courtyard. This is the mosque's 23rd consecutive year that the adhan has been prohibited.

Israeli soldiers positioned at military checkpoints close to the mosque inspected locals and their identity credentials, according to Al-Rajabi.

The decision to strike the Taliban from a list of terrorist organizations was "taken at the highest level," according to a statement released by Russia's Foreign Ministry on Friday, as reported by the official TASS news agency.

According to Reuters, President Vladimir Putin's special envoy for Afghanistan, Zamir Kabulov, added that the decision must be implemented through several legal processes.

Putin declared in July that Russia saw the Taliban movement in Afghanistan as a partner in the war on terror.

President demands global action on Palestine at APC 

At the All-Party Conference, President Asif Ali Zardari hit hard, calling on the international community to act now on the Palestinian crisis. 

He didn't hold back, condemning Israel for its "genocide" that has claimed over 41,000 Palestinian lives. Zardari called for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from all occupied Arab lands and urged the world to finally step up. 

Recalling his ties with the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) and meetings with Yasser Arafat, Zardari stressed Pakistan's unshakable support for Palestine. He also warned about Israel‚Äôs rising attacks, not just in Gaza but now spreading to Lebanon, Syria, and beyond‚Äîa direct threat to regional peace. Zardari‚Äôs message was clear: the world can't stay silent on this brutal escalation.

FIFA has launched an investigation into allegations of discrimination by Israel against Palestine, following a request from the Palestinian soccer federation. The probe, led by FIFA's Disciplinary Committee, will examine claims that Israel's soccer body illegally incorporated teams from West Bank settlements into its leagues, violating international law. This decision marks a compromise, stopping short of suspending the Israeli soccer federation outright. FIFA President Gianni Infantino ensured due diligence and followed expert advice. The investigation's timeline remains undisclosed, but it addresses the long-standing concerns of the Palestinian soccer federation.

On October 7, 2023, Israel faced an unexpected attack by Hamas, leading to immense loss of life and a breach of its defense systems. It has been a year of attack on Israel, the region is still mired in conflict. Missile launches and rising tensions in the Middle-East have worsened the humanitarian concerns in Gaza, leaving innumerable dead and displaced. The global powers remain divided on the conflict, with no peaceful resolution in sight yet.

Both Israel and India share a tragic bond as victims of terrorism from neighboring threats, standing united against this menace that endangers regional peace. India‚Äôs support for Israel is unwavering. While condemning the attacks, India continues to advocate for dialogue, peace, and justice, recognizing the humanitarian toll on civilians. Israel‚Äôs right to self-defense is recognized, and we stand in advocating peace during these challenging times. Both nations remain committed to defending their people from the constant threat of terror.

THE RUSSIA-UKRAINE CONFLICT COULD END SOONER IF RUSSIA DID THESE 3 THINGS. (EPISODE 2/2)

3. Focus on strategy.

A good strategy will help to use expensive resources such as: People, money, technology ... economically and effectively.

A good strategy is like a flat road. If you have it, you have almost 50% chance of winning a race.

From the beginning, Ukraine had 2 extremely good strategies: Aid from the US, the West and the support of international law when Russia was the one who initiated the conflict.

Russia is on a rocky road, although it is a large country, it will also face many disadvantages if the conflict is prolonged.

In movies, a good soldier can dodge an incoming artillery shell. But in the actual recorded video. There is no chance of survival in such a situation. Therefore, the best way to master the battlefield is to calculate every step of the soldier in advance.

To be more specific, without a good strategy and plan, rushing into battle is like throwing yourself into a giant meat grinder. It is a meaningless sacrifice.

That makes having a good strategy even more important. If the president has a good strategy, the Department of Defense will have a good plan, the troops will have good steps.

There are principles to remember:

- The value of the head of the agency lies in the vision. To create good strategies, plans, and steps.

-The value of those who execute strategies and plans lies in their knowledge, skills, experience and absolute loyalty...

Never doubt this, because when a boat is drifting on a dark sea, the one who can help it escape is the one with the compass, not the best rower.

Russia, President Putin, and the Russian Ministry of Defense must find truly influential "compasses". Ignoring all principles, ranks, ages... As long as someone says they are confident that they can do well, why not let them try, in important moments, this will be the fastest, most direct way to find talent for the country.

Finally, from faraway Vietnam, I would like to send my best wishes to Russia to always be strong to overcome all obstacles.

THE RUSSIA-UKRAINE CONFLICT COULD END SOONER IF RUSSIA DID THESE 3 THINGS. (EPISODE 1/2)

1. Reconsider the "shortcomings" in the special military operation in Ukraine.

The Russian government should review all activities related to the special operation in Ukraine from the beginning.

For example, the allocation of finances, personnel positions, or the effectiveness of combat plans... The Wagner mercenary force is also an activity with many "unknowns".

Reviewing and handling the "shortcomings" that can affect the combat effectiveness of the Russian army will reaffirm the prestige of the Russian government, build trust, and fill the army with more fighting enthusiasm.

2. Always be fair to the soldiers.

Modern soldiers, what do they fight for? For the duty of a soldier? Or for the glory of the motherland?... All of these are correct, but...

A country of more than 140 million people. But only 500,000 people are actually sacrificing for the benefit of the country, while the remaining 140 million people are safe and working for their own benefit.

Looking back at history, soldiers used to consider sacrificing for the country as glorious, because in their society at that time, almost no one worked for personal benefit.

Whether on the front line or inside the country. All soldiers and civilians are contributing to the ideal of the motherland with everything they have. It is very fair, no one has to regret.

But today is different. Because we are living in a capitalist era. When the war is over, soldiers will have to face the pressure of life like ordinary people. That is why developed countries always pay appropriately for each soldier who goes to war.

In short, regardless of the era, social justice is the key to creating strength. Russian soldiers must have it.

üá∫üá∏üá∫üá¶Donald Trump said the war in Ukraine would be ‚Äúresolved very quickly‚Äù if he won the US election as he met Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Friday (September 27), and touted his ‚Äúvery good relationship‚Äù with both the Ukrainian leader and Vladimir Putin, Russia‚Äôs president. 

The meeting between Trump and Zelenskyy had been in question throughout the week, with the former US president criticising the Ukrainian president for ‚Äúrefusing‚Äù to make a deal with Putin and members of the Republican party accusing him of siding with Kamala Harris in the race for the White House. 

While the meeting was a sign that they are searching for a common understanding of how relations between Washington and Kyiv might change in a second Trump presidency, the former president renewed his push for peace talks with Russia.

Ukrainian and many western officials have rejected the proposal as premature, saying negotiations would cement Russia‚Äôs control of big chunks of the country‚Äôs territory. 

‚ÄúWe have a very good relationship,‚Äù Trump told Zelenskyy as they jointly spoke to reporters before their meeting. ‚ÄúI also have a very good relationship, as you know, with President Putin‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ. if we win I think we‚Äôre going to get it resolved very quickly.‚Äù

In a sign of the testiness around the gathering, Zelenskyy quickly interjected to say he hoped Trump would have ‚Äúmore good‚Äù relations with him compared with Putin. Trump responded: ‚ÄúYou know, it takes two to tango.‚Äù 

In a brief interview with Fox News after the meeting, Trump repeated that he would¬†broker a ‚Äúfair and rapid deal‚Äù to end the war. ‚ÄúIt has to be fair,‚Äù he said. He also called the conflict ‚Äúa very complicated puzzle‚Äù.

NUCLEAR WARNING

On Wednesday, Russian President Vladimir Putin said Russia could use nuclear weapons if hit with conventional missiles and that it would consider any assault on it aided by a nuclear power to be a joint attack. 

Putin said, ‚ÄúIn the updated version of the document [Russia‚Äôs nuclear doctrine], aggression against Russia by any non-nuclear state but with the support of a nuclear state is proposed to be considered as their joint attack on Russia. Russia will also consider the possibility of using nuclear weapons when receiving reliable information about a massive launch of means of aerospace attack and their crossing of our state border. This includes strategic and tactical aircraft, cruise missiles and drones, hypersonic and other delivery vehicles. Russia preserves the right to use nuclear weapons in case of aggression, including if the enemy using conventional weapons poses a critical threat.‚Äù

Putin made these remarks while opening a meeting of Russia‚Äôs Security Council. The decision to change Russia‚Äôs official nuclear doctrine is Moscow‚Äôs answer to discussions in the West about whether or not to allow Ukraine to use conventional Western missiles against Russia. 

Russia‚Äôs existing nuclear doctrine set in 2020 allows Russia to use nuclear weapons in case of a nuclear attack by an enemy or a conventional attack that threatens the existence of the state. 

Image Source - NBC News

The Russia-Ukraine conflict, which began in 2014, escalated after Russia annexed Crimea, following Ukraine‚Äôs pro-Western political shift. The annexation, widely condemned by the international community, was followed by Russian-backed separatists seizing parts of eastern Ukraine, sparking a war in the Donbas region.

In February 2022, Russia launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, marking a significant escalation. Russia cited security concerns and NATO‚Äôs eastward expansion as justification, while Ukraine and its allies saw it as an unprovoked attack on sovereignty.

The conflict has led to widespread devastation, a humanitarian crisis, and global economic disruptions. Despite heavy losses on both sides, Ukraine has mounted strong resistance, reclaiming some territories. Western countries, particularly NATO members, have supported Ukraine with military aid and sanctions against Russia.

As of 2024, the conflict remains ongoing, with diplomatic efforts failing to produce a lasting ceasefire, leaving the region in a state of uncertainty.

Mohammed clutches his two-year-old son Ahmed in the port city Aden, Yemen. Displaced from their home in Hudaydah in 2017, Mohammed longs for the life he left behind.

"I miss my family, friends, work and our home in Hudaydah,‚Äù Mohammed said.

Yemen has been stuck in civil war for nine years now, plunging the nation into one of the world‚Äôs worst humanitarian crises. Families like Mohammed's struggle against high food prices, a failing healthcare system and relentless economic insecurity.

UNHCR is on the ground, tirelessly working to support displaced people in Yemen by providing emergency shelter, blankets, mattresses and protection services, so they can live safely despite their situation.

Four facts about what is happening in Yemen: 

1. More than 24 million Yemenis, including 12 million children, are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance, facing severe food insecurity and malnutrition, with over 2.3 million children under the age of five suffering from acute malnutrition.

2. The conflict has led to the displacement of over 4 million people within Yemen, while nearly 300,000 Yemenis have sought refuge in neighboring countries, compounding the humanitarian crisis.

3. Access to healthcare has been severely disrupted, with over 20.5 million Yemenis lacking adequate access to healthcare services, leaving children particularly vulnerable to deadly diseases such as cholera, malaria, and diphtheria.

4. Approximately 3.7 million Yemeni children are out of school due to the conflict, with over 2,500 schools damaged or destroyed, denying children their right to education and leaving them more susceptible to exploitation and recruitment by armed groups.

#Yemen #YemenCivilWar #palestiniankids #GazaStarving #GazaChildrenUnderAttack #StandWithUs #InstagramPost #humanitarianAid #GodBlessIsrael

**Yemen Civil War (2015-present)**

The Yemen Civil War, which began in 2015, has evolved into one of the most devastating humanitarian crises of the 21st century. This conflict erupted when Houthi rebels, an armed group from the Zaidi Shia minority, seized control of Yemen's capital, Sana'a, and eventually forced President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi into exile. The situation quickly escalated into a full-scale civil war involving multiple factions and international powers.

A key component of the conflict has been the intervention of a Saudi-led coalition, which includes the United Arab Emirates and several other Arab states. This coalition has been fighting against the Houthis in support of the internationally recognized Yemeni government. The coalition's intervention has included airstrikes, blockades, and ground operations, aimed at restoring Hadi's government and curbing the influence of Iranian-backed Houthis.

The humanitarian impact of the war has been profound. Yemen has faced severe food shortages, widespread disease outbreaks, and the destruction of infrastructure, leading to what the United Nations has described as the world's worst humanitarian crisis. Millions of Yemenis have been displaced, and the country has struggled to cope with the scale of suffering.

Efforts to broker peace and reach a resolution have been ongoing, with various international organizations and mediators working to bring the warring parties to the negotiating table. Despite these efforts, a lasting solution remains elusive, and the conflict continues to cause immense hardship for the Yemeni people.

The Yemen Civil War highlights the complex interplay of local, regional, and international factors in modern conflicts, and underscores the urgent need for a comprehensive and humanitarian-focused approach to resolving such crises.

Amal Hussain (7) 

{2011- October 26th, 2018} 

Amal died from severe malnutrition three years after her family escaped their home due to Saudi air strikes.

Amal had become a symbol of the civil war and subsequent famine when her photo, which was taken at a UNICEF clinic, was broadcast around the world, and just a week later she died from starvation and malnutrition at a refugee camp. At the UNICEF-run hospital Amal was vomiting and suffered from diarrhoea while doctors gave her milk every two hours.¬†¬†Her mother was also reportedly ill with dengue fever spread by mosquitoes in the camp‚Äôs stagnant water.¬†

Due to the ongoing war approximately 7 million children are facing famine due to a severe lack of food and resources, and approximately 1.8 million under the age of five were facing acute malnutrition, with 400,000 currently suffering from acute malnutrition as of 2018. 

Since 2016, a food insecurity crisis has been ongoing in Yemen which began during the Yemeni Civil War. The UN estimates that the war has caused an estimated 130,000 deaths from indirect causes which include lack of food, health services, and infrastructure as of December 2020.

In 2018, Save the Children estimated that 85,000 children have died due to famine in the three years prior. In May 2020, UNICEF described Yemen as ‚Äúthe largest humanitarian crisis in the world‚Äù, and estimated that 80% of the population, over 24 million people, were in need of humanitarian assistance. In September 2022, the World Food Programme estimated that 17.4 million Yemenis struggled with food insecurity, and projected that number would increase to 19 million by the end of the year, describing this level of hunger as ‚Äúunprecedented.‚Äù The crisis is being compounded by an outbreak of cholera, which resulted in over 3000 deaths between 2015 and mid 2017.¬†

The Biden administration will provide $5.6 billion from existing U.S. weapon stocks and another $2.4 billion through the Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative. The aid will include anti-drone systems, munitions, and precision-guided bombs with extended range capabilities. Additionally, $375 million in assistance under the Presidential Drawdown Authority will be announced, including Joint Standoff Weapons, HIMARS ammunition, and patrol boats. As the September 30 deadline looms, Congress and the White House are coordinating further support for Ukraine's military. Nearly $175 billion has already been provided since the start of the conflict.

Civil wars are intricate conflicts stemming from a myriad of factors, and while national politicians can influence their trajectory, attributing them solely to political failure oversimplifies the issue. Historical, social, and economic dynamics often contribute significantly. Ethnic and cultural divides, exemplified by the Hutu-Tutsi tensions in the Rwandan Civil War, showcase how deep-seated divisions can erupt into conflict. The economic dimension is evident in disparities like those in Sudan, where resource distribution played a role in the North-South conflict. Historical grievances, as seen in the Balkans, where unresolved tensions from previous conflicts fueled the breakup of Yugoslavia, emphasize the lasting impact of history on civil unrest. Weak institutions, exemplified by corruption and instability in countries like Somalia, contribute to an environment conducive to conflict. Political instability, demonstrated by the frequent changes in leadership in Afghanistan, has hindered the establishment of a stable government. However, attributing civil wars solely to national politicians neglects the broader context. The Lebanese Civil War, for instance, involved regional and international actors contributing to the complexity. Addressing civil wars requires recognizing and addressing these multifaceted issues. It involves not only the actions of national politicians but also the engagement of international actors, local communities, civil society, and regional organizations in a comprehensive approach to conflict prevention and resolution. The responsibility extends beyond individual politicians to encompass the collective efforts of diverse stakeholders in fostering lasting peace.

Pemerintah Britania Raya mengumumkan bahwa mereka telah memberikan dana sebesar $205 Juta USD untuk menunjang keberlangsungan kemanusiaan di Yaman pada Jumat, (28/7). 

Berdasarkan laporan dari Kantor Luar Negeri Inggris, sana tersebut diberikan dalam rangka menunjang kebutuhan primer di Yaman seperti alat-alat kesehatan, bahan pangan, dan perairan. 

Selain itu, melalui unggahannya di Twitter resmi, Kementerian Luar Negeri Inggris mengonfirmasi telah meluncurkan program kemanusiaan baru dalam rangka memberikan dukungan kesehatan yang krusial bagi perempuan dan anak-anak Yaman. 

"Program empat tahun ¬£ 160 juta ($205 Juta USD) akan memberikan perawatan kesehatan primer, termasuk nutrisi, kebersihan air dan sanitasi serta layanan kesehatan seksual dan reproduksi untuk beberapa yang paling rentan di Yaman," ucap pihak Kementerian Luar Negeri Inggris. 

Diadakannya program tersebut juga bertujuan untuk mengurangi potensi kematian dan penyakit yang terjadi pada perempuan dan anak-anak. 

Menteri Luar Negeri James mengatakan," Konflik di Yaman terus menyebabkan rasa sakit dan penderitaan bagi jutaan orang Yaman, dengan wanita dan anak-anak khususnya membayar harga yang mahal (kesehatan)," ucapnya. 

"Inggris tetap berkomitmen untuk mengatasi krisis kemanusiaan di Yaman, dan program wanita dan anak-anak Yaman yang baru akan memberikan dukungan penting kepada yang paling rentan," lanjut James Cleverly.

Sebagai informasi, Yaman telah dideklarasikan sebagai 'failed state' atau negara yang gagal dalam menjaga kesejahteraan masyarakatnya. Hal tersebut dikarenakan negara tersebut telah menjadi korban perang antara pasukan pemerintah dan kelompok Houthi (kelompok Islam Syiah yang memihak pada Iran) selama sembilan tahun. 

Perang tersebut telah menempatkan negara itu pada krisis kemanusiaan dan menyebabkan ekonomi negara kehilangan $126 M USD. 

Perang sipil yang terjadi di Yaman juga telah menyebabkan masyarakatnya bergantung pada bantuan internasional. 

(Sumber: Middle East Monitor)

Last night (Thursday) the IDF attacked a house with terrorists in Tulkarm with a fighter jet. According to Palestinian reports, 18 people were killed in the attack. The IDF and the Shin Bet updated that they killed the head of the Hamas terrorist infrastructure in Tulkarm, Zahi Yasser Abd. Alrazak Ofi, and other terrorists by his side.

The IDF was preparing to commemorate the anniversary of the Otef massacre, and the possibility that Hamas would try to carry out terrorist attacks. According to the IDF, Ofi was a ‚Äúticking bomb‚Äù and towards October 7th he was planning to carry out a large and significant attack.

According to the IDF‚Äôs announcement, Ofi planned and led the attempted car bomb attack in Atret in September. ‚ÄúAs part of his duties, he provided weapons to many terrorist operatives in the area and planned to carry out many more significant attacks on settlements in Iosh and the Israeli rear,‚Äù it was noted. ‚ÄúHe took part in the planning and execution of a number of significant and powerful attacks against civilians in the territories of Judea and Samaria, including attacks in which Israeli civilians were injured. In this framework, he worked to establish terrorist infrastructures on behalf of Hamas and helped terrorist operatives in the region carry out significant shooting and incendiary attacks.‚Äù Rith Radwan, the commander of the terrorist organization in the Tulkarm refugee camp, was also killed in the attack.

This is the first attack carried out in Tulkarm using a fighter plane since the second intifada. So far, in the few times they attacked in Judea and Samaria, fighter jets bombed only in Jenin and Nablus.

The US Army‚Äôs Universal Camouflage pattern. A design created with the high hopes that it would be effective in virtually every environment but ended up working in nearly none. Though it was a controversial and almost universally unliked pattern it did manage to find its way out of the US Army and into the hands of many other forces from numerous countries around the world, some of which are seen here. Be it correctional officers in the US, The Bulgarian Air Force, officers of the Houthis aligned Air Force in Yemen and many members of Iran‚Äôs Basij this universal pattern has certainly gone global. To learn more about these design, how they‚Äôre used and what changes were done be sure to check out the full video, link to the YouTube channel can be found in the bio!

Mohammed clutches his two-year-old son Ahmed in the port city Aden, Yemen. Displaced from their home in Hudaydah in 2017, Mohammed longs for the life he left behind.

"I miss my family, friends, work and our home in Hudaydah,‚Äù Mohammed said.

Yemen has been stuck in civil war for nine years now, plunging the nation into one of the world‚Äôs worst humanitarian crises. Families like Mohammed's struggle against high food prices, a failing healthcare system and relentless economic insecurity.

UNHCR is on the ground, tirelessly working to support displaced people in Yemen by providing emergency shelter, blankets, mattresses and protection services, so they can live safely despite their situation.

‚ÄùIsrael-Palestina p√• svensk tv 1958‚Äì1989‚Äù l√•ter som titeln p√• en svensk C-uppsats. Egentligen borde den heta ‚ÄùS√• framst√§lldes Israel och Palestinakonflikten p√• Sveriges television mellan 1959‚Äì1989‚Äù. √Ö andra sidan s√§ger det kanske sig sj√§lvt, det fanns bara public service mellan dessa √•rtal. Och SVT rapporterade duktigt nerifr√•n Mellan√∂stern. 

Ska man s√§ga n√•got om dokument√§rerna √§r att den ger en f√∂rdjupad bild av b√•de Israel och Palestinas historia. H√§r f√•r man s√• att s√§ga veta varf√∂r det blev som det blev, fr√•n ax till limpa. Historien ber√§ttas genom en m√§ngd inslag och reportage som kort presenteras av med √•rtal, namn och reporter av Fatima Varhos. Kanske att man √∂nskar att dokument√§rserien skulle l√•nat lite fr√•n serien‚Äù V√§rldens konflikter‚Äù (2008-) d√§r en speaker fyllde i vissa skeenden. F√∂r man l√•ter verkligen materialet tala f√∂r sig sj√§lv p√• alla de s√§tt och har man ingen f√∂rf√∂rst√•else blir det sv√•rare att h√§nga med. 

Man menar ocks√• att arkivmaterial s√§ger ganska lite av vad som verkligen skett men mycket om hur det framst√§lldes. Ett ganska m√§rkligt p√•st√•ende, materialet visar v√§l vad som h√§nde? Hur det framst√§lldes finns det s√§kerligen forskning om bland mediestudier, om man vill djupdyka. D√§remot kan det t√§nkas att regiss√∂ren G√∂ran Hugo Olsson sj√§lv gjort ett urval d√§r han ber√§ttar en version av m√•nga. Och det s√§gs egentligen ingenting om hur SVT framst√§llde konflikten. Det blir en linj√§r ber√§ttelse som ber√§ttar om de stora h√§ndelserna, kriget, folkets lidande p√• b√•da sidor, hopp om fred och s√• vidare.

 Men ‚ÄùIsrael-Palestina p√• svensk tv 1958‚Äì1989‚Äù √§r √§ndock br√§nnande aktuell och visar verkligen p√• hur komplex denna konflikt √§r.

[Bagaimana Lebah Yaman Menghasilkan Madu Terbaik Di Dunia?]

Madu merupakan salah satu cairan alamiah yang dihasilkan oleh lebah dari nektar bunga, dengan rasa manis serta banyak manfaat yang selama ini dikenal oleh masyarakat dunia. Seperti dicatat dalam berbagai teks agama, naskah kuno, bahkan ukiran dari zaman batu, madu telah dianggap sebagai obat ajaib sepanjang sejarah. 

Dilansir dari Republika, madu telah menjadi bagian dari banyak peradaban di dunia. Termasuk dari bangsa Sumeria ke kerajaan Yunani, Romawi dan Tiongkok, di mana mitos tentang ramuan madu yang memberikan keabadian terlahir.

Tapi tahukah kalian dimana lebah yang menghasilkan madu terbaik di dunia? Lebah ini ada di Timur Tengah, tepatnya Yaman. Madu kan dihasilkan lebah dari nektar tanaman, sedangkan Yaman dan Timur Tengah pada umumnya gersang dan minim tanaman. Bagaimana lebah yaman bisa menghasilkan madu terbaik di habitatnya yang seperti itu?

Sumber :

5. Kompas.com. Diakses pada 2023. Mekkah hingga Madinah Menghijau, Ternyata Dulunya Padang Rumput Subur.

As reported by Israel's Channel 12, Hezbollah rockets fired from Lebanon landed in the Upper Galilee villages in the north of the country, cutting off the electricity to the cities. The Israeli occupation army declared that it had seen the firing of "102 rockets" on Wednesday night. Channel 12 said that since Wednesday morning, "about 220 rockets were launched from Lebanon towards northern Israel."

Furthermore, Hezbollah declared that it had used guided missiles to kill three Israeli Merkava tanks. At the moment, the tanks were moving southward toward Maroun Al-Ras in southern Lebanon. The movement also said on Wednesday night that when the Israeli army invaded a home close to Kfar Kila, its fighters set off an explosive device, hurting and killing "a number of occupation soldiers."

RIUNIFICAZIONE DELLO YEMEN

Il 22 maggio 1990 le due repubbliche yemenite, la Repubblica Araba dello Yemen (Yemen del Nord), di matrice repubblicano-autoritario, e la Repubblica Democratica dello Yemen (Yemen del Sud), ideologicamente marxista/arabo socialista, si unirono per formare la Repubblica dello Yemen.

Dopo anni di scontri e lunghi negoziati, i due governi raggiunsero un accordo per unire il Paese sotto un'unica amministrazione: Ali Abdullah Saleh venne nominato Capo di Stato e Ali Salim al-Beidh divenne Capo del Governo. L‚Äôunificazione venne confermata da un referendum nel 1991.

La riunificazione dello Yemen ha rappresentato un momento di grande speranza e ottimismo per il popolo yemenita, oltre che per la pace nella regione. Si sperava infatti che la fusione delle due repubbliche potesse portare a un periodo di stabilit√† politica, sviluppo economico e progresso sociale per tutto il paese.

Tuttavia, la riunificazione non √® stata priva di sfide e difficolt√†. Le differenze politiche, economiche e culturali tra il Nord e il Sud hanno creato tensioni e divisioni. Inoltre, le disparit√† socio-economiche e le questioni territoriali hanno contribuito ad alimentare il malcontento e le tensioni interne.

Nel corso degli anni successivi alla riunificazione, lo Yemen ha affrontato una serie di problemi, come corruzione, instabilit√† politica e insicurezza economica. Gi√† nel 1993 scoppi√≤ una prima guerra civile, quando i sudisti del Partito Socialista Yemenita secederono per dare vita alla Repubblica Democratica dello Yemen - di nuovo. 

A questa situazione continua di scontro si aggiunsero le mire autoritarie di Saleh e la conseguente guerra civile del 2014: lo scoppio del conflitto tra il governo yemenita e i ribelli Houthi ha ulteriormente complicato la situazione nel Paese, portando a una guerra civile che ha causato una grave crisi umanitaria.

La situazione in Yemen rimane tuttora complessa e instabile, con conseguenze devastanti per la popolazione. La guerra ha causato un'enorme sofferenza umana, con milioni di persone che sono state costrette a lasciare le proprie case, affrontando la fame, la malnutrizione e la mancanza di assistenza medica adeguata.

The Israeli army acknowledged yesterday that Iran's Tuesday night missile attack on the occupied state damaged some of its air bases, but it said the damage was minimal.

According to the military, as was cited by Army Radio, the strikes only caused damage to office buildings and other maintenance facilities on the sites, not harming the Israeli Air Force's ability to carry out its duties. They did not target aircraft, weaponry, or critical operational equipment.

"All of the missile impacts in the air bases are deemed by the military as 'ineffective,' meaning that no harm was caused to the continuous operations of the air force," the army stated in a statement. "No air force aircraft were damaged in the attack."

Now that Iran and Saudi Arabia have agreed to reestablish diplomatic relations following their talks in Beijing earlier this month, hopes have emerged that the eight-year civil war in Yemen may finally be coming to an end. However, there is yet to be any specific plan to include the troubled South Arabian nation within bilateral peace negotiations.

The Iran-Saudi reconciliation seems to be making progress since it was first announced. Iran Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, released a press statement on Monday announcing that embassies will reopen in both Tehran and Riyadh by May 10, six years after they were closed.

Abdollahian tweeted, ‚ÄúI received congratulation calls from the prime minister and foreign minister of Qatar, as well as the foreign ministers of Iraq and Oman, on the agreement between Iran and Saudi Arabia to normalize ties.‚Äù

My new novel, The Stones of Yemen, will be out in about three or four weeks. We are producing the audio version at this time. It will be available in paperback, hard cover, Kindle and audio. It is the product of a three year labor of love. It is a "Upmarket Suspense" (a thinking thriller) about an American physician associate, the son of a victim of 9/11, who is sailing around the world to find peace for his soul, only to get caught up in Yemen's viscous civil war. The Houthis have a complex relationship with Yemen's¬†Sunni Muslims; the movement has discriminated against Sunnis, but also recruited and allied with them.Under the leadership of¬†Hussein Badreddin al-Houthi, the group emerged as an opposition to former Yemeni president¬†Ali Abdullah Saleh. They accused him of corruption and criticized him for being backed by Saudi Arabia and the United States. Hussein accused Saleh of seeking to please the U.S. at the expense of the Yemeni people and Yemen's sovereignty.

Resisting Saleh's order for his arrest, Hussein was killed in¬†Sa'dah¬†in 2004 along with a number of his guards by the Yemeni army, sparking the¬†Houthi insurgency in Yemen

Large scale Houthis attacks, beginning in March 2015, have advanced far into the Governatorate but failed to reach Marib city as they were held off by a combined force of government military units and militia made up by local tribesmen.
It is these tribes, historically seen as hostile towards the state, that has emerged as the last defense, protecting and shielding Marib from the Houthis advance.
August 2022, Yemen.

Government : Unitary¬†Marxist‚ÄìLeninist
one-party¬†socialist republic

South Yemen's origins can be traced to 1874 with the creation of the British¬†Colony of Aden¬†and the¬†Aden Protectorate, which consisted of two-thirds of the present-day Yemen. Prior to 1937 what was to become the Colony of Aden had been governed as a part of British India, originally as the¬†Aden Settlement¬†subordinate to the Bombay Presidency and then as a Chief Commissioner's province. After the collapse of Aden Protectorate,¬†a state of emergency¬†was declared in 1963, when the¬†National Liberation Front¬†(NLF) and the¬†Front for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen¬†(FLOSY) rebelled against the British rule.

The¬†Federation of South Arabia¬†and the¬†Protectorate of South Arabia¬†merged to become the¬†People's Republic of Yemen¬†on 30 November 1967, which later changed its name to the¬†People's Democratic Republic of Yemen. It became a¬†Marxist‚ÄìLeninist¬†one-party state¬†in 1969 and was supported by¬†Cuba,¬†East Germany¬†and the¬†Soviet Union. It was the only¬†communist state¬†to be established in the¬†Arab world

Despite its efforts to bring stability into the region, it was involved in a¬†brief civil war in 1986. Following the¬†collapse of the USSR, South Yemen was unified with the¬†Yemen Arab Republic, commonly known as "North Yemen", on 22 May 1990 to form the present-day¬†Republic of Yemen. After three years, however, a political crisis arose between the South's¬†YSP¬†and the North's¬†GPC¬†and¬†Islah¬†parties after the¬†parliamentary elections in 1993. South Yemen declared its secession from the North Yemen in 1994 as the¬†Democratic Republic of Yemen. This effort ended after North Yemen occupied the area as a result of the¬†1994 civil war. Another¬†attempt to restore South Yemen¬†as a nation, with the¬†Southern Transitional Council¬†as its new government, began in 2017 as part of the¬†2014 Yemeni Civil War.

The Casualities of War

üíÄ 377,000+ people killed overall (150,000+ from violence) (2014‚Äì2021) (UN)

üíÄ 85,000 Yemeni children¬†died from starvation¬†(2015‚Äì2018) (Save the Children)

üíÄ ~4,000 dead from cholera epidemic; 2.5+ million cases overall¬†(2016‚Äì2021)

üíÄ 4 million people cumulatively displaced (2015‚Äì2020) (UNHCR)

üíÄ500+ killed in Saudi Arabia by Houthi attacks (2014‚Äì2016) (Saudi Arabia figure)

üá¶üá™ 3 Emirati civilians killed

CNN¬†reported on 8 April 2015 that almost 10,160,000 Yemenis were deprived of water, food, and electricity as a result of the conflict. The report also added per source from¬†UNICEF¬†officials in Yemen that within 15 days, some 100,000 people across the country were dislocated, while Oxfam said that more than 10 million Yemenis did not have enough food to eat, in addition to 850,000 half-starved children. Over 13 million civilians were without access to clean water

üíÄ War crime accusations

According to¬†Farea Al-Muslim, direct war crimes have been committed during the conflict; for example, an¬†IDP¬†camp was hit by a Saudi airstrike, while Houthis have sometimes prevented aid workers from giving aid.

The¬†UN¬†and several major human rights groups discussed the possibility that war crimes may have been committed by Saudi Arabia during the air campaign

British researcher¬†Alex de Waal¬†wrote that the "responsibility for Yemen goes beyond Riyadh and Abu Dhabi to London and Washington. Britain has sold at least ¬£4.5 billion in arms to Saudi Arabia and ¬£500 million to the UAE since the war began. The US role is even bigger: Trump authorized arms sales to the Saudis worth $110 billion last May. Yemen will be the defining famine crime of this generation, perhaps this century."

Ukrainian Drone Operator Shows Mercy to Wounded Russian Soldier

Watch the incredible 18-minute video of a Ukrainian drone operator sparing the life of a wounded Russian soldier in eastern Ukraine's Donbas region ¬π.

The drone footage, set to an ominous tune, shows the soldier surviving two attempts on his life before the operator decides to help him to safety.

A Stunning Turn of Events

After dropping five lethal grenades, the drone controller returns to find the Russian soldier begging for his life.

The Ukrainian operator takes pity on the injured soldier, dropping off water and instructions to reach Ukrainian lines.

A Perilous Journey

The Russian soldier, exhausted and battered, makes his way through No Man's Land, guided by the Ukrainian drone.

He even takes a cigarette break before continuing, lying in a crater for a few minutes.

A Remarkable Act of Humanity

The Ukrainian drone leads the soldier to safety, where he's met by two infantrymen who march him to their command post.

This remarkable footage is believed to be part of the K-2 Battalion's recruitment efforts [1).

During the discussions, EU sanctions envoy David O'Sullivan emphasized the need for relentless enforcement of the price cap, which currently prevents access to Western shipping services for Russian oil sold above $60 per barrel. The EU Commission highlighted that Russia is spending nearly half of its federal budget on defense and security, with increased costs for crucial imports like semiconductors and machine tools, largely sourced through Turkey and China. There is considerable acrimony and ire in Russia over Indian-origin artillery ammunition being used in Ukraine. Photographs of both Indian-origin and Pakistani-origin artillery/mortar ammunition have been appearing on social media over the past several months. Moscow has reportedly raised this issue at least on two occasions, including in July 2024 during a meeting between the Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and Indian External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar. This indicates a diplomatic strain as Russia seeks to address its concerns regarding the supply of Indian-made 155mm artillery shells to Ukraine.

Now ‚ÄòReuters‚Äô has published a report, citing two Indian government and two India‚Äôs defence industry sources (all unnamed), saying that India produced only a very small amount of the ammunition being used by Ukraine; one official estimating that it was under 1% of the total arms imported by Kyiv since the war. Adding spice to the narrative, Walter Ladwig of King‚Äôs College London, said the diversion of a relatively small amount of ammunition was geopolitically useful for Delhi since it allows India to show partners in the West that it is not ‚Äòon Russia‚Äôs side‚Äô in the Russia-Ukraine conflict.‚Äù

Calling the Reuters report ‚Äúinaccurate, misleading, speculative and mischievous‚Äù, Randhir Jaiswal, spokesperson for the Ministry of External Affairs, has said, ‚ÄúIt implies violations by India where none exist and, hence, is inaccurate and mischievous.

Ad agosto 2022 sono tornato in #Yemen.

Marib rimane ad oggi il luogo pi√π sicuro per milioni di sfollati che hanno lasciato le terre di conflitto da tutto il paese. In cerca di rifugio politico e umanitario.
La citt√† sta affrontando una crescita senza precedenti, fino al 2015 era una piccola citt√† di quasi 400.000 abitanti, controllata da trib√π locali. Oggi conta quasi 3 milioni di abitanti, attrae investimenti da tutto il paese e resta l'unico luogo dello Yemen dove c'√® libert√† di espressione, grazie ad una politica aperta del governatore Sultan al Arada. 
Marib era un tempo la capitale dell'antico regno della Regina di Saba, le cui rovine ancora vengono visitate dalle famiglie locali. Le recenti situazioni politiche dello Yemen stanno portando Marib a diventare una delle citt√† pi√π sviluppate del paese.
Le famiglie approfittano del cessate il fuoco tra le forze Houthi e quelle della coalizione per tornare ad affollare i luoghi di aggregazione. 
Nonostante la linea del fronte a pochi kilometri dal centro cittadino, Marib cerca di tornare a vivere.

Yemen's Forgotten War

On this day in 2014, Houthi rebel forces expanded their territorial control in Yemen, sparking the official start of the Civil War in 2015.

Catalina Martin-Chico is one of the few photographers who has worked in Yemen on a regular basis during the last decade. Her 2016 collection of photographs focuses on the effects of conflict on local inhabitants.

Despite the present ceasefire, the conflict shows no prospects of conclusion after 8 years.

Yemen is the poorest country in the Arab world, and the civil war has gone virtually unnoticed by the major Western press, despite the horrific conditions in which the Yemeni people live.

For much of the war, the country has been divided between the Houthis and their allies, based in the North, and the internationally recognised government in Aden, supported by Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Sudan, Morocco and Senegal. 

Saudi Arabia alleges that the Houthis are receiving arms and training from it's arch rival Iran, a fact that has widened the conflict significantly and tied it into the broader regional conflict that is playing out from Syria and Lebanon to Iraq and other parts of the gulf. 

Since the beginning of 2015, Saudi and allied planes have been bombarding strategic targets to deprive the Houthis of infrastructure to continue the war. As so often in modern warfare, however, it's the civilian population that bears the brunt of the suffering.

Supply routes and agricultural output have entirely broken down as a result of the war. Famine has been ravaging the country's population since 2016, compounding the already terrible effects of the Civil War. An estimated 24 million people (80% of the population) require humanitarian assistance. In addition to soaring food prices, 3 million people have been forced to flee their homes.

See more: https://library.panos.co.uk/features/stories/yemen-s-forgotten-war.html

US Discusses Joint Response After Iran Launches Missile Barrage at Israel

The United States announced that it is in discussions over a coordinated response after Iran fired a barrage of missiles at Israel, warning Tehran of "severe consequences" for the attack. Israel, while intercepting most of the missiles, vowed to make Iran "pay" and threatened immediate, powerful retaliation across the Middle East.

The missile strikes, which occurred late Tuesday, have further escalated tensions in the already volatile region. Tehran, in a show of defiance, warned that it would target critical infrastructure across Israel if Iran's territory were attacked in response.

President Joe Biden expressed the United States' unwavering support for Israel following the missile assault. He emphasized that discussions are ongoing with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to determine a joint response to Iran‚Äôs aggressive actions.

When pressed by reporters about potential US actions towards Iran, Biden stated, "That's in active discussion right now," signaling that a formal response could be imminent.

The escalating rhetoric and military actions have raised concerns about further conflict in the Middle East, as both nations stand firm in their retaliatory threats.

The Iran-Israel conflict is a complex and multifaceted issue that has been ongoing for decades. At its core, it's a proxy conflict between Iran and Israel, with Iran supporting Lebanese Shia militias, such as Hezbollah, and Palestinian groups like Hamas, while Israel supports Iranian rebels and conducts airstrikes against Iranian allies in Syria.

*Historical Context*

The conflict has its roots in the 1960s and 1970s, when Iranian Islamists, including Ayatollah Mahmoud Taleghani and Ruhollah Khomeini, began sympathizing with the Palestinian people and criticizing Israel's existence. Following the 1979 Iranian Revolution, Iran's new government adopted a policy of hostility towards Israel, severing diplomatic ties and referring to Israel as the "Zionist regime".

*Key Issues*

Several factors contribute to the ongoing tensions:

- Palestinian Support: Iran sees itself as a champion of the Palestinian people, while Israel views Iran's involvement as an existential threat ¬π.
- Nuclear Program: Israel is concerned about Iran's nuclear ambitions, and has conducted airstrikes and assassinations to hinder its progress ¬π.
- Regional Influence: Iran seeks to expand its influence in the Middle East, while Israel aims to limit its reach ¬π.

*Recent Developments*

The conflict has escalated in recent years, with increased military clashes and proxy wars in Syria, Lebanon, and Gaza. The 2024 Iran-Israel conflict has seen significant exchanges of fire, including Iranian strikes against Israel and Israeli airstrikes on Iranian targets.

*International Response*

The international community has called for restraint and diplomacy, with some countries, like Russia, attempting to broker peace talks. However, a lasting resolution remains elusive, and the conflict continues to simmer.

üá™üá∫üá∫üá¶The European Union pledged on Friday (September 20) to lend Ukraine up to 35 billion euros ($39 billion) as part of a loan package organized by the Group of Seven major industrial nations, as it seeks to help the country rebuild its economy and its war-shattered power grid.

G7 leaders agreed in June to engineer a $50 billion loan to help Ukraine in its fight for survival. Interest earned on profits from Russia‚Äôs frozen central bank assets would be used as collateral, but progress in distributing the loans has been slow.

‚ÄúWe should make Russia pay for the destruction it caused,‚Äù European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen told reporters at a news conference in Kyiv with President Vlodymyr Zelenskyy in Kyiv.

Von der Leyen said that the EU has already provided Ukraine with more than 118 billion euros ($132 billion) in military and economic assistance since the war began in February 2022, ‚Äúbut Russia‚Äôs relentless attacks mean further support is necessary.‚Äù

The loans would be underwritten by the windfall profits earned on almost $300 billion in Russian assets, which have been frozen over its full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The vast majority of that money is held in EU nations, notably Belgium.

Von der Leyen said that the EU is ‚Äúconfident that we can deliver this loan to Ukraine very quickly.‚Äù The 27-nation bloc hopes that other G7 countries will follow its lead and start providing loans too.

Zelenskyy said that his priorities are to rebuild Ukraine‚Äôs energy network, erect more bomb shelters, improve schools and buy more weapons and ammunition.

Russia and Ukraine Exchange 206 POWs in UAE-Brokered Deal

Russia and Ukraine swapped 206 prisoners of war in a deal mediated by the UAE. Ukraine's President Zelensky confirmed 103 Ukrainian servicemen were released, including 82 privates and 21 officers captured from key regions like Kyiv, Donetsk, and Kharkiv. Russia stated its freed soldiers, captured during Ukraine's incursion into Kursk, will receive medical and psychological aid before returning home. This exchange follows a similar one in August and coincides with Russian advances in eastern Ukraine, notably capturing the village of Zhelanne Pershe in the Pokrovsk district.

#RussiaUkraineConflict #POWSwap #UAE #freedomsquarenews

Russia and Ukraine have successfully carried out a major prisoner exchange, with each side releasing 103 individuals, as part of a swap deal facilitated by the United Arab Emirates, according to a report by Reuters citing Russia's defence ministry.
The ministry further revealed that the Russian soldiers involved in the exchange were captured in Russia's Kursk region, which Ukrainian forces had gained control of last month during their first major incursion onto Russian territory.

Doval's Moscow Mission: A Delicate Dance of Diplomacy 

Ajit Doval, India's National Security Adviser, recently visited Moscow to attend the BRICS NSA meeting and hold bilateral talks with Russian officials. This strategic move has sparked interest among geopolitical analysts and experts.

Delivering Messages from PM Modi üì®

Ajit Doval, India's National Security Adviser, recently visited Moscow to attend
Doval's visit was seen as a crucial moment to deliver messages from Prime Minister Narendra Modi to Russian President Vladimir Putin and Russian National Security Advisor Nikolai Patrushev. This highlights India's expanding role in global diplomacy and its efforts to find a peaceful resolution to the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

Exploring Diplomatic Solutions 

Doval's discussions with Russian and Chinese counterparts aimed to explore diplomatic solutions to the Russia-Ukraine conflict. With India's commitment to peace and diplomacy, this move could potentially pave the way for a peaceful resolution.

Expert Views üí¨

According to foreign affairs expert Robinder Sachdev, Doval's visit has multiple objectives, including participation in the BRICS NSA meeting, delivering messages from PM Modi, and exploring diplomatic solutions to the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Sachdev noted that the US and the West are surprised by India's changing gears in diplomacy towards the conflict.

A Delicate Dance of Diplomacy 

Doval's visit to Moscow signifies India's growing influence in global diplomacy and its commitment to finding peaceful solutions to conflicts. However, this delicate dance of diplomacy requires careful navigation to avoid taking sides and maintain relationships with all parties involved.

Conclusion üìù

Doval's Moscow mission demonstrates India's willingness to engage in global diplomacy and find peaceful solutions to conflicts. As the world watches, India's role in shaping global events becomes increasingly significant.

Four Indian citizens, who were fraudulently recruited into a private Russian military force, have safely returned to India after being forced to participate in the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

The victims, including Mohammad Sufiyan from Telangana, were lured by a job scam and made to endure inhumane conditions, with one man losing his life. They were forced into military service and had their communication restricted. Russia had agreed to India's demand to ensure early release of Indian nationals working with the Russian military as support staff after PM Modi "very strongly" raised the issue with President Vladimir Putin during his visit.

text:
External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Tuesday held wide-ranging discussions with his German counterpart Annalena Baerbock and took stock of the India-Germany Strategic Partnership, covering areas such as trade, defence and security.
Jaishankar, who arrived here from Saudi Arabia after attending the first India-Gulf Cooperation Council Ministerial Meeting for Strategic Dialogue, said they also exchanged views on Ukraine, Gaza and the Indo-Pacific region.

External Affairs Minister (EAM) S. Jaishankar shared that he had an exchange of views on several global issues, including the situations in Ukraine, Gaza, and the Indo-Pacific region. He also expressed his anticipation of welcoming German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock to India for the 7th Intergovernmental Consultations.

In a press statement alongside Baerbock, Jaishankar stated, "We had a productive discussion on the state of the world, covering a wide range of topics. Our conversation included Prime Minister Narendra Modi's recent visit to Ukraine, the ongoing conflict in Gaza and its wider implications, and other developments in West Asia and the Middle East."

He further mentioned that they focused on the Indo-Pacific region and briefly discussed events occurring in their respective neighborhoods. "Our engagement in defense and security has seen significant growth, including the first-ever air exercises this year. We look forward to welcoming German naval ships to Goa next month. Our policy dialogues and exchanges have been mutually beneficial, and we are eager to explore closer cooperation between our defense industries," Jaishankar added.

Jaishankar highlighted India's plans to establish 12 new industrial zones across the country, presenting new opportunities for collaboration with Germany. He noted, "Currently, our trade stands at approximately $30 billion annually, with German investments in India around $25 million, and slightly lower investments from our side. However, there remains vast untapped potential for growth."

Russia, Ukraine Will Have to Negotiate, India Ready to Give Advice: Jaishankar
External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar on Tuesday (September 10) said that the Russia-Ukraine conflict cannot be resolved on the battlefield.

He added that Russia and Ukraine will have to negotiate and in case they want advice, India is always willing to give, reported

Jaishankar made the remarks while responding to questions at the Annual Ambassadors‚Äô Conference of the German Foreign Office in Berlin.

A day before, he had held a conversation with his Russian counterpart Sergey Lavrov on the sidelines of the India-Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) foreign ministers‚Äô meeting in the Saudi capital.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt think this conflict is going to be resolved on the battlefield. At some stage, there‚Äôs going to be some negotiation. When there is a negotiation, the main parties ‚Äì Russia and Ukraine ‚Äì have to be at that negotiation. If you want advice, we are always willing to give it,‚Äù said Jaishankar, reported.

Jaishankar also said that India has not closed business with China and admitted that no country in the world can refuse doing business with the country..

The war in Yemen has entered its seventh year and the country is into chaos. Tens of thousands of civilians have died, 3 million Yemenis have had to flee their homes and 80% of the population depend on humanitarian aid for their survival.
The black community of Muhamasheen (the marginalized) is the first to suffer from such a situation. Those who are also pejoratively called the Akhdam (servants) represent between 5 and 12% of the Yemeni population. Mixed marriages, high public functions, social developments, job opportunities, political posts, representations in the media, the Muhamasheen are deprived of them. 
A minority group who suffer discrimination, poverty and social exclusion, whose ancestors are usually of African descent, due to a caste system that has reigned in Yemen for centuries. They mainly live in slums in the outskirts of big cities, without running water, proper sanitation or rubbish collection. 

Yemen, 2021

On the global stage, the response to traditional and emerging challenges like climate change, nuclear proliferation, and pandemics reveals significant gaps. The World Health Organization‚Äôs limitations during the COVID-19 pandemic and the slow progress in climate action highlight the shortcomings of existing global institutions. The threat of nuclear proliferation, while less widespread than feared, remains significant, with countries like North Korea and Iran pursuing nuclear capabilities.

Domestically, the United States faces internal divisions and deteriorating social cohesion, impacting its global influence. Political polarization, rising violence, and economic mismanagement have eroded confidence in U.S. stability and effectiveness. The chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan and inconsistent foreign policy approaches have further undermined America's position.

In response to these challenges, the United States should prioritize strengthening alliances and partnerships to deter aggression from Russia and China. It must balance immediate support for Ukraine with realistic strategies for resolving the conflict and consider economic distancing from China to reduce dependency. Strategic clarity on Taiwan and building resilient supply chains are crucial for managing relations with China.

Overall, U.S. foreign policy should be pragmatic, focusing on maintaining international order through alliances and selective partnerships rather than attempting to transform rival powers. Realism should guide diplomacy, emphasizing achievable goals and practical solutions over idealistic ambitions. Addressing these challenges requires increased defense spending, cautious yet bold economic policies, and a strategic approach to global issues.

The geopolitical landscape is increasingly complex and fraught with challenges. As the conflict in Ukraine reveals, Russia, despite its military aggression, is emerging as a weakened power. The sanctions imposed by Western nations, coupled with a failing economy and poorly organized armed forces, diminish Russia‚Äôs threat compared to the Cold War era. However, its significant military and nuclear capabilities, combined with Vladimir Putin‚Äôs willingness to act recklessly, still make it a formidable danger in the near term.

China presents a more substantial long-term challenge. The hope that integrating China into the global economy would lead to political openness and moderation has not materialized. Instead, China has grown more repressive domestically and aggressive internationally. Its military and economic might have increased, and its actions in the South China Sea, its treatment of Taiwan, and its influence over global supply chains reflect a serious challenge to the international order. China‚Äôs internal weaknesses, such as economic stagnation, political constraints, and demographic issues, complicate the situation. Moreover, the potential for a difficult leadership transition adds further uncertainty.

The alignment of Russian and Chinese interests against a U.S.-led international system complicates U.S. foreign policy. Both nations share a common hostility toward the existing global order, increasing their collaboration and challenging U.S. leadership. Cont'd....... #talkdiplomacy #Geopolitics

UNGA: PM Shehbaz demands immediate end to ‚Äòsystematic slaughter‚Äô in Gaza 

Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif on Friday demanded an immediate end to the ongoing Israeli military offensive in the Gaza Strip, terming it ‚Äúsystematic slaughter‚Äù and ‚Äúbloodshed‚Äù. 

The premier was addressing the plenary meeting for the UN General Debate as the second speaker at the 79th session of the 193-member United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York.

He said humanity was diminished when the ‚Äúendless suffering‚Äù of Palestinians was ignored. It is not enough to condemn ‚Ä¶ we must act now and demand an immediate end to this bloodshed.

He said the world must work for a durable peace for Palestine through a two-state solution. PM Shehbaz demanded that Palestine be immediately admitted as a full UN member.

PM Shehbaz said it was a matter of ‚Äúgreat honour‚Äù for him to address the UNGA for the second time as the prime minister of Pakistan.

On the most active front line in Yemen‚Äôs long civil war, the months-long battle for the city of Marib has become a dragged-out grind with a steady stream of dead and wounded from both sides.‚Å†‚Å†
.‚Å†‚Å†
Houthi rebels have been trying since February to take the city, but have been fended off by heavy air attacks by Saudi Arabia. Yemeni government troops defending Marib say they need more and better weapons to turn the tide.‚Å†‚Å†
.‚Å†‚Å†
Amid another round of peace talks, this time led by Oman, officials and observers believe the final victors in Marib will dictate terms for peace.‚Å†‚Å†
.‚Å†‚Å†
Marib ‚Äì 115km (70 miles) east of the capital Sanaa on the edge of Yemen‚Äôs large desert ‚Äì is a strategic gateway from the central highlands to southern and eastern provinces.‚Å†‚Å†
.‚Å†‚Å†
Its relative stability in past years made it a haven for those fleeing the war‚Äôs other fronts. The area, which had a prewar population of 400,000, now hosts some 2.2 million displaced people, many of them crowded into camps.‚Å†‚Å†

Kids play pools in one of the main streets of Aden.
In the background a heavily damaged building.
In 2015 there was the Battle for Aden, where Houthi forces managed to take the important southern coastal city with one of the main commercial seaports of Yemen. 
The coalition managed to retake the city after 6 months of bloody fights in the streets and pushed the Houthi back to the north. 
Aden is now controlled by STC, a secessionist movement backed by the UAE (for its own commercial interests) with the aim of bringing back national borders as they were before 1990: two different countries, North and South Yemen.
Aden was once a cosmopolitan and buzzing city, now it is a poor city that carries with it the signs of war everywhere.

@sociolegalcorp Human rights lawyers representing hundreds of victims of Yemen‚Äôs civil war are calling on the International Criminal Court to open an investigation into war crimes and crimes against humanity allegedly committed by the Saudi Arabia-led coalition during the devastating conflict.

British lawyer Toby Cadman filed the request Monday, highlighting three separate incidents ‚Äì an August 2018 airstrike that destroyed a school bus and killed dozens; a missile attack in October 2016 that killed at least 110 people; and allegations of torture and murder of civilians being held in prisons in the south of Yemen.

The filing came a day after a missile and drone attack, blamed on the Houthi rebels, on a key military base in Yemen‚Äôs south killed at least 30 troops.

The civil war in Yemen erupted in 2014, when the Iranian-backed Houthis swept across much of the north and seized the capital, Sanaa, forcing the internationally recognized government into exile. The Saudi-led coalition entered the war the following year on the side of the government. All sides are accused of atrocities in the yearslong conflict.

Lawyer Almudena Bernabeu, representing victims of the school bus attack, said that the coalition said it would investigate the deadly strike and bring those responsible to justice.

‚ÄúOf course, they did no such thing,‚Äù Bernabeu said in a statement. ‚ÄúAs the court of last resort, victims and families have no choice but to call on the International Criminal Court to ensure justice is done.‚Äù

A spokesman for the Saudi-led coalition did not respond to phone calls seeking comment.

Yemen is not a member state of the court and nor are key coalition members Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. 

However, in a 212-page written submission, the lawyers argue that the court should exercise jurisdiction because some members of the coalition are ICC member states.

Named after the Honey-badger, the Ratel ICV is a a long-running family of 6x6 armored vehicles which has been developed & produced in South Africa. After using tracked armored vechiles for several years, they realized that wheeled AFV‚Äôs were more mobile, more reliable & more ideally suited for dashing across the sandy, grassy & bushy parts of the country. It also meant the vehicles could drive to their target areas, rather than being delivered by transporters or railway like the tracked vehicles. 

The South Africans have since become something of experts in the field of wheeled armored vehicles, ‚Äúprimarily where land mines are a concern‚Äù. The production of Ratel commenced in 1978 & final deliveries were made during 1987. All models of the Ratel have a 6x6 drive configuration with the long armored steel hull being specially contoured underneath to minimize land mine damage, & if necessary it can also travel with two wheels missing. 

It has a turbocharged diesel engine which produces 282 hp & provided the vehicle with a road speed of 105 km/h on ideal surfaces and up to 30 km/h on uneven terrain at an perational range of 997 km. Tests have also proven that it is also amphibious.

Ratel was designed for speed & mobility, thus it had to sacrifice its armor. It has an effective thickness of 20 mm over the frontal arc. The upper hull sides are 8 mm, lower hull 10 mm, rear hull 10 mm & floor hull 8 mm. It‚Äôs mine resistance is derived from the hull`s height above the ground, which is due to its large oversized wheels. The original production version was the Ratel 20 which featured a 20mm cannon. The Ratel 60 had a 60mm mortar, the similar Ratel 80 made use of an 81mm mortar. The Ratel 90 included a 90mm cannon as well as interior room for up to 6 troops. There were also other variants such as Command vechiles, ATGM & logistics carrier etc.

On the most active front line in Yemen‚Äôs long civil war, the months-long battle for the city of Marib has become a dragged-out grind with a steady stream of dead and wounded from both sides.‚Å†‚Å†
.‚Å†‚Å†
Houthi rebels have been trying since February to take the city, but have been fended off by heavy air attacks by Saudi Arabia. Yemeni government troops defending Marib say they need more and better weapons to turn the tide.‚Å†‚Å†
.‚Å†‚Å†
Amid another round of peace talks, this time led by Oman, officials and observers believe the final victors in Marib will dictate terms for peace.‚Å†‚Å†
.‚Å†‚Å†
Marib ‚Äì 115km (70 miles) east of the capital Sanaa on the edge of Yemen‚Äôs large desert ‚Äì is a strategic gateway from the central highlands to southern and eastern provinces.‚Å†‚Å†
.‚Å†‚Å†
Its relative stability in past years made it a haven for those fleeing the war‚Äôs other fronts. The area, which had a prewar population of 400,000, now hosts some 2.2 million displaced people, many of them crowded into camps.‚Å†‚Å†
.‚Å†‚Å†

I attended a talk on "Historical Origins of the #Palestine War" this evening at the India International Center, presented by Prof. Madavan Palat, former Chairman of the Centre for Historical Studies at Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, editor of Selected Words of Jawaharlal Nehru, and trustee of the Jawaharlal Nehru Memorial Fund. I must say this was the best lecture about the historical perspective of the crisis I have come across in recent years.

In an extensive one-hour lecture, Prof. Palat, in the presence of former National Security Advisor Shiv Shankar Menon and Mr. C. Aday Bhaskar, explained the reasons behind the brutality of Israel against the Gazans as well as the people of Lebanon. He also stated that, in reality, it's the Arabs who should have been involved in this crisis more than Iran, but the monarchs and kings there are not accountable to their public.

When I asked why the Arabs are not as involved as Iran, not even 20 percent of the same, he said that it is due to the fear of revolution. He explained that they know public anger against Israel on the Arab streets can anytime turn toward Arab rulers, and they won't be able to save themselves from the ire.

I must say people like Mr Palat keep on reviving our diminishing hope in humanity through their ways of speaking out against the brutality of the state and society. #IsraelPalestineConflict #GazaGenocide‚Äå #IsraelLebanonConflict

Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed willingness to resume peace talks with Ukraine, despite previously stating that Ukrainian military actions in Kursk made negotiations impossible. He referenced a peace deal that was initially outlined during earlier discussions in Istanbul, suggesting that it could serve as a foundation for a new agreement. Putin emphasized that Russia has never refused negotiations, but any dialogue should be based on the existing framework from the Istanbul talks rather than new or vague demands.

Putin also suggested that BRICS member nations, specifically China, Brazil, and India, could potentially act as mediators in future negotiations. As the current chair of BRICS, which includes South Africa as well, Russia seeks to involve these emerging economies in the peace process to help facilitate discussions and potentially reach a resolution.
Source: AP, Reuters, AFP

So what
It seems possible that Putin may be willing to negotiate, but it is unlikely that much of his positions will change. In particular, Ukraine has continued to state that they want Russia to withdraw outside of the pre2014 borders, something Russia is highly unlikely to do. In an additional statement today, Putin stated that Russia's primary goal in Ukraine is to control the Donbas region, indicating they are highly unlikely to give it up in any peace negotiation.

Our new article "Theses on Capitalism and the Generalisation of War" has now been published on our website! 

"As war rages around the world, it is the working class who invariably pay the price, without so much as a choice in the matter of their own lives. Against the chorus of bourgeois political actors, and even so-called ‚Äúsocialists‚Äù and ‚Äúanarchists‚Äù, who exhort us to line up behind one camp of imperialist murderers or another, we reject their paradigm altogether, and instead insist on the need for the working class to develop and maintain its political independence with respect to capital and its institutions; to refuse to allow itself to be used as cannon fodder by any of the warring sides and organise itself to achieve their mutual overthrow.

The defence of proletarian internationalism‚Äîthe core communist principle that workers‚Äô interests are the same everywhere and that, contrarily, they have no interest in common with ‚Äútheir‚Äù exploiting class‚Äîand its practical application: revolutionary defeatism, is fundamental today for communists who wish to act to stem the bloody tide of capitalist civilisation."

YEMEN 2018: This photo is from the Northern Houthi-controlled part of Yemen. The boy is carrying sugar beets from his family's farm down to the river where he and his brother wash the beets before they take them to the market and sell them. YEMEN 2018 - I love this picture of these two roadside merchants with all their colorful goods. I met them on my way to a refugee camp in Abs in the northern part of Yemen back in 2018. Seeing the flags in their headgear and how they were just packed with stuff I immediately knew I needed a picture of them. After having taken the picture the rest of the team and I went into the restaurant we were having lunch at and thought nothing more of the guys outside. 
Coming back outside after our lunch I was met by a group of soldiers and the officer in charge asked me in a harsh tone asked what the hell I was doing in their district and why I was taking pictures of people. Luckily my fixer quickly got there and sorted out the situation. But I still love this little colorful and cheerful moment in the middle of the world's worst humanitarian crisis.

Houthi fighter in Yemen can be seen here posing for a picture while armed with an interesting Chinese QBZ-97 rifle that is essentially an export version of the QBZ-95 chambered in 5.56x45mm instead of the 5.8mm ammunition it usually uses. The rifle also has a modified magazine well in order to accept STANAG magazines. However, this rifle could also be a QBZ-97A variant that has a 3 round burst feature and is missing the "front grip" part in front of the trigger guard. It is unknown how this rifle ended up in Yemen although is it is thought that China may have sold some rifles to the Government prior to the civil war, or perhaps these rifles came from Sudan where the rifle is made at the Military Industry Corporation from components shipped from China. Known as Sinan.

Ukraine has urged Mongolia to arrest Russian President Vladimir Putin during his upcoming visit on September 3, in compliance with an International Criminal Court (ICC) warrant issued last year for war crimes related to the deportation of Ukrainian children. The Kremlin, however, expressed confidence that Mongolia, an ICC member since 2000, would not take such action. This visit marks Putin's first trip to an ICC member state since the warrant was issued, and according to ICC rules, Mongolia is obligated to arrest and transfer him to The Hague.

Russia Launches Barrage of Missiles and Drones at Kyiv

Russia unleashed a massive attack on Kyiv early Monday, firing drones, cruise missiles, and ballistic missiles at the Ukrainian capital, as reported by AP.

Multiple explosions were reported across the city, prompting residents to seek shelter. Emergency services responded to incidents in Holosiivskyi and Solomianskyi districts, while one person was injured by debris in Shevchenkivskyi district. 
Ukrainian officials vowed retaliation, with Presidential Office head Andrii Yermak stating, "The enemy will feel it."

Very nice image depicting a Houthi fighter in Yemen armed with a very nice example of a Dragunov SVU rifle that is essentially a bullpup version of the SVD. Yemen received a batch of these rifles from Russia prior to the ousting of the Saleh government in February 2012. Additionally, a fighter next to him can also be seen armed with an AK-104 which is essentially a shortened version of the AK-103. The AK-104 is actually rather common in Yemen as Russia delivered quite a few of them to different units of the Yemeni army prior to the outbreak of the civil war.

Yemeni Houthi fighters can be seen here armed with either an American M47 Dragon ATGM supplied to the Saudi‚Äôs or an Iranian reverse engineered copy of the American M47 known as the ‚ÄúSaeghe‚Äù. The United States military officially resigned this weapon in 2001 and destroyed its remaining stocks in September 2009, but the Saudis do still operate this platform, albeit in small quantities. In my opinion it is much more likely for these to be Iranian copies due to the large amounts of munitions that the IRGC supplies to the houthi movement. The Saeghe 1 was first shown by the Iranians in 2001 and is thought to have entered serial production in 2002. Iran later introduced the Saeghe 2, a more advanced variant with a tandem warhead to defeat explosive reactive armor,and the Saeghe 4, with a thermobaric warhead. Despite being essentially obsolete, Saegheh anti tank guided missiles have been exported to Syria, Hezbollah, and Shia militias in Yemen and Iraq. The Saeghe 1 and Saeghe 2 were in production and service as of 2011, though they were not widely deployed. The Saeghe ATGM is extremely hard to aim and operate and in Iranian service it appears to be limited to IRGC and rapid response forces.

India‚Äôs humanitarian aid to Ukraine has been remarkable since the outbreak of the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine. The act of granting aid shows that New Delhi has much at stake in international humanitarian missions with caution regarding its relations. India has sent tranches of humanitarian aid to Ukraine since the outbreak in February 2022. For instance, in March 2022, India shipped 90 tonnes of humanitarian load, which included pharmaceutical supplies, tents, blankets, solar lamps, and other rescue commodities to Ukraine.
