"Antony Blinken‚Äôs decades of experience in top Democratic foreign policy circles brings with it assets and liabilities. On the plus side, he understands the bureaucratic workings of the State Department and the value of traditional alliances, the lack of which demoralized many career diplomats during the Trump administration.

On the negative side, he also comes to the position saddled with the calamitous foreign policy decisions of the elected officials he advised, most notably Biden‚Äôs leading role in providing Democratic support as chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to authorize the Bush administration‚Äôs illegal war on Iraq.

Although Biden eventually expressed regret for this mistake, as late as this year, Blinken was still deceptively referring to the authorization for use of force against Iraq as a ‚Äúvote for tough diplomacy.‚Äù

More recently, as a senior foreign policy figure in the Obama administration, Blinken shares in the blame for the president‚Äôs incoherent, piecemeal, and unprincipled response to the Arab Spring, which consisted of a combination of questionably unauthorized uses of force against long-time adversaries and a studied indifference to the repression inflicted by brutal allies against their citizens."

writes Josh Ruebner for Politics Today. Read the full article by clicking the link in our bio.

This is the Great Marib Dam. Built in the 8th century BCE, it was one of the truly great architectural marvels of the ancient Mediterranean world. It also signified the power and grandeur of the ancient civilisations that resided in Yemen such as the Sabaeans and Himyarites. Slide along and you will see other images that attest to this nations' historic prosperity and cultural richness. Indeed, Yemen's wealth was unmatched in the Arabian peninsula well into the second millennium. This is made all the more surprising by the fact that today, Yemen is one of the poorest countries in Central Asia and remains in the thrall of a complicated and devastating war. There are no consolations we can offer to the horrors that have occurred there, though we sincerely hope that Yemen - and the international community, who is fully implicated in the disaster - can bring about the peace that Yemenis deserve. With that, perhaps Yemen might one day return to its former glory.

Slide along to see images of the Great Mosque of Sana'a, the Dar al Hajar in Wadi Dhar, and the ancient skyscraper city of Shibam.

üá¨üáß The war in Yemen is dragging on and has led to the worst humanitarian crisis in the world today. This internationalized conflict has also damaged Yemen's cultural heritage including the historic town of Zabid. The former capital of Yemen from the 13th to the 15th century has an exceptional historical value. Firstly because it had a key importance in the history of the Arab and Muslim world, secondly because it contains relics and historic buildings including 86 mosques and houses in the Tihama style and finally because the organization of its urban plan and its military architecture makes it unique. The air strikes of the coalition led by Saudi Arabia on Zabid and the looting of the historical library by the Houthist forces supported by Iran are examples showing the consequences of war, destroying our universal past and memory.

IMT Hyderabad takes immense pride in announcing the research paper titled ‚ÄúReflection of public perception of Russia-Ukraine conflict and Metaverse on the financial outlook of Metaverse coins: Fresh evidence from Reddit Sentiment Analysis‚Äù authored by our distinguished faculty member Prof. (Dr.) Indranil Ghosh (Assistant Professor, IT & Analytics), co-authored by Dr. Esteban Alfaro- Cort√©s, Dr. Mat√≠as G√°mez and Dr. Noelia Garc√≠a-Rubio has secured successful publication in the prestigious journal ‚ÄúInternational Reviews of Financial Analysis‚Äù.

The study investigates the relationship between Metaverse coin prices and social media attitudes about the Russia-Ukraine war and Metaverse potential. Using Wavelet Coherence Analysis, the research uncovers a short-term link between these factors. Furthermore, Reddit sentiment analysis on both topics demonstrates their influence on Metaverse coin prices. Forecasting is done using nonlinear approaches such as UMAP and PSO-tuned XGBR, with XAI interpreting the findings. The study concludes that short-term media discussion and Reddit sentiment can effectively forecast Metaverse coin price patterns.

To discover in-depth insights and findings about the research paper, please click here: https://bit.ly/46Y7ACm

SA'DAH, YEMEN 2018: Said was nine months old when I photographed him in the triage section of the Al-Jumhuri hospital in Sa'dah back in 2018. He was one of the more than 400,000 children suffering from severe acute malnutrition according to the UN. He measured 68 cm, weighed 5,6 kg, and was furthermore diagnosed with measles while suffering from diarrhea, vomiting, and fever. 
------
Unfortunately, the situation hasn‚Äôt improved in the two-and-a-half years that have passed since I was in the country with journalist @tparabien. According to the @unitednations, more than 400,000 children under the age of five are suffering from severe acute malnutrition to a degree where they are at risk of dying within a short period of time, and more than 16 million people are starving and are also at risk of dying as a result. 
The UN estimates that the country right now is in need of aid and protection for close to 4 billion USD.

Fighting intensifies in the Yemeni province of Marib as the Iran-backed Houthi rebels push closer towards the city. Sources told the Hindu, that at least 90 combatants have been killed in less than 24 hours on Saturday.

The fighting in Yemen which has been raging on since 2014 has left many displaced and killed. The Civil war in Yemen is being fought between an Iranian-backed Houthi armed movement and the internationally recognized Hadi-led Yemeni government-backed mostly by Saudi Arabia. The lives of civilians have become catastrophic.

The city of Marib, located between Sana‚Äôa and Sa‚Äôdah (which are under the control of the Houthis) is the last stronghold for the Yemeni Government in the Northern part of the country. The loss of Marib would be a huge blow to the Saudi-led coalition as the area is also rich in oil but moreover, it would threaten the lives of countless citizens of the city as well as those in refugee camps situated in the province.

The siege of the city was started last month by the Houthis and after a steady advance, a three-prong offensive was launched into the city. The area is under constant threat of ballistic missiles from both sides and a long battle for the city seems to be in the offing. US Secretary of state, Antony Blinken has urged the Houthis to halt their advance as he announced $191 million in aid.

OTR-21 Tochka Tactical ballistic missile of the Soviet Union
-
The OTR-21 is a mobile missile launch system, designed to be deployed along with other land combat units on the battlefield. While the 9K52 Luna-M is large and relatively inaccurate, the OTR-21 is much smaller. The missile itself can be used for precise strikes on enemy tactical targets, such as control posts, bridges, storage facilities, troop concentrations and airfields. The fragmentation warhead can be replaced with a nuclear, biological or chemical warhead. The solid propellant makes the missile easy to maintain and deploy. OTR-21 units are usually managed in a brigade structure. There are 18 launchers in a brigade; each launcher is provided with 2 or 3 missiles. The vehicle is completely amphibious, with a maximum road speed of 60 km/h (37 mph) and 8 km/h (5.0 mph) in water. It is NBC-protected. The system has been in development since 1968. Three variants were developed.
-
Warhead : Chemical, 100 kt nuclear warhead, EMP, or fragmentation filling
-
Engine : Single-stage Solid-fuel rocket
-
Maximum speed : 1.8 km/s (1.1 mi/s; Mach 5.3)
-
Guidance
system : Inertial guidance, Tochka-P added passive radar against radar installations
.
.
.
.

President Joe Biden is ending the United States‚Äô support for Saudi Arabia in the Yemen civil war. Yemen has been in a civil war since 2014, it is a proxy war between Saudi Arabia and Iran. The United Nations describes Yemen as the world‚Äôs biggest humanitarian crisis, with 80% of its people in need and millions on the verge of a large-scale famine. According to UNICEF, with the pandemic spreading, Yemen is facing an ‚Äúemergency within an emergency.‚Äù

Russia Tightens Grip in #EasternUkraine: Novohrodivka Falls, Pokrovsk in Sight üö® #Russia #Ukraine #UkraineWar #UkraineConflict #Novohrodivka #Pokrovsk #Donetsk #Putin #Zelensky #RussiaUkraineWar #RussiaUkraineConflict #UkraineRussiaWarÔ∏èÔ∏è #EuropeNews #WorldNews #TheDailyIntake

Russia has warned Western countries about the serious consequences of allowing Ukraine to launch deep strikes into Russian territory using Western-supplied missiles. The statement from Moscow comes amid ongoing tensions and conflict in the region.

Earlier this month, Ukraine launched an attack on Russia's western Kursk region, marking the most significant foreign strike on Russian soil since World War II. In response, Russian President Vladimir Putin promised that Russia would respond appropriately to the attack.

Russia's Foreign Minister, Sergei Lavrov, who has held his position for over two decades, accused the West of provoking a broader conflict by even considering Ukraine's request to relax the restrictions on using foreign weapons. Lavrov described such actions as "playing with fire."

He also emphasized the potential global consequences of such a move, warning that if World War III were to occur, it would not be confined to Europe. Lavrov cautioned that Western leaders who control nuclear weapons should recognize the dangers of escalating tensions.

Since its invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Russia has repeatedly warned of the risks of a broader war involving nuclear powers. However, President Putin has maintained that Russia does not desire a direct conflict with NATO, the U.S.-led military alliance.

Lavrov's comments come as Russia reviews its nuclear policy. According to Russia's 2020 nuclear doctrine, the use of nuclear weapons would be considered only if the nation faced an existential threat, whether from nuclear, mass destruction, or conventional weapons.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has cautioned that allowing Ukraine to launch deeper strikes into Russian territories is akin to "playing with fire" üî•. Lavrov‚Äôs statement, invoking the threat of nuclear retaliation, underscores the gravity of the situation.

With Ukraine urging for more aggressive measures, the possibility of deeper strikes inside Russia has ignited fears of a broader conflict. Lavrov warned that World War III, if it were to occur, wouldn‚Äôt be limited to Europe but would have catastrophic global consequences. üåê

Student Clayton Hawes describes his experience in the IWP-Oxford Study Abroad this summer:

"This summer term during the IWP-Oxford Study Abroad, I researched with my tutor, Dr. Mark Almond, looking at Russian military lessons learned from the Russo-Japanese War, from its military rearmament through the First World War.

"The research question was, 'If Russia was prepared for war in 1914, why did things go so wrong by 1917?'

"I looked at what the Russians did and what shortfalls were present and examined what trends we see today in the Russia-Ukraine conflict. My assessment was that similar shortcomings are still drawn out from then to what we see of Russian military shortcomings in Ukraine.

"My study experience at Oxford and New College was filled with academic enrichment and personal fulfillment."

Yemen is going through one of the worst man made humanitarian crises as a result of the ongoing civil war. Though Yemen was always besieged with internal conflicts since its unification in 1990, the severity of fighting and destruction is the current phase of civil war since 2015 is unimaginable.

Most of Yemen's 3,500 medical facilities have been damaged or destroyed in air strikes, and only half are thought to be fully functioning. As of early this year, it has added another layer to the war: the failing healthcare infrastructure and the rise of COVID-19. 

Much of the current conflict can only be understood as a result of the events of the latter half of the 20th century. A brief look at the history that has shaped today‚Äôs wars in Yemen is given in  a series of six short explanatory articles.

The civil war in Yemen has taken a toll on the healthcare infrastructure of the country. Most of Yemen's 3,500 medical facilities have been damaged or destroyed in air strikes, and only half are thought to be fully functioning.

In June 2015 itself, aid agencies warned of the humanitarian risks brought by the US and UK-backed Saudi blockades.

According to UNICEF reports, over 3.3 million children and pregnant or lactating women suffer from acute malnutrition. 

In 2017, the World Food Programme estimated that an additional 3.2 million people would be pushed into hunger. If left untreated, 150,000 malnourished children could die within the coming months. 

Save the Children, the international charity and aid agency, estimated that 85,000 children under the age of five have starved to death in between 2015 to 2018. 

A solution to the war must be found soon, before the pandemic eviscerates more of the healthcare infrastructure.

To read more check the link in bio.

They argued that the government could have done more to crack down on these rackets.

A Catholic Reverend father has been ousted by Police authorities for lying to donors after he raised at least $650,000 for overseas medical clinics he claimed to operate, but in reality used the donations to fuel an extravagant lifestyle that included ‚Äòheavenly‚Äô meals, trips to the Hamptons and plastic surgery.

Pawel Bielecki, known as ‚ÄúFather Paul,‚Äù claimed he ran medical clinics in war-torn Lebanon, meanwhile he was 5,600 miles away in Manhattan, New York..

‚ÄúBielecki exploited his position as a friar to gain the trust of victims across the country and steal hundreds of thousands of dollars from them,‚Äù said Damian Williams, US Attorney for the Southern District of New York, which collared the clergyman on Aug. 17 on charges of wire and mail fraud.
 
For eight years, the priest allegedly preyed on the compassionate members of his flock, soliciting donations on local radio shows and crowdfunding websites for non-existent Lebanese hospitals and ambulances, authorities said.

The cleric allegedly exploited the horrific August 4, 2020 chemical explosion in Beirut, which killed 218 people to fill his wallet, claiming he was hurt in the attack.

But prosecutors said he wasn‚Äôt even there and ‚Äúmade several purchases at coffee shops, restaurants and other businesses‚Äù in Manhattan on the day of the disaster.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Ukraine on August 23, 2024, marked the first-ever visit by an Indian Prime Minister to the country since the establishment of diplomatic relations. Arriving in Kyiv by 'Rail Force One' from Poland, PM Modi received a ceremonial welcome at the Kyiv Central Railway Station. Despite the ongoing conflict with Russia, the visit highlighted India's commitment to peace and humanitarian aid.

During his visit, PM Modi paid tribute to Gandhiji at the ‚ÄòOasis of Peace‚Äô park, emphasizing the relevance of Gandhiji's message of peace in today‚Äôs global challenges. He also visited the Martyrologist exposition at the National Museum of History of Ukraine, where he was deeply moved by the memorial dedicated to children who lost their lives in the conflict.

PM Modi held fruitful discussions with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at Maryinskyi Palace, where they reviewed bilateral ties and signed agreements in agriculture, medical products, and cultural cooperation. PM Modi reiterated India's stance for peace and offered to mediate in the Russia-Ukraine conflict without taking sides.

As a gesture of humanitarian support, PM Modi handed over four BHISHM Cubes, containing medicines and medical equipment, to President Zelenskyy. Additionally, PM Modi interacted with Ukrainian students learning Hindi, commending their efforts to promote Indian culture in Ukraine.

PM Modi's visit underscored India's growing role in global diplomacy, with his ability to engage both Russia and Ukraine, demonstrating India's commitment to peace and humanitarian assistance amidst the ongoing conflict.

The UAE successfully mediated a seventh prisoner exchange between Russia and Ukraine in 2024, swapping 115 inmates on each side, increasing the total to almost 1,700 this year. The UAE Ministry of Foreign Affairs congratulated both countries for their collaboration, emphasizing the UAE's position as a trustworthy mediator and dedication to diplomatic solutions. The exchanges highlight the UAE's efforts to mitigate the humanitarian consequences of the crisis while also strengthening its connections with Russia and Ukraine.

In a historic visit that marks a significant moment in global diplomacy, Prime Minister Narendra Modi arrived in Kyiv, becoming the first Indian Prime Minister to visit Ukraine since its independence. This visit comes at a crucial time as Ukraine faces ongoing conflict with Russia, and the world looks on in concern.
During his visit, PM Modi engaged in one-on-one and delegation-level talks with President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, focusing on finding a peaceful and negotiated resolution to the conflict that has not only devastated Ukraine but also impacted global stability. Both leaders emphasized the importance of dialogue and diplomacy in resolving such critical issues.
President Zelenskyy, expressing his gratitude, described the meeting as "historical," underscoring that it was about the nations and their people rather than individual leaders. The discussions highlighted the shared values of democracy, sovereignty, and the right to peaceful coexistence.
PM Modi's visit is a testament to India's commitment to global peace and its willingness to play a constructive role in resolving international conflicts. This visit also reflects India's balanced foreign policy, seeking to foster peaceful solutions through dialogue while maintaining strong bilateral ties.
As the world watches, the outcomes of this meeting may have far-reaching implications for the ongoing conflict and the broader international community's approach to peace and security.

As reported by local media on Sunday, a coal mine explosion in northeastern Iran claimed the lives of at least 51 people, Anadolu reports.

According to the state news agency IRNA, the explosion was brought on by a sudden leak of carbon monoxide and methane on Saturday night in two blocks of the Tabas mine in the Khorasan region.

Approximately seventy people were at the mine when the explosion occurred, according to the local authorities.

Iranian authorities claimed that underground conditions made it difficult to conduct a quick rescue effort.

An investigation into the incident has been ordered by Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian.

One of my followers sent these incarceration cards from their great aunt‚Äôs internment at Buchenwald (the other photo is an example of a card).I am deeply honoured that this person wanted to share these with me, and they are shared with their permission. 

My gut reaction to these cards was sobbing. They weren‚Äôt only Jews held at Buchenwald. Australian and allied POWS, the disabled and infirm, gays, and Romani‚Äôs were there. 2 priests were crucified upside down there. Large scale human experimentation took place in Buchenwald. Everyone held in Buchenwald had these cards. 

Now if I cried understanding the meaning of these cards and those triangles as a Jew, imagine the trauma of the descendants of Buchenwald prisoners seeing the scum of the earth walking Australian streets week after week, or targeting people they‚Äôve never met before in their lives with the murder triangles because free Palestine. I don‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs ignorance, I believe it‚Äôs a level of malicious evil that has to be stopped. 

Never stop fighting.

Anadolu Agency says that in only four days, Lebanon has seen three horrific and unprecedented attacks that have left 2,997 people injured and at least 49 dead.

Hezbollah and the Lebanese government both accuse Israel of being behind the assaults, despite Tel Aviv's silence on the subject. Hassan Nasrallah, the Secretary-General of Hezbollah, has promised revenge, calling Israel's actions "hell."

Israeli forces raided Al Jazeera's office in Ramallah, ordering a 45-day closure.

Heavily armed and masked Israeli soldiers handed the closure order to the network's West Bank bureau chief without providing a reason.

The raid follows a previous ban in May that barred Al Jazeera from operating inside Israel, citing national security concerns.

Al Jazeera condemned the closure, calling it a violation of human rights and an effort to suppress press freedom.

The Gaza Government Media Office described the raid as a scandal and a blatant violation of press freedom.

Al Jazeera has consistently faced restrictions and attacks on its journalists, including the killing of reporter Ismail Al-Ghoul in Gaza.

According to an Israeli media outlet on Saturday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has chosen to extend a military operation on the northern front with Lebanon, according to the Anadolu news agency.

Without naming the participants in the meeting, Channel 13 stated that Netanyahu made the remarks on Thursday during a strategic dialogue session to address the escalation on the northern front.

"A broad and strong operation on the northern front is imminent for Israel," the speaker declared.

A senior source from Netanyahu's administration, who wished to remain anonymous, was quoted by the station as saying that "no date has been set" for the escalation but that "it is expected in the near future."

Ukraine has launched one of its largest drone attacks on Moscow, as it presses on with a major incursion into Russia‚Äôs Kursk region, Russian authorities said.

Russia‚Äôs Ministry of Defence said on Wednesday that air defence forces shot down 11 drones over Moscow and its surrounding region, with some reportedly downed over the city of Podolsk some 38km (24 miles) south of the Kremlin.

‚ÄúThis is one of the largest ever attempts to attack Moscow with drones,‚Äù Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin said on the Telegram messaging app. No damage or casualties were reported, he said in an earlier post.

Drone attacks on Moscow are rare. Ukraine‚Äôs latest attempt to target the Russian capital appeared to be larger than a previous attack in May 2023, when at least eight drones were struck down.

Wednesday‚Äôs barrage was part of a broader attack on Russia, with the Defence Ministry saying its air defence units destroyed 45 Ukrainian drones in total overnight.

In addition to the 11 drones destroyed over the Moscow region, 23 drones were downed in the border region of Bryansk, six in the border region of Belgorod, three in the Kaluga region, which borders the Moscow region to its northeast, and two in the embattled Kursk region, the ministry said.

Russian Su-34 Bomber Destroys Ukrainian Armor with Glide Bombs in Kursk Region

In a significant escalation, a Russian Su-34 frontline bomber conducted a nighttime strike on massed Ukrainian troops and armored vehicles in the Kursk Region. The Russian Defense Ministry announced that the attack utilized upgraded aerial bombs with a unified glide/adjustment module to target fortified enemy positions, reports TASS news agency. 

The operation, which occurred in the borderline area of the Kursk Region, successfully destroyed the intended targets, according to reconnaissance data. Following the strike, the bomber crew returned safely to their airfield.

This comes after a massive Ukrainian attack on the Kursk Region on August 6, heightening tensions in the area.

US Targets Over 400 Entities in New Sanctions Against Russia

The US imposed sanctions on over 400 entities and individuals for aiding Russia‚Äôs war in Ukraine. This includes Chinese firms suspected of helping Russia evade Western sanctions and build its military. The new measures target companies involved in shipping machinery and microelectronics to Russia, as well as networks involved in procuring military supplies. The sanctions also add 123 entities to the US export control list. Ukrainian President Zelenskiy welcomed the sanctions, emphasizing their importance in weakening Russia‚Äôs war efforts.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has visited the border areas in the Sumy region from which his forces staged a major offensive into Russia‚Äôs Kursk region this month.

The president said on Thursday that he had met Oleksandr Syrskii, commander-in-chief of the army, receiving reports on the ‚Äúoperational situation across all active combat zones‚Äù, in a video posted on social media platform X.

The Ukrainian army‚Äôs surprise incursion into Kursk on August 6 saw it take control of dozens of settlements, forcing tens of thousands of civilians to flee and taking hundreds of prisoners captive.

Zelenskyy said Ukraine had ‚Äúreplenished the exchange fund‚Äù, a reference to the capture of Russian soldiers who could be exchanged for Ukrainian prisoners of war held by Moscow.

Ukrainian officials have said the goals of the offensive included creating a ‚Äúbuffer zone‚Äù on Russian territory, seeking an end to the war on ‚Äúfair‚Äù terms and stretching Russian forces.

In his statement on Thursday, the president said there had been a decrease in shelling and civilian casualties in Sumy since the Kursk operation.

As the US and three European nations implemented sanctions against the nation's aviation industry on Saturday, Iran's foreign minister stated that Tehran was open to using diplomacy to resolve problems but not "threats and pressure," according to state media, Reuters reports.

Abbas Araqchi made his remarks one day after the senior diplomat of the European Union stated that the union is thinking of imposing additional sanctions on Iran's aviation industry in response to rumors that Tehran had given Russia ballistic missiles to use in its conflict with Ukraine.

"Iran remains strong on its own course, but we've always been willing to hold discussions to settle disagreements. However, communication needs to be founded on respect for one another rather than coercion and threats, Araqchi stated, as reported by the official news agency IRNA.

Russia Claims Western Arms Used in Kursk Bridge Attack

A Russian court sentenced US-Russian citizen Ksenia Karelina to 12 years in prison on charges of "treason" after she allegedly donated around $50 to a pro-Ukraine charity. Karelina, a 32-year-old ballerina who had been living in Los Angeles, was arrested while visiting family in Yekaterinburg in January. The Russian FSB claimed that the funds she collected were used to purchase supplies and equipment for the Ukrainian armed forces. Karelina reportedly pleaded guilty to the charges last week, according to Russian state media.

This sentencing occurs amid heightened tensions between Russia and the West, particularly following Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Just two weeks prior, Russia released 16 prisoners with US and other Western citizenships in a major prisoner swap, the largest since the Cold War. The case of Karelina, along with others involving Western citizens, highlights ongoing concerns that Russia is imprisoning foreigners on questionable charges to use them as leverage in diplomatic negotiations.
Source: AFP, Reuters

So what
I guess following the large prisoner exchange that occurred a few weeks ago Russia is in need of some new prisoners for bargaining. Though this charge seems quite straightforward when compared to previous political prisoners, it is similar to what would happen to people who are caught raising money for terror groups in the West. Of note around this is some reporting about Russia initiating talks to exchange prisoners for the first time in the conflict, following the capture of some FSB units during Ukraine‚Äôs attack on Kursk. It could be possible Russia plans to use Karelina to pressure Ukraine into a trade for these forces.

The United Nations has condemned Israel following an airstrike on a school in Gaza, which resulted in the deaths of 18 people, including six U.N. workers. The school, located in the Nuseirat refugee camp, was sheltering over 12,000 displaced Palestinians. U.N. Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres called the strike a violation of international humanitarian law and demanded an immediate halt to the violence in Gaza.

The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) defended the strike, claiming it was a targeted operation against Hamas members using the school as a command center. However, no evidence was provided to support this claim, and the U.N. Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) reported the attack as the deadliest single incident involving its staff.

The governor of Russia‚Äôs Belgorod region on Ukraine‚Äôs northern border has declared a regional state of emergency blaming relentless bombardment by Ukraine.

‚ÄúThe situation in the Belgorod region continues to be extremely difficult and tense,‚Äù Vyacheslav Gladkov said in a video posted on the Telegram messaging app.

Daily shelling by Ukraine‚Äôs armed forces had destroyed houses, and had killed and injured civilians, he added.

‚ÄúTherefore, we are making a decision, starting today, to declare a regional emergency situation throughout the Belgorod region ‚Ä¶ with a subsequent appeal to the government to declare a federal emergency situation.‚Äù

Gladkov‚Äôs announcement comes as Russia battles to push back Ukrainian forces in neighbouring Kursk after thousands of soldiers launched a surprise assault across the border in the early hours of August 6.

I servizi di sicurezza russi (Fsb) hanno aperto un'inchiesta contro i due giornalisti della Rai che hanno realizzato un reportage dalla regione al confine di Kursk, tetro di un'offensiva delle truppe ucraine. L'accusa √® di aver attraversato "illegalmente" il confine, entrando nella Federazione russa dall'Ucraina. Lo ha riferito il servizio stampa dell'Fsb come riportano le agenzie russe.

L'Fsb "ha aperto un'indagine penale" contro la giornalista Stefania Battistini e l'operatore Simone Traini per "attraversamento illegale della frontiera", hanno riferito i Servizi in un comunicato. L'ambasciatrice italiana in Russia, Cecilia Piccioni, √® stata convocata a Mosca dal ministero degli Esteri in relazione al caso.l'Fsb ha anche fatto sapere che sta effettuando "una valutazione giuridica dei materiali distribuiti dai media che indicano la presenza sul territorio del posto di controllo russo di Sudzha del corrispondente Nick Paton Walsh". "Sulla base dei cui risultati verr√† presa una decisione procedurale", si legge nel comunicato rilanciato dalle agenzie russe.

Come i due inviati della Rai, anche Nick Paton Walsh della Cnn ha firmato un reportage dalla citt√† di Sudzha, di cui le truppe ucraine hanno rivendicato il controllo nell'ambito della loro offensiva in corso nella regione di Kursk da oltre 10 giorni.

Russia Launches Operation; Basically Grounded But With Tanks
*
Russia has imposed a "counter-terrorism operation" in three regions to halt a Ukrainian incursion. Now, authorities in Kursk, Belgorod, and Bryansk can restrict movement and tap phones.

This after Ukrainian troops advanced 10km into Russia, the deepest since the invasion in February 2022.

Russia's National Counter-Terrorism Committee says it's to ensure public safety. Powers include home entry, traffic control, and electronic monitoring.

76,000 have been evacuated from Kursk. Up to 1,000 Ukrainian troops have reportedly seized multiple villages and threaten Sudzha town.

A video shows armed Ukrainians at Sudzha's Gazprom facility, confirmed by BBC Verify. Another video shows a damaged Russian convoy near Oktyabrskoe.

Russia sent reinforcements, including tanks and rocket systems. Moscow claims to be repelling the invasion, but these claims are unverified.

As fighting nears Kursk nuclear plant, the UN urges "maximum restraint" to avoid a nuclear accident.
*

Hollow Peace Propositions

Amid the never ending conflict between Ukraine and Russia, discussions about a potential peace settlement have gained a facade of momentum. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky‚Äôs recent suggestion of holding a referendum to let the Ukrainian people decide on territorial concessions is nothing more than a distraction. Zelensky‚Äôs statement, made during an interview with the French newspaper Le Monde, appears to be a desperate move to placate a war-weary populace.

The feasibility of such a referendum is laughable. Furthermore, the Ukrainian Constitution does not allow for a plebiscite on territorial changes, making the suggestion a political ruse. Despite these obvious hurdles, Zelensky‚Äôs simulated optimism about the prospects of peace, claiming his administration is committed to preparing a viable peace settlement by the end of the year is a ruse.

Russian Dissidents Refuse to Sign Putin's "Sorry We Got Caught" Petition
*
In a plot twist worthy of a spy novel, two Russian dissidents, Vladimir Kara-Murza and Ilya Yashin, were released in a prisoner swap but refused to sign a mercy petition to Putin. During a Germany press conference, they vowed to return home, stressing their opposition to Putin's war in Ukraine. The swap also freed US journalist Evan Gerschkovich and ex-Marine Paul Whelan, while convict assassin Vadim Krasikov got a get-out-of-jail-free card. The dissidents pledged to fight for a free Russia and criticized the ethics of the swap. Kara-Murza, who was held in solitary for over 10 months, likened his release to a surreal movie. Yashin, still longing to return to Russia, acknowledged that his presence complicates further negotiations. Sasha Skochilenko echoed the surreal experience, ecstatic to reunite with family. They paid tribute to the late critic Alexei Navalny, asserting Putin's direct role in his death, and insisted that Russia deserves better than a "corrupt KGB dictator."

The first batch of long-awaited F-16 jets have arrived in Ukraine, Lithuania‚Äôs foreign minister and a United States official have said, an effort Kyiv has said will help rebuild its depleted air force.

Ukraine has been eager to acquire F-16s, built by Lockheed Martin, because of their destructive power and global availability.  The fighter jet is equipped with a 20mm cannon and can carry bombs, rockets and missiles.

‚ÄúF-16s in Ukraine. Another impossible thing turned out to be totally possible,‚Äù Lithuanian Foreign Minister Gabrielius Landsbergis wrote on X on Wednesday.

A US official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that the delivery had been completed. The Ukrainian government has not confirmed receipt of the jets.

Ukraine has been pushing its Western allies for F-16s for months, saying they were critical in fighting back against the onslaught of missiles Russia has fired against it. The West has moved haltingly towards providing the jets, after previous concerns that arming Ukraine with advanced weaponry would further escalate the war with Russia.

The US has also been training Ukrainian pilots on how to fly the jets and has already graduated the first group of pilots on its operation.

The Israel-Palestine conflict traces back to the late 19th and early 20th centuries, when Jewish and Arab nationalistic aspirations clashed over the same land. After World War II, the creation of Israel in 1948 sparked intense conflict, leading to wars in 1948, 1967, and beyond. Israel established control over key territories such as the West Bank, Gaza Strip, and East Jerusalem after the Six-Day War in 1967. Palestinians demand statehood, sovereignty over the occupied territories, and the right to return for refugees displaced by the conflict.

Presently, peace efforts remain stagnant, with Israel expanding settlements in the West Bank and Palestinian factions divided between the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank and Hamas in Gaza. Violent clashes continue, fueled by deep-seated grievances.

The future remains uncertain. While some push for a two-state solution, others argue for a binational state or separate paths, but political and ideological divides make any resolution elusive.

An Israeli airstrike on a designated humanitarian zone in the southern Gaza Strip killed at least 40 people and injured dozens more, according to Gaza's civil defence authorities. The strike targeted the Mawasi area in Khan Younis, which had been identified by Israel as a humanitarian zone. Local civil defence official Mohammed al-Mughair confirmed the death toll, and both the Hamas-linked Shehab news agency and Fatah-linked Wafa news agency corroborated the reports of 40 fatalities. The impact of the strike caused extensive damage, with over 20 tents catching fire and craters up to nine meters deep left in the area.

In response, the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) stated that the target was a Hamas command centre, accusing Hamas of using human shields within the civilian and humanitarian infrastructure. Hamas denied the presence of its fighters in the area, calling the claims a "blatant lie." The IDF further alleged that Palestinian militant groups have consistently exploited humanitarian zones for terrorist activities against Israel. The incident adds to the escalating conflict, deepening the humanitarian crisis in the region.
Source: AFP, AP, Reuters, dpa

So what
It will be interesting to see what comes of this strike. Numerous commentators online mentioned how abnormal this strike was even for Israel and speculated that the targets must have been important. However, it will likely come at the cost of significant public backlash; even if they can show clear signs that they hit military targets, the general public will likely criticize the strike. Yet it seems like Israel no longer cares about the opinion of the general international community so long as they maintain US support.

In an apparent attempt to increase the production and sale of minerals, the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Jordan have signed a Memorandum of Understanding to construct a multibillion-dollar freight railway that will run from the Dead Sea to the Red Sea.

The country's phosphate and potash mines in Al-Shidiya and Ghor Al-Safi near the Dead Sea will be connected to the port at Aqaba on the Red Sea through a Memorandum of Understanding that Jordanian officials and enterprises signed, according to media sources. Etihad Rail is the national rail operator of the United Arab Emirates.

Construction on the 360-kilometer freight railway, estimated to be worth $2.3 billion, will start in 2026 and include the construction of terminals at Aqaba, Ghor Al Safi, and Shidiya for the loading and unloading of freight.

Israel continues to massacre Palestinians in Gaza using American bombs supplied by Washington, intensifying accusations of genocide. The Israeli military has deployed powerful US-made munitions to strike a so-called ‚Äúhumanitarian safe zone‚Äù in southern Gaza, burying entire families, according to a Geneva-based human rights group.

Early Tuesday, Israeli airstrikes on a refugee tent camp in Khan Younis, located in the al-Mawasi area, resulted in at least 40 Palestinians killed and dozens more injured. This zone had been designated by Israel as a ‚Äúhumanitarian zone‚Äù for displaced civilians seeking refuge from the ongoing violence. Gaza‚Äôs civil defense service reported that the Israeli bombs created craters as deep as nine meters, devastating the camp.

The Euro-Mediterranean Human Rights Monitor confirmed that Israeli warplanes dropped three US-made MK-84 bombs, each weighing 900 kg, on the camp while civilians were sleeping. These bombs were among the more than 14,000 transferred from the US to Israel in 2023 and 2024, according to media reports.

The targeting of civilians coerced into relocating to designated "safe zones" and then bombed during the night highlights America‚Äôs direct complicity in what many are calling the Palestinian genocide.

"The bombs caused craters as deep as several meters, burying about 20 tents with families inside," the rights group said. "Many tents, with entire families inside, were buried under the sand."

Euro-Med condemned the global silence, stating that it emboldens Israel to continue its atrocities.

The group further emphasized the role of the US, which provides Israel with the weapons used to kill civilians, labeling America a partner in these crimes.

Following his passing in July, Dr. Ismail Haniyeh, the late leader of Hamas, was the subject of proceedings that the International Criminal Court (ICC) announced on Friday, according to Reuters.

A request for arrest warrants against Israeli and Hamas leaders issued earlier this year is presently being considered by the ICC.

The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, Karim Khan, requested arrest warrants for Hamas leaders in May. He claimed that there were good reasons to believe Yahya Sinwar, Dr. Ismail Haniyeh, and military chief Mohammed Al-Masri were criminally responsible for alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity.

The prosecutor declared in the same announcement that he was also requesting arrest warrants for Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. No updates about those requests have been received.

Minilateralism ,the brand new way to conflict resolution:

Why and how minilateralism ?

Proper implementation of law requires its enforcement and enforcement requires a central superior authority that's not biased nor coerced.Since international law is considered a weak law, as there's no central superior authority nor there's way to strictly prevent a crime or implement a solution for any conflict, as in today's world the Palestine issue.
the perspective of world is now shifting towards the close cooperative conflict resolution as minilateralism.Which ensures that justice is offered to all parties and conflict resolution is rational.

Minilateralism provides a forum to negotiate on mutual interests and future sustainable goals.For instantiation ,the UAE and Indonesia and five other states started an initiative with the name of "Mangrove Alliance for Climate" at COP'27 (conference of parties) in Egypt.QUAD (Quadrilateral security dialogue) is also an example of minilateralism.Quad is a group where big nations are cooperating in a small group.In international arena minilateralism is considered an effective solution as compared to multilateralism to make fruitful negotiations; especially When it comes to disastrous conflicts like Syrian conflict, Palestine conflict , Russo-Ukrainian war and South China sea.

According to an ISM statement, Aysenur Ezgi Eygi was part of a peaceful rally in Beita against illegal Israeli settlements when the Israeli army opened fire.

A statement by Turkish Interior Minister Ali Yerlikaya on X, an Indian Vistara Airlines flight made an emergency landing on Friday at approximately 4.30 p.m. (1330 GMT) in Erzurum, eastern Turkiye, after a piece of paper with the words "bomb on board" was discovered in a restroom.

234 passengers and 13 staff members had safely evacuated, said Yerlikaya, who also stated that two bomb disposal specialists and one search dog were still combing inside the aircraft.

A Vistara representative confirmed the plane had landed at Erzurum and told Reuters, "Vistara flight UK 27, operating from Mumbai to Frankfurt, has been diverted to Turkiye due to a security concern that was noted by our crew while onboard."

CNN Granted Permission to Appeal Employment Tribunal Decision in Saima Mohsin Case

The Court of Appeal has allowed CNN to proceed with their appeal against an Employment Tribunal's ruling in favor of British-Pakistani journalist Saima Mohsin. Mohsin, who was injured while reporting on the Israel-Palestine conflict in 2014, had her contract terminated by CNN in 2017 after requesting a role adjustment and support during her rehabilitation. Despite undergoing extensive physiotherapy, Mohsin still lives with constant pain, uses a walking stick, and cannot work full-time.

The UAE has led in mediating prisoner exchanges between Russia and Ukraine, showcasing its strong commitment to humanitarian efforts and international diplomacy. The most recent exchange saw 95 prisoners released from each side, marking the sixth successful exchange this year facilitated by the UAE.

Previously, on February 9, 2024, the UAE played a key role in an exchange where 100 prisoners of war were swapped. This marks the third exchange since December 2023, underscoring the UAE‚Äôs ongoing dedication to fostering peace and dialogue.

The UAE's consistent efforts have resulted in the release of hundreds of prisoners, significantly contributing to easing tensions in the region. This humanitarian achievement has garnered international praise and solidified the UAE's reputation as a key mediator in the conflict.

As reported by Anadolu, Palestine's Mission to the United Nations stated on Friday that it will attend the 79th session of the UN General Assembly (GA) for the first time with an official seat.

"Starting the 79th GA session, and for the first time, you can find the State of Palestine seated between Sri Lanka and Sudan," the mission stated on X, adding that the position follows the adoption of a resolution at the General Assembly.

The decision, ES-10/23, provides Palestine greater rights and benefits for membership in the UN, significantly improving its standing within the international organization.

The Gaza Health Ministry has initiated a polio vaccination program in the southern Gaza Strip, aimed primarily at children under the age of ten, according to Anadolu.

The initiative, which began on Saturday in Khan Younis, aims to vaccinate more than 90% of Gaza's children by September 12.

The immunization push, which is being performed in partnership with the World Health Organization (WHO), UNICEF, and the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA), began at Nasser Hospital after the organizations held a joint news conference.

The Turkish government announced on Friday a massive $30 billion incentive package aimed at moving the country to the forefront of high-tech businesses. The program, one of the largest state-backed investments in Turkish history, aims to promote innovation and growth in crucial industries such as information technology, artificial intelligence, biotechnology, and renewable energy.

The package comprises a variety of incentives, including as tax rebates, grants, and low-interest loans, for enterprises and start-ups functioning in certain high-tech fields. The government has also promised to expedite bureaucratic processes, making it easier for enterprises to access these funds and multinational companies to participate in Turkey's expanding tech sector.

After a polio case was reported in Gaza for the first time in 25 years, a vaccination campaign for children began on Saturday. At Al-Nasr Hospital, Palestinian health workers administered polio drops to children. 

The United Nations health agency and other partners will formally launch the polio campaign on Sunday, aiming to vaccinate more than 600,000 children. The Palestinian Ministry of Health has called for a "genuine ceasefire" to ensure the success of the children's vaccination campaign.

The recent conflict between Israel and Hamas began on October 7, following a terrorist attack by Hamas on Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,200 people. 

In response, Israeli actions have led to the deaths of over 40,000 Palestinians in Gaza, according to the health department under Hamas administration.

As per Reuters, more than half of Libya's oil production, or approximately 700,000 barrels per day, was shut down on Thursday as a deadlock between competing political factions over the Central Bank and oil revenue threatened to break a four-year period of relative quiet.

The conflict over control of Libya's Central Bank threatens a new bout of instability in the country, a major oil exporter split between eastern and western factions supported by Turkey and Russia.

Waha Oil Company, a subsidiary of the National Oil Corporation, has reduced output at its oilfields to 150,000 barrels per day (bpd) from 280,000 bpd, and it is projected to decrease further, engineers told Reuters on Thursday.

Two US Marines were physically attacked by a nationalist Turkish youth group on Monday in western Turkiye, according to the US Embassy in Turkiye and the local governor's office. They also indicated that 15 attackers had been apprehended in connection with the event, as reported by Reuters.

Three security and government sources told Reuters that President Abdel Fattah Al-Sisi received an intelligence briefing that triggered worries about food security, which led to the largest wheat tender in Egypt's history, which was over 20 times larger than typical.

Tens of millions of Egyptians rely on wheat, which is imported by Egypt, one of the largest countries in the world, to make subsidized bread. To prevent public discontent, successive governments had kept the price steady for decades. However, in June, Sisi's government increased the price by 300 percent.

It has not yet been disclosed how Sisi contributed to the earlier this month tender, which called for 3.8 million metric tons of wheat but only received 7% of that amount. When contacted for comment, his office did not provide one.

Tens of thousands of Israelis came to the streets in one of the largest nationwide protests since Israel‚Äôs war on Hamas began, calling on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to obtain a ceasefire-for-hostages agreement.

The scope of the strike early Monday remained unclear, but supporters have promised a countrywide response.

Israel is tightening the noose around Palestinians by forcibly transferring them into an increasingly narrow area no more than 10 percent of the Gaza Strip. Even before the war, the Gaza Strip was one of the most densely populated places in the world, with 2.3 million Palestinians ‚Äì two-thirds of them refugees from areas conquered by Zionist forces in 1948 ‚Äì concentrated in 141 square miles. Since October, two percent of Gaza‚Äôs population has been killed, and many more injured or gone missing. But nearly everyone has been displaced, many multiple times.

The Government Media Office in Gaza published a timeline demonstrating how Israeli evacuation orders beginning in November have forced Palestinians from the north of the territory to the south under the threat of death, pushing much of the population to a so-called humanitarian zone along the coast of southern Gaza. Since 16 August, the Israeli army has issued at least five evacuation orders directing Palestinians in central Gaza, primarily in the town of Deir al-Balah, to flee to an ever-shrinking area of the Gaza Strip.

On 25 August, patients, staff and displaced families inside and around the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir Al-Balah packed up what they could and fled.

In the midst of Ukraine's war, drone warfare has taken center stage. A Ukrainian drone operator, wearing a VR headset, controls a drone as they navigate through the battlegrounds near Kharkiv. Soldiers in a fast-moving army truck depend on a small device called "sugar" to alert them of Russian drones.

.
Despite advanced jamming equipment, Russian Lancet drones remain a significant threat. A year ago, this tech was rare in Ukraine. Now, drones are crucial, impacting both military and civilian life.

.
Ukraine's forces counterattack with their own drones, aided by allies pledging a million drones. The result is a transformed battlefield where drones play a vital role.

Egypt delivered its first military aid to Somalia in more than four decades yesterday, according to three diplomatic and Somali government sources, a move likely to deepen strains between the two countries and Ethiopia, Reuters reports.

Egypt and Somalia have drawn closer together this year after Ethiopia signed a preliminary deal with the breakaway region of Somaliland to lease coastal land in exchange for possible recognition of its independence from Somalia.

The Mogadishu government has called the deal an assault on its sovereignty and said it will block it by all means necessary.

Swedish prosecutors said on Wednesday that they intend to charge two individuals with lighting fire to copies of the Qur'an in a series of instances last year that sparked indignation in the Muslim world and stoked worries of Islamist strikes, Reuters reported.

The two men committed "offenses of agitation against an ethnic or national group" four separate times by burning Islam's sacred book outside a mosque and in other public places, according to the Swedish Prosecution Authority.

Sweden's internal security service boosted its terrorism warning level in response to the burnings, while neighboring Denmark, which also saw a surge in Qur'an burnings, tightened its legislation to criminalize the practice.

Watching the atrocities being committed on the land of Palestine and on Palestinians, my hands ended up penning down this piece of poetry, which entirely doesn't represent the pain and struggles of Palestinians but is an attempt to comprise a small part of their tale of oppression in the form of a poem. 
Their pain and struggle are known by the entire world, but we all remain helpless. Let's hope and pray for their lives to get better and for peace to finally embrace their land. üáµüá∏

-

On the land of olives, 
Somewhere in the old city its engraved, 
A nation led by the Prophet will not
surrender, 
The history echoes the torture of offenders.
From Alleys of Gaza to grounds of Jerusalem, 
Engulfs the mist filled with resilient squalls,
Tales of oppression moulds in mosaics of minarets and walls.
Even in the ruins of bustling cities,
The hope in people is not forsaken,
The faith in them remains unshaken.
Children inherit the trauma their mothers bore,
Flows the streams of sorrow till shore.
From the refugee camps to watermelon yards,
Threads weave the story of every soul scarred.
An Ice-cream truck to mortuary,
General newspaper to thousand obituaries. 
Hustling city to a rubble, 
Fashioning dreams to watching them crumble.
Abode of families to cemetery, 
Bombed the barren and residuary.
Missiles fall like rain pouring down, 
The smears of innocent blood cover the town.
Endured everything they stand steadfast,
Their hope for freedom and peace outlast.
May solace embrace their land,
Palestinians with courage withstand.

According to a report from Reuters, emergency workers are trying to determine how many people are still missing after waters burst over a dam in eastern Sudan, causing the deadliest in a series of floods that have ravaged a country already torn apart by 500 days of war.

The collapse of the Arbaat Dam on Sunday killed 30 people and possibly killed scores more, the latest in a string of inundations around the country as this year's rainy season arrives sooner and heavier than in previous years.

War-shattered Sudan is already dealing with one of the world's worst starvation and displacement crises, and the floods have hampered assistance distribution, which has already been interrupted by the army's war with its adversary, the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces.

The explainer discusses the impact of Houthi attacks on global trade through the Red Sea, especially following their involvement in the Israel-Palestine conflict that began on October 7th. The Red Sea is highlighted as a crucial global trade route, with significant geopolitical importance due to its connection to the Suez Canal and various strategic straits. 

The Houthi attacks have disrupted trade, particularly affecting shipping companies and various global industries, leading to increased freight costs and delayed shipments.

 Despite these disruptions, the energy sector remains largely unaffected, and the Houthis have not achieved their goal of enforcing a ceasefire in Gaza. 

The situation underscores the evolving geopolitical dynamics in the region, with major global powers involved and the potential for further escalation.

‚ÄúJUST LET HIM DO WHAT HE WANTS‚Äù

Because that is the most pleasant way for the Russia-Ukraine conflict to end peacefully through negotiations.

Efforts from major countries can partially contain the heat of the conflict.

But it would be better if the negotiation took place voluntarily on both sides.

From the first Swiss summit, to the second Ukrainian peace conference.

Mr. Zelensky can hold the summit many more times. But please be patient, let him try to do everything he can for Ukraine.

Give him a chance so he won't regret it later.

Give him time to realize that for himself. Only the path of negotiation on Russia's terms can bring peace to the two countries.

And only negotiations that take place voluntarily can completely resolve the conflict hidden deep in the hearts of both sides.

So, just let him do what he wants.

On March 6, Russia fired a missile into the Ukrainian port of Odesa that exploded about 400 metres (1,300ft) from where Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was preparing to tour the city with Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis.

‚ÄúAs we were getting into our cars, we heard a large explosion,‚Äù Mitsotakis later told reporters. ‚ÄúWe were all concerned, especially if you consider that we were in an open space with no cover. It was quite savage.‚Äù

Many Western leaders have visited Zelenskyy, but this was the only occasion when there was a plausible threat to their life and safety. Analysts in Athens do not believe it was an accident.

‚ÄúIt was a message to Greece, a message to the Russophilic portion of Greek society,‚Äù said Konstantinos Filis, a professor of international relations who directs the Institute of Global Affairs at the American College of Greece.

That Russophilic population is dropping dramatically.

According to Dianeosis, an Athens-based think tank, about 70 percent of Greeks had a favourable view of Russia before the full-blown war in Ukraine. That fell to 50 percent after the 2022 invasion and to 30 percent last year.

üö® Breaking News: Russia Tightens Internet Grip, Orders Apple to Remove 25 VPN Apps! üö®

In a significant move, Russia's internet and mass media watchdog, Roskomnadzor, has directed Apple to remove 25 VPN apps from its App Store. This directive targets popular VPNs like NordVPN, Proton VPN, Red Shield VPN, and more, frequently used to access content deemed illegal in Russia. üá∑üá∫üîí

This crackdown is part of a broader campaign that has intensified since the Russia-Ukraine conflict began in February 2022. VPNs, vital tools for internet freedom, are now being systematically restricted. Apple confirmed the directive to affected VPN vendors, emphasizing compliance with Russian laws.

Earlier this year, Apple faced a $13.7 million fine from Russia's Federal Antimonopoly Service over market dominance issues. Despite these challenges, Apple's products have played crucial roles in the conflict, with Ukraine's Air Force using iPads for operating modern weapons in older jets.

What do you think about this latest development? Should tech companies comply with such directives? Share your thoughts below! üí¨üëá

Omani actor Talib Al-Balushi, who appears in the recently released Indian film The Goat Life, has disputed social media rumors that he has been barred from visiting Saudi Arabia. The film, directed by Blessy, has stirred controversy for its unflattering representation of a Saudi sponsor (kafeel), as well as its emphasis on labor exploitation.

The Goat Life is based on Benyamin's Malayalam novel Aadujeevitham, which chronicles the true story of Najeeb Muhammad, an Indian migrant forced into slavery as a goatherd in the Saudi Arabian desert.

Russian missile attack hits children‚Äôs hospital in Kyiv

Emergency and rescue personnel along with medics and others clear the rubble of the destroyed building of Ohmatdyt Children's Hospital following a Russian missile attack in the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv on Monday, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Russia launched more than 40 missiles at several cities across Ukraine on July 8, 2024 in an attack that killed at least 20 people and smashed into a children's hospital in Kyiv, officials said.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised Russia as India's trusted partner and "all-weather friend" during his two-day visit to Moscow, expressing gratitude to President Vladimir Putin for strengthening bilateral ties over the past 20 years.

Other carriers that have canceled flights include Hungarian Wizz Air, Malta-based Corendon, Ethiopian carriers, Greek Aegean Airlines, and Greek Universal Airlines.

Turkey and Iraq have agreed to assign high-ranking military generals to a new Coordination Centre in Baghdad. This measure intends to boost bilateral security cooperation, particularly in counterterrorism and border security.

The new Centre, launched following recent high-level meetings between the two countries, would act as a focal point for intelligence sharing, cooperative military operations planning, and coordination on security matters affecting both nations. The move highlights the growing defense relations between Ankara and Baghdad as they face common dangers, including terrorist groups operating in the region.

As reported by Reuters, the United Nations Libya mission expressed worry late yesterday over reports of military mobilizing in Tripoli and threats of force to resolve a crisis over central bank management.

Stephanie Koury, the mission's deputy leader, told the UN Security Council on Monday that Libya's political and military situations had deteriorated significantly in the preceding two months, including a series of armed faction mobilizations.

"The use of military force and armed confrontations in densely populated areas is unacceptable and endangers civilian lives and security," the mission stated in a statement Wednesday.

According to Reuters, a portion of available aid has slipped through the Adre border crossing from Chad into Sudan's hunger-ravaged Darfur area this week, following the Sudanese army's decision to temporarily suspend a delivery prohibition.

The Rapid Support Forces militia, the army's main competitor in Sudan's deadly 16-month civil war, controls the majority of Darfur as well as the Adre crossing, the quickest entry into the region. The army had ordered aid agencies to stop using the corridor in February, claiming that it was used by the RSF to transport weaponry across the border, but last week reversed that order for three months.

Releasing this month, Hope is a Woman's Name is the extraordinary story of Amal, who was at five years old a shepherd in the Negev region of Palestine. By her teens, she ran literacy classes for Bedouin women, sparking a lifelong career in organizing and policy change. She built economic empowerment programs, founded an Arab-Jewish school, and created organizations promoting shared society. 
Amal builds bridges by embracing every part of her identity‚ÄîBedouin, Arab, woman, feminist, Palestinian, and Israeli‚Äîensuring no one is left out.

‚ÄºÔ∏èUn tribunale di Mosca ha ordinato l'arresto in contumacia di Yulia Navalnaya con l'accusa di coinvolgimento in un gruppo estremista. Lo scrive RIA Novosti che cita il ;;servizio stampa del tribunale. Il tribunale "ha scelto una misura preventiva sotto forma di detenzione per un periodo di 2 mesi. Il periodo viene calcolato dal momento dell'estradizione nel territorio della Federazione Russa o dal momento della detenzione nel territorio della Federazione Russa", riferisce il tribunale. La corte ha chiarito che Navalnaya √® stata inserita nella lista internazionale dei ricercati perch√© "si √® nascosta dalle autorit√† investigative".

Three Palestinians have been killed in an Israeli air attack on a house in the Tulkarem refugee camp in the occupied West Bank, the Palestinian Ministry of Health says.

Reporting from Tulkarem, Al Jazeera‚Äôs Nida Ibrahim said on Thursday that the raid was ongoing 12 hours later in the congested area, with sounds of explosives and gunfire heard and drones flying above.

‚ÄúPeople inside the refugee camp say the Israeli army has set fire to some of the homes and that civil defence teams are not being allowed in to put out the fires,‚Äù she said.

The aerial attack on Thursday came as the Qassam Brigades, the military wing of Hamas, said fighters from its Tulkarem Battalion clashed with Israeli soldiers in the camp and detonated explosive devices targeting military vehicles.

‚ÄúOur fighters continue to clash with the occupation forces and we have achieved direct hits among them,‚Äù the Qassam Brigades said.

The Israeli military deployed snipers on roofs and sent in bulldozers to destroy infrastructure.

The Quds News Network posted a video of a fire following the army‚Äôs ground assault on the camp.

The United Nations has urgently called for de-escalation as tensions between Israel and Hezbollah continue to rise.

On 25 August, the conflict intensified with Israel launching airstrikes on Hezbollah targets in Lebanon, while Hezbollah responded with a barrage of rocket attacks.

The UN secretary-general, Antonio Guterres, expressed deep concern over the escalating violence, which endangers both Israeli and Lebanese civilians, and threatens regional stability. The UN has emphasised the need for both sides to cease hostilities and adhere to Resolution 1701, which calls for an end to the conflict.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has concluded his Middle East trip without securing a deal to ease the Gaza blockade. Despite efforts to address the humanitarian crisis, no agreement was reached between Israel and Palestinian officials.

Blinken's trip aimed to strengthen ties with regional partners and address pressing issues, including the Gaza situation. However, the lack of progress on a deal highlights the complexity and challenges in achieving lasting solutions.

The Gaza blockade has led to severe economic and humanitarian conditions, exacerbating tensions in the region. Blinken's efforts will continue, but the immediate outcome falls short of expectations.

The US will likely maintain engagement with regional partners to explore alternative solutions and support initiatives promoting stability and peace in the Middle East.

Further strengthening the relationship between Rabat and Tel Aviv, Morocco has signed a lucrative contract for an estimated $1 billion to acquire Israeli spy satellites.

Morocco last week inked a contract with Israel Aerospace Industries (IAI) for the supply of two Ofek 13s, IAI's new, highly powerful military surveillance satellites, for a five-year period ending in 2029, according to the publication Military Africa.

The $1 billion contract to deliver the new satellites will replace Morocco's present monitoring system, which is based on technology from European corporations Thales and Airbus.

I don't post these here often, as the internal political situation in Israel is too chaotic for most people to understand, let alone people that don't live here, and I get too much hate responses. But I keep going to these protests and documenting them, as the struggle to bring the Israeli hostages back to their family is a moral human obligation that is above all political affairs. It is not a matter of sides or party. It is not a matter of pro- or anti- or whatever. It is a basic demand to let innocent people out of captivity after 10 months. 
In the 4th photo meet Einav Zangauker, mother of 24 years old hostage Matan. Every Saturday she is there. Screaming. Fighting. You can tell she is barely sleeping. Going crazy without knowing anything about her son's medical and mental situation. And tens of thousands  Israelis surround her and the hostages families. Calling for an immediate hostage deal and ceasefire. For 324 agonizing days now.

Hamas's rejection of the latest cease-fire proposal, despite mediation efforts from the U.S., Egypt, and Qatar, highlights the deep political divides complicating peace efforts. Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu‚Äôs new demands, including the exclusion of Hamas from Gaza‚Äôs future governance, are seen as obstacles to reaching a consensus. This impasse reflects the broader challenge of balancing domestic political pressures with international mediation efforts and underscores the difficulty of achieving lasting peace in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

The ongoing violence and the humanitarian crisis in Gaza, exacerbated by recent airstrikes and the failed cease-fire, continue to impact civilians severely. The rejection prolongs suffering and highlights the urgent need for effective humanitarian aid and conflict resolution strategies. The international community's focus on addressing immediate needs and negotiating peace remains critical amid the escalating humanitarian crisis.

As reported by Israeli media, an Israeli negotiation delegation left Cairo on Monday without concluding on the Philadelphi Corridor, which straddles the border between Gaza and Egypt (Anadolu Agency).

The Corridor is a demilitarized buffer zone that stretches 14 kilometers (8.69 miles) along the border between Egypt and the Gaza Strip.

The Yedioth Ahronoth daily said that "no progress has been made in the talks on the Philadelphia Corridor."

When the next round of axis discussions will take place is still unknown.

Citing an Israeli insider acquainted with the negotiations, the publication stated, "We are talking about very critical hours."

A prominent figure in Yemen's Supreme Political Council has stated that Sanaa is prepared to work with Algeria to increase support for Gaza. Following Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune's promise to provide military, medical, and humanitarian aid to the Gaza Strip, Mohammed Ali Al-Houthi made his announcement on X.

Al-Houthi commended Tebboune's "important, ideal, and wonderful statements" in his Sunday response. He voiced optimism for concerted actions to aid Palestine and Gaza, possibly creating new fronts in the "Jerusalem Axis."

Thirty British medical experts have written to Prime Minister Keir Starmer, imploring him to terminate the UK's role in the "unimaginable cruelty" unfolding in Gaza and to suspend military shipments to Israel.

The doctors, nurses, surgeons, and medical professionals described their experiences while volunteering in Gaza, emphasizing that they "are among the only neutral observers who have been permitted to enter the Gaza Strip since October 7." With international journalists being targeted and refused entry to Gaza, our eyewitness testimonies have had to take the place of journalistic or investigative reports."

Russia has suffered multiple diplomatic and judicial blows during the past week over its war on Ukraine, despite President Vladimir Putin‚Äôs high-profile visits to North Korea and Vietnam and Moscow‚Äôs claims that it is founding a ‚ÄúEurasian security architecture that will replace the discredited Euro-Atlantic security arrangements‚Äù.

Putin signed a ‚Äúcomprehensive strategic treaty‚Äù with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on June 19, incorporating what he said was a defensive alliance. South Korea‚Äôs government condemned the agreement. Its national security adviser, Chang Ho-jin, declared that Seoul would reconsider lifting a ban on arms supplies directly to Ukraine. Until now, South Korea has only sold weapons to Ukraine‚Äôs allies.

Chang later added that the type of weapons supplied to Ukraine would depend on Russia‚Äôs cooperation with North Korea. Putin said it would be a ‚Äúgrave mistake‚Äù if South Korea changed its policy of not supplying belligerents.

Russia also suffered judicial embarrassments. The International Criminal Court at The Hague issued arrest warrants on Tuesday for former Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and Chief of Military Staff Valery Gerasimov, saying that they bore responsibility for attacks on Ukrainian electricity infrastructure. The court said, ‚ÄúThere are reasonable grounds to believe that the alleged strikes were directed against civilian objects,‚Äù and that ‚Äúthe expected incidental civilian harm and damage would have been clearly excessive to the anticipated military advantage.‚Äù

According to Anadolu Agency, the Scottish government declared on Monday that it would no longer hold talks with Israeli ambassadors until there was "real progress" towards peace in the Gaza Strip and unhindered access for humanitarian aid to reach the enclave.

External Affairs Secretary Angus Robertson stated in a statement that unless there was genuine progress on the Gaza situation, the Scottish government would not accept any invitation for a second meeting with Israel.

"Until real progress has been made towards peace, unhindered access to humanitarian assistance is provided, and Israel fully cooperates with its international obligations on the investigation of genocide and war crimes, this will remain our position," Robertson stated.

NATO allies selected Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte as NATO‚Äôs next boss, as the war in Ukraine rages on its doorstep and uncertainty hangs over the United States‚Äô future attitude to the transatlantic alliance.

Rutte‚Äôs appointment became a formality after his only rival for the post, Romanian President Klaus Iohannis, announced last week that he had quit the race, having failed to gain traction.

NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg earlier said that the alliance had no plans to deploy forces to Ukraine, despite many of its members supplying Kyiv with weapons since Russia‚Äôs invasion.

‚ÄúNATO has no plans to deploy forces to Ukraine,‚Äù Stoltenberg said during a visit to Finland, adding that the alliance was seeking ‚Äúlong term financial commitment to ensure that we stand by Ukraine for as long as it takes‚Äù.

‚ÄúOver the last months, we have seen some gaps, some delays in the provision of military support to Ukraine,‚Äù Stoltenberg said, adding: ‚Äúwe need to ensure that that doesn‚Äôt happen again.‚Äù

The visit marked Stoltenberg‚Äôs first to Finland since the country joined NATO in April 2023, prompted by Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine, thereby leaving decades of military non-alignment behind.

Stoltenberg‚Äôs visit came as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday joined Western leaders in France to commemorate D-Day.

While there, Zelensky is due to meet US President Joe Biden for talks on how Ukraine can gain background after recent Russian advances.

Asked to comment on the risk of a Russian attack against a Nato member, Stoltenberg replied: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt see an imminent military threat against any NATO ally.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis idea that there‚Äôs a kind of a countdown to the next war is wrong.‚Äù

WHY IS THE RUSSIA-UKRAINE CONFLICT MORE DIFFICULT TO NEGOTIATE THAN THE ISRAEL-HAMAS WAR?

You can imagine it like this.

If Hamas is seen as someone who is "in danger", then Ukraine is like someone who is "wanting to die".

You only need to act once to save someone in "danger" like Hamas. But it is very difficult to save someone who really "wants to die".

Because, even if you save them once, they will find a way to "die" many more times.

In short, there is almost no effective solution to the Russia-Ukraine conflict until the balance of power in this world is changed.

The UK's criminal justice system is at a crisis point as a result of the recent outbreak of far-right-inspired riots in towns and cities throughout England and Northern Ireland, according to Anadolu Agency.

Although the police have been instrumental in quelling the disturbance by deploying more officers and making hundreds of arrests, the criminal justice system as a whole, which includes courts and jails, is terribly unprepared to deal with the growing demand.

Law enforcement officials have been at the forefront of efforts to restore order since the riots broke out on July 30 as a result of a deadly knife assault and a subsequent wave of misinformation. Hundreds of arrests have been made in an effort to stem the violence.

The UAE has once again demonstrated its commitment to diplomacy and conflict resolution, successfully mediating another prisoner exchange between Russia and Ukraine. This latest swap saw the release of 180 captives - 90 from each side.

The UAE's Ministry of Foreign Affairs praised the cooperation of both Russia and Ukraine, stating that this exchange "demonstrates the country's consistent position in calling for diplomacy, dialogue and de-escalation" in the ongoing conflict.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy welcomed the return of the Ukrainian prisoners, pledging to continue efforts to bring home all those still held by Russia. This prisoner swap marks an important step forward in resolving the conflict through diplomatic means, with the UAE playing a crucial role as a neutral mediator.

The International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague has issued arrest warrants for former Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and current military Chief of the General Staff Valery Gerasimov. These charges are related to alleged crimes during Russia's invasion of Ukraine, particularly for their roles in directing missile strikes against Ukraine's electric infrastructure from October 10, 2022, to March 9, 2023. The court believes there are reasonable grounds to hold Shoigu and Gerasimov responsible for these actions, categorizing them as war crimes and crimes against humanity due to the targeting of civilians and civilian objects.

These charges add to the broader context of ICC actions against Russian officials, including President Vladimir Putin, who is already facing an ICC arrest warrant for the alleged forced relocation of Ukrainian children to Russia. Despite these charges, Russia, not being a full signatory to the ICC, typically does not extradite its citizens, raising doubts about whether Shoigu and Gerasimov will ever stand trial. Shoigu, who was recently dismissed from his role and reassigned to Russia's security council, and Gerasimov were among Putin's most senior defence officials, highlighting the high-level nature of these accusations.
Source: Reuters, AP

So what
While no doubt justified it is unlikely this move will do anything more than aggravate the Kremlin and restrict any movement by the two generals (something that was already highly unlikely). Additionally, this puts an end to rumours that Shoigu may defect following his removal as it is highly unlikely he would willing to go to a country that may end up selling him out to the ICC.
