The Israeli military has bombed a warehouse sheltering displaced Palestinians in the az-Zawayda area of central Gaza, killing 15 members of one family, including nine children.

The civil defence spokesman in Gaza, Mahmoud Basal, said on Saturday that 15 people killed in the overnight attack were members of the al-Ejlah family, with three women among the dead. The total death toll from the attack was 16.

Reporting from Deir el-Balah in central Gaza, Al Jazeera‚Äôs Tareq Abu Azzoum said three Israeli missiles hit the warehouse, located a few kilometres south of the Nuseirat refugee camp.

‚ÄúA massive fire broke out, burning everything in the warehouse as children were torn to pieces. Rescue efforts are still continuing to try to recover more bodies,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThere is a great level of frustration and grief. The bodies are now being lined up at Al-Aqsa Hospital‚Äôs morgue as the family gets ready to bury them.‚Äù

The attack killed the family‚Äôs patriarch, Sami, along with his wife, mother and all of his children, according to Abdalhadi al-Ejlah, a cousin of the victims.

As reported to the UN, severe flooding and strong winds have destroyed sections of Yemen, resulting in thousands of people being displaced and at least 61 deaths since late last month. Four fatalities were recorded on Sunday alone in the central province of Marib, where the internally displaced people's (IDPs) tents were pounded by torrential rains.

More than 34,000 families have been impacted by the disastrous weather, which has further exacerbated Yemen's already serious humanitarian catastrophe. Strong winds in Marib, where more than two million internally displaced people have sought safety from the fighting, crushed portions of the Jaw Al-Naseem camp, injuring numerous people.

As reported by the Pentagon, growing tensions in the Middle East were discussed on Friday between Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin, as reported by Anadolu Agency.

Spokesman Maj. Gen. Pat Ryder said in a statement that Austin and Gallant discussed the "growing risk of escalation" from Iran, Hezbollah, the Lebanese group, and other groups throughout the Middle East.

Gallant was advised by Austin that the US "is well-postured throughout the region to defend Israel and protect US personnel and facilities" and that it "continues to monitor attack planning from Iran and its proxies." Ryder concurred.

The United Nations has reported that Israel has denied access to Gaza for about one-third of all aid missions since the beginning of this month, contributing to "a continued cycle of deprivation and distress" for the population in the war-torn Palestinian territory.

According to the latest situation report from the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), 198 people were killed and 430 injured in Israeli attacks between Friday and Monday.

From August 1 to 11, Israeli authorities denied access to northern Gaza for 32 of 85 coordinated humanitarian aid missions. An additional 13 missions were impeded by Israeli authorities, and six were canceled due to logistical and security reasons, according to the OCHA report.

We further condemn the United States for providing Israel with the funding to carry out the attack, and Western states more generally for using their diplomatic muscle to protect Israel from condemnation. Genocide begins with the silence of the world.

‚ÄúWe are alarmed by the extreme, racist dehumanization of Palestinians in Israeli society, which has reached a fever-pitch. In Israel, politicians and pundits in The Times of Israel and The Jerusalem Post have called openly for genocide of Palestinians and right-wing Israelis are adopting Neo-Nazi insignia.

‚ÄúFurthermore, we are disgusted and outraged by Elie Wiesel‚Äôs abuse of our history in these pages to justify the unjustifiable: Israel‚Äôs wholesale effort to destroy Gaza and the murder of more than 2,000 Palestinians, including many hundreds of children. Nothing can justify bombing UN shelters, homes, hospitals and universities. Nothing can justify depriving people of electricity and water.

‚ÄúWe must raise our collective voices and use our collective power to bring about an end to all forms of racism, including the ongoing genocide of Palestinian people. We call for an immediate end to the siege against and blockade of Gaza. We call for the full economic, cultural and academic boycott of Israel. ‚ÄúNever again‚Äù must mean NEVER AGAIN FOR ANYONE!‚Äù
--Hajo Meyer, Holocaust survivor
.
.

Palestinian detainees are enduring severe physical and psychological torture in Israeli facilities, the Al Mezan Center for Human Rights has said, calling for accountability for the abuses.

The prisoners ‚Äúhave been exposed naked to the scorching sun while standing on sharp gravel stones, subjected to verbal abuse, and threatened with rape, death, and bombing, along with threats against their families‚Äù, it said in a statement on Tuesday.

The rights group said that recent testimony and evidence ‚Äúreveal a level of violence that resounds with the atrocities documented in Guantanamo and Abu Ghraib‚Äù, referring to the United States-run detention facility in Cuba and the prison in Iraq where US soldiers abused detainees.

Al Mezan said that the detainees have also been ‚Äúdeprived of food, water, sleep, and access to sanitation for extended periods, all while facing extremely harsh living conditions‚Äù.

The group estimated at least 2,650 Palestinians taken from the Gaza Strip after October 7 remain in Israeli custody, including 12 children and two women.

Among them, approximately 300 are facing trials, while 2,350 are classified as ‚Äúunlawful combatants‚Äù without a defined detention period or specific charges.

China's foreign minister Wang Yi called Iran's acting foreign minister on Sunday and said, according to a statement from China's foreign ministry, that China supports Iran in preserving its "sovereignty, security, and national dignity."

During the call, Wang reiterated Beijing's condemnation of the July 31 death of Ismail Haniyeh, the leader of Hamas, in Tehran, claiming that the attack had infringed upon Iran's sovereignty and jeopardized the stability of the region. Iran and Hamas, a Palestinian organization, have charged Israel with executing the attack that claimed Haniyeh's life.

La Nato ha nominato il premier olandese Mark Rutte come prossimo Segretario generale. Rutte, 57 anni, assumer√† l'incarico di capo della Nato il 1¬∞ottobre, sostituendo il norvegese Jens Stoltenberg, che ha ricoperto la carica per dieci anni. Rutte: "√à un grande onore essere nominato Segretario Generale. L'Alleanza √® e rimarr√† la pietra angolare della nostra sicurezza collettiva".

"Guidare questa organizzazione √® una responsabilit√† che non prendo alla leggera. Sono grato a tutti gli alleati per aver riposto la loro fiducia in me. Sono ansioso di assumere l'incarico - ha detto - con grande vigore in ottobre, come successore di Jens Stoltenberg, che ha fornito alla Nato una leadership eccezionale negli ultimi 10 anni e per il quale ho sempre nutrito grande ammirazione".

"So di lasciare la Nato in buone mani", ha affermato l'attuale segretario generale dell'Alleanza atlantica, Jens Stoltenberg, commentando la ratifica della nomina di Mark Rutte a suo successore. "Accolgo con grande favore la scelta di Rutte come mio successore degli alleati Nato. Mark √® un vero 'transatlantista', un leader forte e un costruttore di consenso. Gli auguro di avere successo mentre continuiamo a rafforzare la Nato", ha detto. "So di lasciare la Nato in buone mani".

 Il portavoce di Putin, Dmitri Peskov, ha dichiarato che la decisione di nominare Mark Rutte a capo della Nato "difficilmente pu√≤ cambiare qualcosa nella linea generale dell'Alleanza e dei suoi Stati membri". "Sia come Stati membri indipendenti sotto la guida diretta degli Stati Uniti sia insieme come Alleanza stanno lavorando per infliggere una sconfitta strategica alla Russia", ha aggiunto Peskov, sottolineando che "in questo momento la Nato √® ostile" a Mosca. 

Che ne pensate?

The Palestinian envoy to Japan claims that while the Japanese people are deeply committed to supporting the Palestinian people, the decision to not invite Palestinian officials to a ceremony honoring the American atomic bombing of Hiroshima was the result of "outside pressure." Anadolu Agency reports.

"I believe there was outside pressure on Hiroshima... They were under a great deal of pressure, and it's obvious who the source of that pressure was, Ambassador Waleed Siam told Anadolu.

Despite not acknowledging Palestine as a state, Japan is home to Siam's Permanent General Mission of Palestine in Tokyo.

After winning the Gold medal at the Paris Olympics, Arshad Nadeem received pledges worth crores along with gifts such as cars and apartments/ plots.

According to reports, the FBR has set its sights on his prize money and gifts. If Arshad is a filer, he will need to pay a 15% tax, amounting to Rs 3 crore, assuming the total value of his gifts and prize money is Rs 20 crore.

However, if Arshad is a non-filer, he will be liable to pay 30% in taxes, which would amount to Rs 6 crore on the pledged amount and gifts.

Mountaineer Murad Sadpara died on Monday after suffering an accident on Gilgit-Baltistan's Broad Peak the day before.

Sadpara "was hit by a rock on his head at Camp 1 and suffered severe injuries," according to PTV News, and he subsequently passed away from those wounds.

With assistance from the Pakistan Army, the villagers recovered his body. Four skilled climbers from the Pakistan Army had been sent to the base camp to help with the rescue operations.

I have Palestinian and Israeli friends, and I'm at a loss about what's "right" or "wrong." Frustration grew when I found myself in a demonstration in Berlin, the other day, where both sides were just yelling at each other. Being physically between the parties was completely different from the distanced view we usually have thru the media. The unyielding hostility was palpable. It hurts to see people I care about caught in such a deep conflict. Damn complicated, if not hopeless.

What Happened: Since October 7, over 40,000 Palestinians have reportedly been killed in Israeli attacks, according to Gaza‚Äôs Health Ministry. The situation remains dire, with many more people trapped under rubble and facing severe health risks. The humanitarian crisis has prompted urgent calls for a ceasefire.

What You Need to Know: The US and Israel have sent delegations to Qatar for renewed ceasefire talks, which resumed today. Hamas has expressed a willingness to meet with mediators after these discussions to assess whether Israel is genuinely committed to the proposed truce terms.

More: Jewish Voice for Peace, a US-based advocacy group, has reported that Israel has dropped more than 70,000 bombs on Gaza since October 7, based on UN satellite data. This significant escalation underscores the intensity of the conflict and the urgent need for a resolution to alleviate the suffering in Gaza.

I have Palestinian and Israeli friends, and I'm at a loss about what's "right" or "wrong." Frustration grew when I found myself in a demonstration in Berlin, the other day, where both sides were just yelling at each other. Being physically between the parties was completely different from the distanced view we usually have thru the media. The unyielding hostility was palpable. It hurts to see people I care about caught in such a deep conflict. Damn complicated, if not hopeless.

A drone attack early this morning caused several oil storage tanks to catch fire near the town of Azov in Russia's southern Rostov region, which borders Ukraine. The governor of the Rostov region, Vasily Golubev, reported the incident on the Telegram messaging app, stating that oil product tanks were set ablaze due to the drone strike and that, according to preliminary data, there were no casualties. The Russian Emergencies Ministry released videos showing thick smoke and large flames emanating from the affected oil storage tanks. In response to the fire, approximately 200 firefighters and emergency personnel were deployed to the site to combat the blaze.

While Ukraine did not immediately claim responsibility for the attack, it has a history of conducting similar strikes. Kyiv has justified these actions by stating that such targets are legitimate, as they are used to fuel Russia's military operations during its invasion of Ukraine. The ongoing conflict has seen frequent use of drone technology to target infrastructure critical to the opposing side's military capabilities. The incident highlights the ongoing tensions and active conflict between Russia and Ukraine, with both sides engaging in strategic strikes aimed at crippling each other's resources and military supply chains. The situation remains tense, with international observers closely monitoring the developments.
Source: Reuters, DW, EuroNews

So what
It is highly likely Kyiv is using these attacks as a way to slowly degrade Russia's ability to trade oil, thereby significantly damaging its money-making ability and directly hurting its war effort. This is due to the likelihood that the country's leadership understands that the West and other countries cannot or will not stop buying Russian oil, regardless of the situation, so their only remaining choice is to conduct attacks on this infrastructure directly. So far, this appears to be an effective strategy with Russian oil exports already falling dramatically.

India on Sunday opted out of the Ukraine declaration adopted at the two-day Summit on #Peace in Ukraine, averring that only options acceptable to both parties can bring about abiding peace.

India, along with other #BRICS nations, decided not to join more than 70 other countries in supporting a resolution that characterises the ongoing conflict as a ‚Äúwar of the Russian Federation against Ukraine‚Äù.

Presenting India‚Äôs position, Pavan Kapoor, the secretary (West) in the external affairs ministry, said: ‚ÄúIn our view, only those options acceptable to both parties can lead to abiding peace. In line with this approach, we have decided to avoid association with a joint communique or any other document emerging from this summit.‚Äù

According to Kapoor, India thought it important to join the gathering that seeks to explore the way forward for a negotiated settlement to a complex and pressing issue. ‚ÄúIndia shares the global concern over the situation in Ukraine and supports any collective desire to facilitate peaceful resolution of the conflict. India‚Äôs participation in the Summit on Peace in Ukraine as well as in the preceding NSA political director-level meetings based on Ukraine‚Äôs peace formula is in line with our clear and consistent approach that enduring peace can be achieved only through dialogue and diplomacy,‚Äù he said.

The European Union has given the green light to start membership negotiations with Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy announced in his nightly address. The talks are set to begin next week, marking a significant step in Ukraine's bid to join the European bloc, a process initiated shortly after the Russian invasion in 2022.

The EU's decision to move forward with these discussions sends a powerful message to Russia, underscoring the bloc's steadfast support for Ukraine, both politically and financially. Additionally, the EU has approved a negotiating framework for Ukraine's neighbor, Moldova, further solidifying its commitment to strengthening ties with Eastern Europe.

"It is important that every country, every society that truly professes European values and aspires to real European strength ‚Äî that every such nation ‚Äî be together with all the others in a united Europe," Zelenskyy stated, highlighting the broader implications of Ukraine's potential membership.

Meanwhile, the Kremlin has expressed willingness for security talks with the United States, provided that the conflict in Ukraine is a central topic. Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov emphasized the necessity of dialogue between the U.S. and Russia to address numerous global security issues.

"This kind of dialogue is very much required because problems are piling up, and there are a lot of problems associated with the global security architecture," Peskov said during a briefing, in response to questions about potential discussions on nuclear risks separate from the Ukrainian conflict.

BARI, Italy, June 14 (Reuters) - The Group of Seven rich democracies have agreed to use proceeds from frozen Russian assets to give Ukraine $50 billion in loans, aiming to ensure Kyiv can continue its fight against Russia's invasion and to signal Western resolve to Moscow.
Leaders of the G7 - Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States - agreed to the plan on Thursday, along with top officials from the European Union, where most of the Russian assets frozen as a result of the war are held.

Russian President Vladimir Putin's tour to Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) has opened a new dimension to the bilateral relations of these countries. Unlike 2000, when Mr Putin made his maiden visit to the North-east Asian country, the 2024 visit saw a signing of a defence pact between the two countries. This means, if the US and its allies like Japan or South Korea take any adventurist step against the DPRK, it will also draw Russia into the conflict.
As the US is reviving the military ententes against Russia and China, along with its NATO and other allies, isn't it an appropriate step for Moscow to take affirmative steps by reviving its Soviet-era military alliances in a new and pragmatic format.

In a significant move to bolster Ukraine‚Äôs defenses against Russian aggression and advance the country‚Äôs bid for NATO membership, U.S. President Joe Biden and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy signed a ‚Äúhistoric‚Äù 10-year bilateral security agreement on Thursday.

The agreement, which was finalized on the sidelines of the G7 conference in Italy, aims to ensure continued U.S. support for Ukraine regardless of potential changes in American leadership, including the possibility of a Republican victory in the upcoming November election. The initiative seeks to cement long-term security ties and enhance Ukraine's defense capabilities amid ongoing conflict with Russia.

During a joint press conference, President Biden emphasized the importance of this agreement, stating, "Our goal is to strengthen Ukraine's credible defense and deterrence capabilities for the long term." He further directed a message to Russian President Vladimir Putin, asserting, "You cannot wait us out. You cannot divide us."

In addition to the bilateral security agreement, the G7 countries collectively agreed to provide Ukraine with a $50 billion loan, financed by profits from frozen Russian assets. This financial support is intended to stabilize Ukraine‚Äôs economy and support its war efforts.

President Zelenskiy praised the security agreement as a pivotal moment for Ukraine, describing it as a framework for a sustained effort to modernize the country‚Äôs outdated armed forces and a significant step towards NATO membership. Despite long-standing aspirations, Ukraine has not yet been granted NATO membership, largely due to the alliance's stipulation that an attack on one member is considered an attack on all under its Article Five clause.

The agreement stipulates that in the event of an armed attack or credible threat against Ukraine, senior U.S. and Ukrainian officials will convene within 24 hours to discuss and coordinate an appropriate response.

Pasukan Israel menyerang sebuah sekolah di Kota Gaza, menewaskan sekitar 100 warga Palestina, termasuk perempuan dan anak-anak yang berlindung di sana. 

Menurut laporan Hamas, serangan ini terjadi saat warga sedang salat Subuh. Israel mengakui serangan itu, namun mengatakan target mereka adalah militan Hamas yang diduga mengoperasikan pusat komando di sekolah tersebut. 

Serangan ini merupakan salah satu yang paling mematikan dalam konflik Israel-Hamas, dan diperkirakan akan menghambat upaya internasional untuk melanjutkan perundingan gencatan senjata. 

AS, Qatar, dan Mesir menyerukan putaran baru perundingan pada 15 Agustus, namun Hamas belum memberikan tanggapan.

Pakistan is grappling with the decision to attend the Ukraine Peace Summit in Switzerland on June 15-16. The summit, focusing on the ongoing conflict in Ukraine following Russia's invasion in 2022, presents a significant international engagement for Islamabad. However, Pakistan's participation remains uncertain due to its long-standing policy of non-alignment.

Spokesperson for Pakistan's Foreign Office, Mumtaz Zahra Baloch, confirmed last week during a briefing that Pakistan had received an invitation to the summit. "The invitation is under consideration," Baloch stated, highlighting the careful deliberation underway in Islamabad.

Sources in local media suggest that Pakistan might refrain from attending the summit to maintain its neutral stance. The absence of Russia from the summit, despite being a key player in the conflict, has also raised questions about the efficacy and impartiality of the gathering.

China, another influential player, has already decided to abstain from the summit, citing the exclusion of Russia as a significant flaw. Beijing's decision has been noted in Islamabad, which often aligns its foreign policy closely with that of China. Analysts believe that Pakistan's final decision may hinge on further diplomatic pressures from Western nations seeking broader participation from the Global South.

The backdrop to this summit and Pakistan's dilemma is rooted in the complex geopolitical landscape that emerged following Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. At the time, Pakistan's then-Prime Minister Imran Khan was visiting Moscow, a trip that, despite its coincidental timing, drew international scrutiny and criticism.

Since then, Pakistan has navigated a cautious diplomatic path, avoiding outright condemnation of Russia's actions while seeking to maintain balanced relations. This delicate balancing act was evident as Pakistan hosted the Ukrainian Foreign Minister and dispatched humanitarian aid, yet refrained from supporting U.S.-backed resolutions against Russia at the United Nations.

#PakistanDiplomacy, #UkrainePeaceSummit, #NonAlignedMovement, #Geopolitics, #GlobalSouth, #RussiaUkraineConflict, #InternationalRelations

Ukraine on Saturday said Russia had launched a "massive" overnight attack on energy infrastructure in the west and south, adding that at least seven people died from Moscow strikes elsewhere.

Russia launched 16 cruise missiles from land, sea and air as well as 13 attack drones, aiming at energy infrastructure in several regions, Ukraine's military said.

Air defences downed all but four of them, it added.

Russia's defence ministry said that its troops "carried out a group strike with long-range high-precision weaponry from air and sea and also drones on Ukrainian energy facilities that power arms production".

It said it also targeted warehouses containing munitions and "air-launched weapons provided to the Ukrainian military by western countries".

Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orb√°n warned against allowing Ukraine to strike Russian targets with Western weapons, stating that it could bring Europe closer to destruction. In an interview on state radio, Orb√°n criticized French President Emmanuel Macron for not ruling out sending troops to Ukraine and expressed concern about a NATO proposal that would provide Kyiv with advanced long-range weapons capable of hitting Russian military bases. The Hungarian leader cautioned that these actions could escalate the conflict in Ukraine into a larger global conflict.

Russia launched a combined assault overnight, firing approximately 100 missiles and drones at various energy sites across Ukraine, Kyiv officials reported on Saturday.

This relentless barrage aimed at energy infrastructure has been a recurring tactic throughout the two-year conflict, causing substantial damage and energy shortages as Ukraine's air defenses struggle to fend off the onslaught of drones and missiles.

"""The enemy launched 53 missiles of various types and 47 attack drones,"" the air force said adding that they managed to intercept 35 of the missiles and all but one of the drones."

Two thermal power plants sustained damage in the attack, as confirmed by the DTEK operator, although specific locations were not disclosed.

"Describing the assault as ""extremely difficult night,"" the company, in a Telegram post, said, ""It was another extremely difficult night for the Ukrainian energy sector. The enemy struck two of our thermal power plants. The equipment was seriously damaged."" This incident marked the sixth major attack on DTEK thermal power plants since mid-March."

Ukraine's Energy Minister, German Galushchenko, revealed that Russia targeted sites in five regions: Donetsk, Dnipropetrovsk, Kirovograd, Ivano-Frankivsk, and Zaporizhzhia, spanning from the eastern frontlines to Ukraine's western border with the EU.

Russian President Vladimir Putin stated on Thursday that Moscow is ready for peace talks with Ukraine at any time and place.

Speaking at a news conference in Vietnam's capital Hanoi that was live-streamed on the Kremlin website, Putin said he expected that the West would oppose his peace initiative on Ukraine.

The Russian president questioned why Russia's proposal was called "unrealistic" while no one criticized the same way Ukraine's "ultimatum," containing conditions unacceptable for Moscow.

Sane politicians will think about Russia's proposal on Ukraine if they want to end the conflict, he said, warning that conditions may change depending on the situation on the battlefield.

United States President Joe Biden has eased a ban on Ukraine using US weapons inside Russian territory to help the country defend its northeastern Kharkiv region from attack.

Several US officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, told multiple media outlets on Thursday that Kyiv would be allowed to use the weapons on the border of the Kharkiv region which came under renewed Russian attack earlier this month.

The US decision, which has predictably angered Kremlin officials, marks a policy shift by Biden who had refused to let Kyiv use US weapons beyond Ukraine‚Äôs borders, and comes as France and other European countries indicated Ukraine would be allowed to use their weapons on military targets inside Russia.

Kyiv will be authorised to strike military targets on the border with the Kharkiv region, where Russia has overrun a number of villages since May 10, forcing the evacuation of thousands of residents.

‚ÄúThe president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,‚Äù a US official told the Reuters, AFP and The Associated Press news agencies. The change was first reported by online media outlet Politico.

‚ÄºÔ∏èNigel Farage, leader del partito Riforma del Regno Unito, ha affermato che l‚Äôespansione verso est della NATO e dell‚ÄôUnione Europea ha provocato l‚Äôinvasione russa dell‚ÄôUcraina. Farage, noto per le sue posizioni controverse e per essere stato spesso accusato di simpatizzare con Putin, ha dichiarato durante un‚Äôintervista alla BBC che l‚ÄôOccidente ha fornito a Putin un pretesto per agire. Ha aggiunto che, sebbene condanni le azioni di Putin, ritiene che la reazione russa sia stata una risposta all‚Äôespansione occidentale.
Queste dichiarazioni hanno suscitato forti critiche da parte di esponenti di vari partiti politici britannici, che lo accusano di giustificare l‚Äôaggressione russa e di non sostenere adeguatamente il popolo ucraino. James Cleverly e Ben Wallace hanno denunciato le affermazioni di Farage come echi della propaganda russa, mentre John Healey ha dichiarato che tali commenti lo rendono inadatto a qualsiasi carica politica.

Farage ha inoltre discusso di Brexit, sostenendo che se fosse stato lui a guidare il paese fuori dall‚ÄôUe, una scelta avrebbe portato maggiori benefici economici. Ha criticato le politiche di ‚Äúnet zero‚Äù per aver contribuito alla deindustrializzazione della Gran Bretagna e ha difeso il mini-budget di Liz Truss come pro-crescita e pro-business.

Stiamo parlando di un uomo ha usato gas nervino per le strade della Gran Bretagna e sta stringendo accordi con paesi come la Corea del Nord".

Russian President Vladimir Putin asserted that the collective nuclear arsenals of Western nations cannot compete with Russia's own formidable stockpile. His remarks come amid heightened tensions between Russia and Western countries, particularly over the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.

According to international news sources, President Putin declared, "Russia does not need nuclear weapons to achieve victory in Ukraine. The combined nuclear capabilities of Western nations are still no match for Russia‚Äôs." This assertion underscores his confidence in Russia's military superiority despite global concerns about nuclear proliferation and security.

Meanwhile, American media reports indicate that the United States is reconsidering its nuclear strategy in response to perceived threats from Russia and China. The Biden administration is reportedly contemplating an increase in its nuclear arsenal, a significant shift from decades of disarmament efforts. This potential policy change is seen as a direct response to the evolving geopolitical landscape and the need to maintain strategic parity with major adversaries.

According to the reports, President Joe Biden has signed an executive order outlining the conditions under which the U.S. might deploy nuclear weapons. This move reflects a broader strategic reassessment aimed at addressing the challenges posed by Russia's and China's expanding military capabilities.
 
The escalating rhetoric and strategic maneuvers emphasize the growing tensions between global powers. Experts warn that such developments could lead to a renewed arms race, reminiscent of the Cold War era, with potentially dire consequences for international stability and security.

In a decisive statement, Defense Minister Boris Pistorius emphasized the urgent need for Germany to bolster its armed forces, the Bundeswehr, to achieve full operational readiness before the decade's end. His comments come amid rising concerns over European security following Russia's extensive invasion of Ukraine.

Speaking during a session in the Bundestag, Germany's lower house of parliament, Pistorius stressed the necessity for preparedness. "We must be ready for war by 2029," he declared, underscoring the importance of deterrence to prevent potential conflicts. Pistorius highlighted that achieving this goal hinges on securing adequate finances, materials, and personnel.

"In an emergency, we need strong young women and men who can defend this country," he said, advocating for a new form of military service. He noted that this service model "cannot be completely free of obligations," reflecting his belief in the essential role of conscription in national defense.

Pistorius, affiliated with Chancellor Olaf Scholz's center-left Social Democrats, has tasked his ministry with exploring various models for reintroducing military conscription. Germany had suspended compulsory military service in 2011. Recent surveys, such as one conducted by research institute Forsa in March, indicate that about half of German citizens support its reinstatement.

US to Send Patriot Missile System to Ukraine

US President Joe Biden has approved the deployment of another Patriot missile system to Ukraine to bolster its air defenses amid ongoing Russian attacks. The system, coming from Poland, will be deployed within days. Germany and the Netherlands have also contributed Patriot systems to Ukraine.

ü•Ä Fourteen people died in an air raid on the capital, Sanaa, and at least three children were killed in an attack on the port city of Hodeida. 

ü•Ä On Jan 21, an airstrike on a prison in the northern city of Saada, the rebels' home base, killed at least 87 people and wounded more than 100, overwhelming hospitals‚Äîthough the coalition has denied responsibility for the prison attack. (Aid agencies on the ground like Doctors Without Borders have dismissed the denial.)

La Germania autorizza gli ucraini a difendersi ‚Äúnel rispetto del diritto internazionale‚Äù contro gli attacchi che arrivano da immediatamente oltre confine. E questo ‚Äúanche con le armi consegnate‚Äù, comprese quelle tedesche. Lo dice il portavoce del cancelliere Scholz, Steffen Hebestreit, in una nota.

Tuttavia Washington ha posto un limite sul tipo di armi vietando l'utilizzo di Atacms o missili a lungo raggio in questo tipo di attacchi. Lo rivela un funzionario americano al Wall Street Journal. La decisione, spiegano le fonti, deriva dal tentativo del presidente di aiutare l'Ucraina a difendersi meglio, ma allo stesso tempo evitare un'escalation con Mosca.

According to US officials, President Joe Biden has authorized Ukraine to use American-supplied weapons to attack targets in Russia, specifically in the Kharkiv region.

The officials stated that their directive is to ensure that Ukraine can utilize US weapons for ‚Äúcounter-fire purposes‚Äù in order to retaliate against Russian forces that are attacking or preparing to attack them.

In recent weeks, Russian forces have made advancements in the Kharkiv region following an unexpected offensive in the vicinity, near the Russian border.

Ukrainian officials reported on Friday that three individuals were killed and 16 injured when a residential building in a suburb of Kharkiv city was hit by Russian shelling.

‚ÄúOur policy with respect to prohibiting the use of Army Tactical Missile System [ATACMS] or long-range strikes inside of Russia has not changed,‚Äù The officials stated.

When questioned about whether the new policy involved engaging Russian aircraft, an official responded: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve never told them [Ukraine] they can‚Äôt shoot down a Russian airplane over Russian soil that‚Äôs coming to attack them‚Äù.

The White House and state department did not provide an immediate comment.

Earlier, the UK indicated that it was willing to ease restrictions on how Ukraine could utilize weapons provided by the West.

Despite concerns about potential escalation of the conflict, several European leaders have recently advocated for relaxing restrictions on the use of such weapons.

However, Washington, which is the main supplier of Ukraine‚Äôs weaponry, has been reluctant to ease these restrictions due to fears of escalation.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken suggested this change during his visit to Moldova on Wednesday.

He said that: ‚ÄúAt every step along the way, we‚Äôve adapted and adjusted as necessary, and so that‚Äôs exactly what we‚Äôll do going forward‚Äù.

Data With Geopolitics Explained

Weapons Sales (SIPRI TIV Million)(December 2022)

In a more fractured world, we're seeing more conflicts. These conflicts are often fought with weapons traded between countries. This dataset shows the weapons sales by country in December 2022. The unit, SIPRI TIV Million, is used to measure the volume of sales of weapons, not the price. If used by another force, these weapons are valued at 40% of TIV and weapons that have been refurbished or modified are valued at 66% of TIV. TIV refers to trend-indicator value and reflects military capability, not financial value. As we can see, the United States is leaps and bounds clear of anybody else, likely due to aid to Ukraine. France, Russia, China, Italy, Germany, the UK, Spain, Israel, and Poland make up the 2nd to 10th position.

As the Russia-Ukraine conflict persists, Egypt, Israel, Oman, Nigeria, and South Africa have turned to India for wheat supplies, fearing a global food crisis. India, the world's second-largest wheat producer, is also exploring new markets like Turkey and Sudan. The government is actively addressing logistical challenges to meet the surging demand, with talks underway to export to Egypt.

Russia has moved aggressively to block Ukraine‚Äôs grain exports, aiming to crush both a critical economic sector and source of national pride. But Ukrainians have found ways to keep their crucial food supplies flowing as they enter the third year of Europe‚Äôs largest war in eight decades.

As the conflict continues, Russia has targeted Ukrainian grain and port facilities with air strikes, a potential war crime. The ports supplied staple goods to people around the world and anchored Ukraine‚Äôs economy. But a Russian blockade has changed the calculus.

Naval victories and innovative export routes have allowed Ukraine to keep its grain moving. After the collapse of the Black Sea grain deal, policymakers feared prices would again soar and potentially leave millions hungry. However, the worst was avoided due to a series of new export corridors that have kept the grain flowing.

Germany has also permitted Ukraine to use German-delivered weapons for similar defensive strikes.

Russian forces have started the first stage of exercises ordered by President Vladimir Putin to simulate preparation for the launch of tactical nuclear weapons, the Defence Ministry said on Tuesday.

Moscow has linked the exercises to what it calls ‚Äúmilitant statements‚Äù by Western officials, including French President Emmanuel Macron, which it said created security threats for Russia.

Nuclear analysts say the exercises are designed as a warning signal by Putin to deter the West from wading more deeply into the war in Ukraine. Western countries have provided weapons and intelligence to Kyiv but have refrained from sending troops.

The Defence Ministry said the first stage of the exercise involved Iskander and Kinzhal missiles.

It is aimed at ensuring that units and equipment are ready for ‚Äúthe combat use of non-strategic nuclear weapons to respond and unconditionally ensure the territorial integrity and sovereignty of the Russian state in response to provocative statements and threats of individual Western officials against the Russian Federation‚Äù, the ministry said.

The drills involve missile forces in Russia‚Äôs Southern Military District, which lies adjacent to Ukraine and also includes parts of Ukraine that Russia now controls.

Belarus, where Russia said last year it was deploying tactical nuclear weapons, will also be involved, the two countries have said.

Tactical, or non-strategic, nuclear weapons are less powerful than the strategic arms designed to wipe out whole enemy cities, but they nevertheless have vast destructive potential.

Some Western analysts believe non-strategic nuclear weapons have acquired greater importance in Moscow‚Äôs thinking since the start of the war in Ukraine, where its conventional forces struggled in the first two years.

In theory the use of such a weapon could deliver a stunning shock to the West without necessarily triggering a full-blown nuclear war, though the risk of triggering a cycle of escalation would be huge.

New Zealand's Defence Minister, Judith Collins, has announced a notable reduction in the nation's defense budget, proposing a cut of 6.6%. This decision arises amidst ongoing challenges related to personnel and equipment within the New Zealand Defence Force (NZDF). According to the Defence Minister's office, the current budgetary reduction aims to address these critical issues by reallocating resources and ensuring better financial management.

The government's conservative administration is responsible for this budgetary adjustment. Despite the reduction, the government has also allocated a substantial sum of $571 million to the defense sector. This funding aims to address pay raises for Defence Force personnel and invest in various projects and equipment upgrades.

Despite the proposed cuts, the government has simultaneously committed to a substantial investment of $571 million to bolster the NZDF. Announced on May 10, 2024, this funding is specifically targeted towards improving pay for Defence Force personnel and upgrading critical equipment and infrastructure. The Defence Minister emphasized that this allocation is intended to enhance the operational readiness and welfare of the NZDF, even as the overall budget sees a reduction.

Putin Signals Willingness to End Ukraine Conflict

Russian President Vladimir Putin is prepared to bring the conflict in Ukraine to a close, according to reports from Reuters. Putin is ready to agree to a ceasefire that acknowledges the current positions of both sides on the battlefield.

A senior Russian source, familiar with high-level discussions within the Kremlin, revealed to Reuters that while Putin is capable of continuing the fight indefinitely, he is open to freezing the conflict with a ceasefire. "Putin can fight for as long as it takes, but he is also ready for a ceasefire‚Äîto freeze the war," the source said.

Dmitry Peskov, Putin's spokesman, reiterated that the Russian President has consistently advocated for dialogue as a means to end the war. Peskov emphasized that Russia does not desire a perpetual conflict.

The war, which began on February 24, 2022, remains ongoing as of today, May 24, 2024.

Russia‚Äôs offensive in Ukraine‚Äôs northeastern border region of Kharkiv may just be the ‚Äúfirst wave‚Äù in a wider assault, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has warned as he appealed to allies to send more air defence and fighter jets.

https://www.yahoo.com/news/death-toll-belgorod-apartment-building-202525478.html At least 15 people were killed in the Russian city of Belgorod after an apartment building collapsed on May 12, Russia's Emergency Situations Ministry claimed.

Two children are among those killed, the ministry claimed.

According to the Belgorod Oblast Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov, a part of a 10-story apartment building collapsed there earlier in the day.

Gladkov also claimed that the building was hit by a Ukrainian projectile during an air raid alert in the oblast.

Russian air defenses allegedly shot down six Tochka-U missiles and six rockets over Belgorod Oblast, according to the Russian Defense Ministry. The ministry claimed that the residential building was "damaged" by a Tochka-U missile fragment.

Ukrainian officials did not comment on the claims. The Kyiv Independent could not independently verify the reports.

Russia - Ukraine
End the conflict.

"The Russia-Ukraine conflict will end like that, as calmly as an ending party."

Because according to my personal observation, the conflict is gradually entering a stable trajectory.

The details seem to direct the conflict into the final chapters so it can end peacefully.

Based on what do I say that?

As you know, over the past 2 years, the Ukrainian side has fiercely resisted Russia's attacks.

At the same time, continuously strengthen forces, provide military training, and organize counterattack campaigns into Russian territory.

Or most recently, the terrorist attack at Crocus City Hall theater aimed at dividing Russia is believed to be related to Ukraine.

Meanwhile, the US and Western countries tried hard to interfere in the Russian election.

  At the same time as they strive to provide aid to Kiev, call for sanctions, and confiscate Russian assets almost as much as possible, they are anti-Russian to the point of self-destruction.

There are times when it seems like Russia is fighting against the whole world.

But then what happened? Nothing. Russia is still there. Russian troops continue to advance deeper and deeper into Ukrainian territory.

In short, over the past two years, everything Ukraine and its allies could do, they have done.

But the situation is still irreversible. The Russian side continues to dominate.

As long as Russia can maintain its current minimum performance, the end of the conflict will come in the near future.

It's like a party.

When all parties involved are hungry, they will try to eat as enthusiastically as possible.

  But no matter how delicious it is, there will come a time when they all feel full and start to get bored.

The Russia-Ukraine conflict will also end like that, as calmly as an ending party.

Russian President Vladimir Putin has expressed confidence in Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, showing openness to peace talks with Ukraine, possibly mediated by India. PM Modi's recent diplomatic efforts, including discussions with Putin, U.S. President Biden, and Ukraine's President Zelenskyy, have positioned India as a potential mediator in the ongoing conflict. India‚Äôs focus on dialogue and diplomacy has garnered international attention as the war approaches its third year. With both Russia and Ukraine considering India's role in peace talks, India could play a key part in advancing efforts toward a peaceful resolution.

I will be having on the podcast this week the CEO of Bliss Farm Integrated, Oyeleke Oluwakayode, S. 

Bliss Farm Integrated runs a farm to table service, in Ibadan, where, employing traceability and food entertainment, consumers are given unique experience with products farmed fresh and cooked for retail in a fun ambience and the consumers carried along in the journey.

Oyeleke would be sharing valuable insights on ensuring a sustainable agribusiness in a chaotic business environment of today.

Food and agricultural businesses have been one of the most impacted ventures by and left with lasting effects of ravaging macroeconomic events of the last few years.

At least 50% of the nation‚Äôs poultry farms has shutdown to this.

This is similar event in the quick service restaurant sector (QSR) losing more than half of its over ‚Ç¶250 billion worth.

The Bliss Farm integrated operates in both the food and agribusiness sector and has witnessed and been impacted by these macroeconomic occurences. 

It farms and was affected by input supply chain disruption of Russia-Ukraine conflict and covid pandemic and also low patronage from lockdown and movement restriction of the latter. It also was battered by dwindled purchasing power to cash crunch, inflation and recession.

Despite facing all these, Bliss Farm stood tall weathering these challenges and growing bigger even establishing multiple branches across Ibadan.

This is to the prowess of Oluwakayode in thinking ahead and evolving formidable strategy -that encompasses cost effectiveness, business pivoting and product development, and effective operational and strategic managements. 

It why when I thought of this topic Oyeleke and his company were the perfect match. 

You want to anticipate this podcast and listen to it as it promises potent insights that would help with sustainably managing and scaling your agribusiness.

The State Department notified Congress on Wednesday that it had determined Russian forces have employed chemical weapons against Ukrainian troops. The congressional notification came in accordance with the U.S. Chemical and Biological Weapons Control and Warfare Elimination Act of 1991 (CBW).

‚ÄúThe Department of State has made a determination under the CBW Act that Russia has used the chemical weapon chloropicrin against Ukrainian forces in violation of the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC),‚Äù the State Department announced. ‚ÄúWe make this determination in addition to our assessment that Russia has used riot control agents as a method of warfare in Ukraine, also in violation of the CWC.‚Äù

Chloropicrin was first used as a weapon during World War I.

#ukrainewar #russiaukrainewar #russiaukraineconflict #chemicalweapons #chemicalwarfare

The counteroffensive last year fell short, resulting in Russia's significant recapture of Avdiivka. President Zelensky has acknowledged this new military reality, and the Biden Administration‚Äôs strategy now aims to sustain Ukraine's defense until after the U.S. presidential elections, hoping to exhaust Russian forces in a prolonged war of attrition. However, this approach has significant implications and potential flaws not fully addressed in public discourse.

The critical implication of this strategy is the indefinite loss of territories currently occupied by Russia. Russia is unlikely to relinquish these lands at the negotiating table. While Ukraine should not formally surrender these territories, their status may need to be deferred for future talks, akin to the Cyprus situation, where negotiations have persisted for decades without resolution or renewed conflict.

The Biden Administration must also align American public opinion with this reality. Supporters of a complete Ukrainian victory may hold overly optimistic views, such as the notion of driving Russia out of Crimea through missile bombardment‚Äîa strategy deemed impractical given Ukraine‚Äôs limited amphibious capabilities.

A more realistic scenario involves Ukraine inflicting significant losses on Russian forces while on the defensive, potentially enabling a successful counterattack in 2025. However, this relies on continuous Western weapon supplies and favorable battlefield conditions, which are uncertain.

The Biden Administration should test Putin‚Äôs readiness for peace talks, which would require painful concessions from Ukraine and the West. Nonetheless, these concessions are more emotional than practical and are preferable to prolonged conflict and potential Ukrainian defeat. Recognizing the lost territories and focusing on Ukraine's current borders could pave the way for a feasible peace settlement and prevent further devastation. #talkdiplomacy #upsc #css #cuet #UkraineWar

Rusia-Ukraina kembali memanas, kali ini Rusia menyerang Ukraina dengan rudal! üò±

Serangan rudal Rusia menghantam sebuah institusi pendidikan di kota pelabuhan Odesa, Ukraina. Serangan ini menimbulkan korban jiwa lima orang dan sekitar 32 orang lainnya mengalami luka-luka dalam serangan tersebut. Delapan korban luka di antaranya kini dalam kondisi serius di rumah sakit setempat.

Tayangan televisi Reuters menunjukkan atap gedung akademi hukum swasta, yang penuh ornamen, hancur akibat serangan rudal Rusia. Reaksi keras diberikan oleh Wali Kota Odesa, Hennadii Trukhanov, yang mengecam serangan Rusia tersebut.

Juru bicara Angkatan Laut Ukraina, Dmytro Pletenchuk, dalam pernyataan via Telegram, menyebut serangan itu melibatkan rudal balistik Iskander-M dengan hulu ledak klaster.

Laporan televisi setempat Suspilne menyebut presiden akademi hukum yang dihantam serangan itu, Serhiy Kivalov, termasuk di antara korban luka. Kivalov diketahui seorang mantan anggota parlemen terkemuka di Ukraina.

A recent report from a U.N. sanctions committee has revealed that a North Korean-made Hwasong-11 series ballistic missile was responsible for striking Kharkiv on January 2. Both Ukrainian and U.S. officials have previously alleged Russia‚Äôs utilization of North Korean-produced missiles in attacks on Ukraine. The report further suggests that Russia‚Äôs acquisition of these missiles violates U.N. sanctions, raising concerns about Moscow‚Äôs military cooperation with Pyongyang.

Inspectors conducting a field investigation in Kharkiv found fragments from the missile that indicate its North Korean origin. Notably, the report emphasizes the absence of evidence linking the missile to Russian manufacturing. As Russia‚Äôs top weapons supplier, North Korea‚Äôs provision of advanced military equipment to Moscow underscores growing apprehensions about the extent of collaboration between the two nations and its potential implications for regional security dynamics.

The United States has intensified its response to Moscow's alleged use of chemical weapons against Ukrainian forces by imposing additional sanctions on over 280 entities. These measures, targeting both Russian and non-Russian organizations, aim to cripple Russia's military and industrial capabilities. Among the targeted entities are 20 firms based in China and Hong Kong, reflecting concerns about growing military cooperation between China and Russia. The US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen emphasized that these sanctions would disrupt Russia's war efforts and support Ukraine's resistance. The Russian and Chinese embassies in Washington, DC, have yet to respond to these actions. Additionally, the US Department of State accused Russia of violating the Chemical Weapons Convention by using chloropicrin, a choking agent. Such actions highlight the international community's condemnation of Russia's aggressive tactics in the ongoing conflict.

Citing the 'unprecedented' conflicts that broke out in Ukraine and Gaza, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar said that coming years will be "very difficult", adding that once a conflict starts, it continues to escalate on its own.

He said that no one expected the Russia-Ukraine conflict to continue for over three years, or an attack on Israel of such a massive scale taking place on October 7.

The EAM was interacting with the first-time voters at Delhi Tamil Association School in the national capital on Monday.
Addressing the event, Jaishankar said, "We all should expect the coming years to be very difficult. Nobody expected that there would be a war in Ukraine. Even when it started, people expected it to be over in a few weeks, a few months. We are now in the third year of war with Ukraine with no end in sight...Nobody expected this kind of an attack on Israel in October, that this level of damage and killing would be done, or when Israel responded this would go for so long. It's already over six months."

On Sunday, the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) issued a fervent plea to the government, urging immediate diplomatic interventions to aid Nepalis adversely impacted by the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Tikaram Pokharel, spokesperson for the commission, emphasized the necessity for diplomatic efforts to facilitate the rescue of affected Nepalis and ensure prompt medical treatment for the injured.

In a formal statement, Pokharel stressed the urgency of repatriating the bodies of Nepalis who lost their lives in the conflict. The NHRC also underscored the critical importance of intervening to safeguard the lives of individuals such as Kritu Bhandari, who have been staging a hunger strike in Kathmandu for 17 days, demanding the rescue of fellow Nepalis.

The NHRC's field inspection team reported a concerning deterioration in the health conditions of those participating in the hunger strike on a daily basis.

KYIV ¬≠‚Äî Ukraine‚Äôs security service said Tuesday it had foiled a plot to assassinate President Volodymyr Zelensky by undercover Ukrainian security officials who were working for Russia.

Two unnamed colonels from the Ukrainian State Security Department, the SBU , the main organization protecting top officials including Zelensky, were part of a group of covert agents helping Russia‚Äôs security service, the FSB, to plot the assassination, Kyiv said.

The colonels were arrested and Kyiv said the conspiracy included plans to also murder SBU chief Vasyl Malyuk and Military Intelligence boss Kyrylo Budanov.Zelensky has previously said he has survived more than 10 assassination attempts. ‚ÄúBut it is the first time such a high-ranking official of the state security department has become the enemy‚Äôs moles,- Artem Dehtiarenko, SBU spokesman.

One of the tasks of the FSB intelligence network was to search for executors among the military close to the protection of the president, who could first take him hostage and later kill him,‚Äù- the SBU press service said in a statement.

Besides Zelensky, a group of FSB agents including the defector colonels were planning to assassinate spymaster Budanov, Kyiv said.

Following his criticism of Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine,¬†Rabbi Pinchas Goldschmidt¬†and his family were forced to flee Russia, fearing their immediate arrest. Goldschmidt has since been labeled a ‚ÄúForeign Agent‚Äù by Russia, becoming the first religious leader in Russia to be named as such, a title he carries with distinction.¬†

Today, Rabbi Goldschmidt serves as the President of the Conference of European Rabbis, an umbrella organization which advocates on behalf of Jewish communities across Europe. For his work, he is being presented with the 2024 Charlemagne Prize, awarded for work done in the service of European unification.¬†

Rabbi Goldschmidt  believes that the Kremlin is one of the key players fomenting dissent on college campuses across the US.. He believes hatred towards Jews on campuses should be confronted and communities in Europe are combating similar challenges.  He also believesAmerica and Western democracies should align themselves with Ukraine and Israel.

The Moscow Exchange halted trading in U.S. dollars and euros on Thursday following new U.S. sanctions targeting Russia's financial sector amidst the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.

"Due to the imposition of restrictive measures by the United States against the Moscow Exchange Group, starting June 13, 2024, trading on the Moscow Exchange markets will exclude instruments settled in U.S. dollars and euros," the exchange announced.

Additionally, the U.S. sanctioned Russia‚Äôs National Clearing Center, which facilitates foreign exchange transactions.

On Wednesday, the U.S. Treasury Department expanded its sanctions, targeting over 300 entities, including those in Russia and allied nations such as China, Turkey, and the UAE, aiming to restrict the flow of money and goods supporting Russia's war efforts.

Vladimir Putin was sworn in as Russia's president for a record fifth term, promising to lead the country through its "difficult" period. The inauguration at the Grand Kremlin Palace was boycotted by the United States, United Kingdom, and several European Union countries amid ongoing tensions over Russia‚Äôs war in Ukraine. In his speech, Putin emphasized national unity and resilience, stating that the country would overcome obstacles and emerge victorious. Critics questioned the legitimacy of the election and the conduct of Putin's rule, citing issues such as the death of political rival Alexey Navalny and the crackdown on opposition.

‚ÄúLa nostra posizione non cambia: abbiamo sempre detto che l‚ÄôUcraina andava aiutata in ogni modo possibile, e lo stiamo facendo, ma abbiamo anche sempre escluso un intervento diretto nel conflitto dei nostri militari''. Lo dice in un'intervista al 'Corriere della Sera' il ministro della Difesa Guido Crosetto. ''A differenza di altri, noi abbiamo nel nostro ordinamento il divieto esplicito di interventi militari diretti, al di fuori di quanto previsto dalle leggi e dalla Costituzione. Possiamo prevedere interventi armati solo su mandato internazionale, ad esempio in attuazione di una risoluzione dell‚ÄôOnu. Quello ipotizzato in Ucraina non solo non rientrerebbe in questo caso, ma innescherebbe una ulteriore spiralizzazione del conflitto che non gioverebbe soprattutto agli stessi ucraini. Insomma, non esistono le condizioni per un nostro coinvolgimento diretto''. 

Crosetto risponde alla proposta di Macron, l'invio di truppe occidentali in Ucraina, escludendo un intervento diretto dei nostri militari. "Non giudico un presidente di un paese amico come la Francia, ma non comprendo la finalit√† e l‚Äôutilit√† di queste dichiarazioni, che oggettivamente innalzano la tensione''. Per Crosetto ''se i Russi arrivassero a Kiev, se conquistassero un paese sovrano, se dessimo per scontato, come alcuni sedicenti esperti e professori compiacenti verso la Russia, e mi chiedo come si faccia a esserlo gratis... , che si pu√≤ invadere un altro paese solo perch√© si √® pi√π forti, sarebbe un disastro per tutti''. Quindi l'Italia continuer√† a ''fornire aiuti, come abbiamo fatto finora, finch√© sar√† utile e finch√© potremo farlo''.

A military court in Moscow has reportedly sentenced Meta Platforms spokesperson Andy Stone to six years in prison in absentia for ‚Äòpublicly defending terrorism.‚Äô This ruling comes amid Russia‚Äôs crackdown on Meta, which was designated as an extremist organisation in the country, resulting in the banning of Facebook and Instagram in 2022 due to Russia‚Äôs conflict with Ukraine.

Meta has yet to comment on the reported sentencing of Stone, who serves as the company‚Äôs communications director. Stone himself was unavailable for immediate response following the court‚Äôs decision. Stone‚Äôs lawyer, Valentina Filippenkova, indicated they intend to appeal the verdict, expressing a request for acquittal.

The Russian interior ministry initiated a criminal investigation against Stone late last year, although the specific charges were not disclosed then. According to state investigators, Stone‚Äôs online comments allegedly defended ‚Äòaggressive, hostile, and violent actions‚Äô against Russian soldiers involved in what Russia terms its ‚Äòspecial military operation‚Äô in Ukraine.

Russia Steps Up Offensive in Eastern Ukraine

Russia has deployed more troops to Ocheretyne in eastern Ukraine as part of an offensive, but Ukrainian forces maintain control of most of the village and anticipate US arms deliveries to bolster their position, according to the Ukrainian military, Reuters reports.

The Russians have advanced through several villages in the east since capturing Avdiivka in February, as Ukrainian forces faced dwindling supplies. Fierce fighting continues in Ocheretyne, but Ukrainian forces claim to have two-thirds of the village under control. Russian forces are also targeting the strategic town of Chasiv Yar to the north, aiming to capture it as part of their larger push to control the Donbas region.

Despite being outnumbered and outgunned, Ukrainian morale received a boost with the approval of a major US aid package containing military assistance. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has warned of a possible Russian offensive in late May or June.

Banyak cara dan strategi Rusia untuk menjatuhkan mental pasukan Ukraina di medan perang sekaligus mempermalukan negara Barat anggota NATO yang selama ini jadi sekutu Ukraina.¬†

Satu diantaranya dengan menyelenggarakan pameran senjata hasil rampasan perang selama konflik Rusia melawan Ukraina di Kota Moskow.

Sebuah pameran peralatan militer Barat yang dirampas dari pasukan Kyiv selama pertempuran di Ukraina dibuka di ibu kota Rusia pada Rabu (1/5).¬†

Pameran yang diselenggarakan oleh Kementerian Pertahanan Rusia itu menampilkan lebih dari 30 alat berat buatan Barat, termasuk tank tempur M1 Abrams buatan AS dan kendaraan tempur lapis baja Bradley, tank Leopard 2 dan kendaraan infanteri lapis baja Marder dari Jerman, dan kendaraan lapis baja AMX-10RC buatan Prancis.

Lokasi pameran senjata itu diadakan di Victory Park, Moskow. Sebuah taman yang didedikasikan untuk kemenangan USSR terhadap Nazi pada Perang Dunia 2 dahulu.

Lokasi itu juga merupakan tempat dimana Napoleon Bonaparte berdiri pada 1812 sebelum memasuki Moskow pada Perang Patriot melawan Prancis

The Russian invasion of Ukraine began on February 24 2022, days after Russia recognised two breakaway Ukrainian republics. Russia‚Äôs invasion was, in fact, an escalation of the Russo-Ukrainian War that started in 2014. The invasion became the largest attack on a European country since World War II. The invasion has caused tens of thousands of Ukrainian civilian casualties and hundreds of thousands of military casualties. By June 2022, Russian troops occupied about 20% of Ukrainian territory.

From a population of 41 million in January 2022, about 8 million Ukrainians had been internally displaced and more than 8.2 million had fled the country by April 2023, creating Europe‚Äôs largest refugee crisis since World War II. Extensive environmental damage caused by the war led to global food crises. The war rages on but media fatigue has taken it off from the headlines. By September 2022, military costs were estimated at $40 billion. The 2022 GDP losses amounted to between $81 billion and $104 billion and financial capital destruction reached $322 billion by year-end.

Ranjan Solomon writes:

Russia has announced plans to integrate drone operations into the curriculum of schools located in occupied territories, effective September 1. This decision has sparked outrage, with many condemning it as a blatant violation of international law and humanitarian principles.

Ivan Fedorov, the head of the Zaporizhzhia Regional State Administration, took to Telegram to denounce the Kremlin's actions, stating, "From September 1, 2024, schools in the temporarily occupied territories of Ukraine will introduce a new subject ‚Äì a course on controlling unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV). Officially, they may call it ‚Äòtraining,‚Äô but in reality they are preparing young people to kill."

This revelation comes after Ukraine's National Resistance Center (NRC) disclosed similar plans by Russia earlier this year. According to the NRC, the curriculum will cover technical aspects and assembly of UAVs for military purposes, while also encouraging further education in technical fields and employment in military industries among students.

Fedorov further emphasized that Russia intends to provide every school with training UAVs and deploy Russian military personnel to instruct children. However, such actions are deeply concerning, as training minors for military purposes and potentially involving them in conflicts against their own nation constitute grave violations of international law.

The international community has expressed alarm over Russia's decision, calling for diplomatic efforts to address the situation and protect the rights of affected children. As tensions persist, the implications of this controversial move extend far beyond the borders of the occupied territories.

Ukraine‚Äôs top commander has said Kyiv‚Äôs outnumbered troops fell back to new positions west of three villages on the eastern front, where Russia has concentrated significant forces in several locations.

Sunday‚Äôs statement by Colonel General Oleksandr Syrskii reflected on Ukraine‚Äôs deteriorating position in the east, which Kyiv hopes it can stabilise once it receives United States weapons under a $61bn aid package approved in the US this week.

‚ÄúThe situation at the front has worsened,‚Äù Syrskii wrote on the Telegram app, describing the ‚Äúmost difficult‚Äù areas as west of occupied Maryinka and northwest of Avdiivka, the town captured by Russian forces in February.

Kyiv‚Äôs troops, he said, had taken up new positions west of the villages of Berdychi and Semenivka, both north of Avdiivka, and Novomykhailivka, further south near the town of Maryinka.

‚ÄúIn general, the enemy achieved certain tactical successes in these areas, but could not gain operational advantages,‚Äù Oleksandr Syrskii said, adding that Russia had committed four brigades to the assault.

Yemeni rebel offensive threatens camps of those who fled war

Already displaced once in Yemen‚Äôs grinding civil war, Mohammed Ali Saleh fled with his pregnant wife and their three children to central Marib province last year to seek refuge in a region that has known some relative peace and stability because of well-protected oil fields nearby.

But now the fighting is moving toward them again.

Iran-backed Houthi rebels are pushing to capture the province from the internationally recognized government to try to complete their control over the northern half of Yemen. If they succeed, the Houthis could claim a strategic win after a largely stalemated battle in almost seven years of fighting.

The sounds of war terrify Saleh and his family.

YEMEN:  Two-year-old Eyad is badly malnourished and is given water by his mother in a hospital bed in Sanaa. This picture is from 2018 when journalist @tparabien and I visited Yemen to document the effects of the then three-year-long civil war. Nearly three years have passed since then but the situation, unfortunately, has only changed for the wors. 80% of the population are in need of humanitarian aid and despite everything happening in the world the UN still regard this as the worlds worst humanitarian crisis.
After a brief increase in attention and aid to the country back in 2018 last year especially have been hard on the population struggling with increased flooding, less outside aid and the effects of covid19-restrictions.
Let's help spread the word about this terrible humanitarian tragedy.

Winston Churchill once said that ‚ÄúHistory is written by the victors‚Äù. There could be contrary views to this assertion, but this testimony surely does not resonate with the case of Russia-Ukraine War. As we are advancing, the complete collapse of Ukrainian Territory at the hands Russian Federation seems inevitable. 

But I suspect that this will ever go down in History the way things have truly unfolded. Well, the history is not really written by the victors, rather it is written by someone who is really good with documentation and narrative.

The book ‚ÄúRussia Forever‚Äù is a timely intervention into the field of geopolitical literature. Penned by Ashish Shukla, a geopolitical analyst who has shown his presence on International Media. If you follow the international media today, remarks in the favour of Ukraine truly dominates the narrative. 

The contemporary war in the region is not new. The seed of it was sowed back in 2014 with the Russia‚Äôs annexation of Crimea. But what were the reasons behind which forced Russians to barge into a sovereign state and to create it as buffer zone between NATO (Europe) and Itself?

The book draws you to a detailed background of this conflict which traces its roots back in time. Under Gorbachev, Russians were told about the Enlargement of NATO and a ‚Äúguaranteed non-expansion of NATO in Eastern Europe‚Äù. 

But over the period of time, the bearers of utmost morality and truth ‚Äî The Americans, gushed from the words of assurance given to the Russians and NATO expanded heavily & aggressively in Eastern Europe. Seeing it as a potential threat to the Russian Sovereignty, the invasion of Crimea happened followed by the current ongoing war.
.

According to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, Russia managed to destroy the Trypilska thermal power station, a major electricity provider for the Kyiv region, due to a shortage of air defense missiles.

Zelenskyy revealed in an interview with American broadcaster PBS that although 11 missiles were launched, only seven were intercepted. The remaining four successfully hit the Trypilska power station because there were no more available missiles for defense.

In other developments, Zelenskyy has signed a new mobilization law which will come into effect one month after its official publication. This legislation mandates men to update their draft information with authorities, increases payments for volunteers, and imposes additional penalties for those evading the draft.

Pentagon swiftly dispatches $1 billion worth of weapons to Kyiv following President Biden's signing of a $95 billion foreign aid bill. The move aims to bolster Ukrainian forces, who have faced challenges against Russian incursions. Biden emphasized the urgency, stating, "We need to move fast." The package, which includes critical air defense systems and artillery, signifies a shift in Washington's Ukraine policy, overcoming previous delays caused by partisan disputes. Biden stressed the importance of standing by allies and opposing tyrants, reaffirming America's role as the "indispensable nation." The aid package, including advanced weaponry like Stinger missiles and infantry vehicles, is seen as vital in addressing the gaps caused by months of delay. Ukrainian President Zelenskyy welcomed the support, while the Kremlin condemned it, warning of consequences. In addition to aid for Ukraine, the bill includes provisions affecting Israel, Taiwan, and a requirement for TikTok's parent company to divest its U.S. operations. Biden and his administration have underscored the significance of aiding Ukraine, highlighting the potential ramifications of inaction on NATO cohesion and regional stability. Zelenskyy expressed gratitude for the support, emphasizing the need to counter Putin's influence for the preservation of freedom.

The US House of Representatives has approved a $60.84 billion security aid package for Ukraine, with $23 billion allocated for replenishing US weapons and facilities. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov warns that the decision could exacerbate destruction and loss of life 

Instagram Caption: The US House of Representatives has approved a $60.84 billion security aid package for Ukraine, with $23 billion allocated for replenishing US weapons and facilities. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov warns that the decision could exacerbate destruction and loss of life in the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. Russia is concerned about provisions that allow the confiscation of Russian assets to fund Ukraine's reconstruction efforts. Critics, such as former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev, argue that the aid is motivated by Russophobia and benefits the US military-industrial complex. Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova cautions that this assistance could deepen global crises, particularly in Taiwan and Israel.

"Russia-Ukraine Unveiled" is going to put a spotlight on the issue by offering a balanced viewpoint. In a situation likely to be accompanied by discrimination and agitation, Dr. Thomas bravely handles the narrative by presenting a balanced side of the whole story. Despite the difficulty of the issue and the complexity and contradictory aspects of the relationship, he does not fall into either generalization or simplistic narratives. Rather he invites people to dive deeper and came up with your irrefutable views.

Apart from that, the writer not only analyzes but also tells the story in a way that is attention-grabbing and clear. He does not drench his readers with statistics and fact-piles but weaves stories which humanize the conflict making people able to empathize and relate to the subject on a personal level. Through this method it becomes more readable and empathy creation get also rise and it is very vital in such theme.

The book not only provides great analysis but is a sign of Dr. Thomas's dedication to both education and philanthropy. Through his words, he communicates his zeal for making people know more. His readers are encouraged to experience the topic further, and to utilize analytical thinking skills in addressing the issues.

Briefly, "Russia-Ukraine Unveiled" is an outstanding exhibit of intricate geopolitical position. Dr. Joseph K. Thomas's knowledge and his gripping narrative style provide the main reasons why this book belongs in the reading list of everyone who wants to know more about the Russian-Ukrainian relations on a global level. It is an eloquent demonstration of the strength of the human intellect and its capacity to take on not only the intricacy but the changing environment of our world.

I met my friends from Russia (Saint Petersburg) in Hong Kong after so many years. They made my stay in Russia in 2017 so beautiful that, to date, it's my favorite country to travel to.
It was not easy to hear from them about the impact of war on people's lives in Russia.
War is never suitable for anyone!
So before you pick any side, listen to people from both sides and what war did to them.
I have visited both the countries #Russia and #Ukraine, and I have excellent friends from both countries, and I sincerely feel their pain. I can't pick any side; all I want is this war to end and we all live in peace and harmony... Is it too much to ask?

"Russia-Ukraine Unveiled" by Dr. Joseph K Thomas is a compelling book that takes us through the history, complexities, and current relations of the two nations: Russia and Ukraine. 

The book presents facts and paints a vivid picture of the two nations and their struggles. Russia and Ukraine's conflict have affected the whole world, and this book made me aware of many such aspects. I appreciate Dr. Joseph's narration, which kept me hooked, and the descriptions that offered rich insights. 

Dr. Joseph's writing style is engaging and easy to understand, making complex issues and topics accessible. 

"Russia-Ukraine Unveiled" is a well-researched book and a must-read for anyone interested in history, politics, or simply curious to know more about the world.

Since the unification of Yemen in 1990 the political, economic and military leadership was dominated by the Northerners which resulted in continuous conflicts. They however continued to work together in the fight against Al Qaeda and Houthis.

The failure of President Hadi against Al Qaeda and Houthis encouraged the revival of a long suppressed secessionist movement in Southern Yemen, Al-Hirak al-Janoubi commonly called Hirak.

In 2018, the Separatists occupied the government at Aden in a coup d‚Äô√©tat against the Hadi government and in April 2020 declared self-rule in Aden, saying it would govern the port city and southern provinces.

So in effect Yemen is now governed by three separate entities, Houthis in North Yemen, STC and Hadi faction in Southern part of Yemen. Apart from this in many of the areas of tribal hinterland, Al Qaeda is running its writ.

The recent drone attack on Ukraine's Zaporizhzhia power plant, a critical nuclear facility with six reactors, has intensified fears of a potential catastrophic nuclear accident, as cautioned by the UN's atomic watchdog, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). Tensions between Russia and Ukraine have reached a critical point, with both sides trading accusations regarding the attack. While Russia alleges Ukrainian involvement, Ukraine vehemently denies any responsibility. The IAEA's Director General, Rafael Grossi, described the drone strike as reckless and a significant escalation in the already precarious situation surrounding nuclear safety and security at the plant. The Zaporizhzhia facility, located in southern Ukraine, holds the distinction of being the largest nuclear power plant in Europe. Since the full-scale invasion by Russian forces in February 2022, the plant has been under Russian control. Despite assurances from the plant's administration that radiation levels remain within acceptable limits and that there is no substantial damage, the IAEA has expressed concerns about the potential impact on the integrity of the reactor's containment system. This incident underscores the grave risks posed by the ongoing conflict and the imperative of safeguarding nuclear facilities to prevent a potentially catastrophic outcome.

üìå In the dead of night in May, Russia launched a Kinzhal hypersonic missile at the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv, reaching speeds up to Mach 10 (about 7,700 mph). The U.S. had sent a Patriot air defense system to Ukraine to counter Russian missiles, successfully intercepting the Kinzhal missile and others. The Patriot system has demonstrated its capabilities by intercepting Russian aircraft and missiles in Ukraine. The U.S. Army is planning to replace the Patriot system with an Integrated Air and Missile Defense system, but the Patriot‚Äôs recent success has attracted global interest.
