Overnight and into Saturday, Russian missile strikes in Ukraine claimed the lives of eight individuals and left 12 others wounded, officials reported.

In the city of Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest, six people were killed and 11 wounded in missile attacks overnight, damaging residential areas, a gas station, a kindergarten, a cafe, a shop, and vehicles, according to Oleh Syniehubov, the governor of the Kharkiv region. Additionally, a further strike on Kharkiv on Saturday afternoon resulted in one more casualty, confirmed Kharkiv mayor Ihor Terekhov. Meanwhile, in the southern Odesa region, a civilian was killed in another missile strike, as reported by its governor, Oleh Kiper.

According to Ukraine's air force commander, Russia launched 32 Iranian-made Shahed drones and six missiles overnight. Ukrainian air defense forces managed to intercept three cruise missiles and 28 drones, stated Lt. Gen. Mykola Oleshchuk, adding, "Russian killers continue to terrorize Ukrainians and attack Kharkiv and other peaceful cities."

Former U.S. President Donald Trump created controversy by his statement that he could end Russia - Ukraine War by pressuring Ukraine to surrender territory to Russia. 

According to a report by the Washington Post, Trump believes that Crimea and the Donbas border regions, areas of significant contention, should be surrendered to Russia to cease hostilities.

Trump has repeated said that he can halt the controversy between Russia and Ukraine within a day.

La presidente del Consiglio Giorgia Meloni, durante la riunione del Consiglio dei ministri a palazzo Chigi, ha annunciato l‚Äôindicazione di Raffaele Fitto come commissario europeo. ‚ÄúOggi stesso comunicher√≤ alla presidente von der Leyen il nome‚Äù di Fitto come commissario europeo ‚Äúe chiedo a tutti di rivolgere un applauso e un grande in bocca al lupo a Raffaele, che avr√† davanti un compito estremamente complesso e allo stesso tempo entusiasmante‚Äù, ha detto Meloni in cdm definendola ‚Äúuna scelta dolorosa per me, credo anche per lui, e per il governo, ma √® una scelta necessaria‚Äú. ‚ÄúSi tratta ‚Äì ha aggiunto ‚Äì di una scelta delicata e molto importante per noi e per l‚ÄôItalia nei prossimi anni. La nostra scelta ricade su una persona che ha una grandissima esperienza e che ha saputo governare le deleghe che gli sono state affidate in questo governo con ottimi risultati‚Äù.

Prima del cdm sempre a Palazzo Chigi si √® tenuto il¬†vertice di maggioranza¬†tra la presidente del Consiglio, Giorgia Meloni, i vice e segretari di Forza Italia e Lega¬†Antonio Tajani¬†e¬†Matteo Salvini, e il leader di Noi moderati¬†Maurizio Lupi. Una riunione durata¬†pi√π di tre ore.¬†Durante il vertice ‚Äúi leader hanno rinnovato il patto di coalizione, garanzia di efficacia e concretezza dell‚Äôazione di governo. Un bilancio positivo sostenuto da¬†dati macroeconomici incoraggianti, a partire dal buon andamento della crescita dell‚Äôoccupazione‚Äú, si legge nella nota congiunta. Comunicato che ha provocato anche qualche problema:¬†la nota diffusa dalla Lega infatti conteneva una frase relativa alla contrariet√† del governo ‚Äúa ogni ipotesi di interventi militari fuori dai confini ucraini‚Äú.

 Riferimento modificato, nella nota ufficiale, con la formula ‚ÄúCondivisione sulla posizione del governo italiano relativamente alla guerra in Ucraina‚Äú. ‚ÄúPer la fretta‚Äú, ha fatto sapere la Lega, √® stata diffusa ‚Äúuna¬†versione del comunicato che poi √® stata modificata‚Äú.

How you can support Ukraine

As the war in Ukraine keeps raging, the humanitarian toll keeps mounting. The United Nations reports roughly 14 million people have been forced to flee their homes since the start of the Russian invasion. Scores of global nonprofits have responded to the crisis, delivering desperately needed aid to Ukrainians who have fled abroad and those who remain in the war-torn country. The NGOs include GlobalGiving ‚Äî which has raised more than $48 million to provide shelter, water and economic assistance to refugees ‚Äî and the International Committee of the Red Cross, which is providing medical equipment and emergency supplies and aiding civilian evacuation efforts.
 
Looking for more nonprofits helping out on the ground? Here is a list of organizations aiding Ukraine:

As reported by Anadolu, a senior Palestinian official ruled out the prospect of Middle East peace as long as Israel occupies the Palestinian territory.

Mahmoud al-Habbash, the chief Sharia judge of the Palestinian Authority and advisor to President Mahmoud Abbas on matters religious and Islamic, stated at the 20th International Muslim Forum on Saturday in Moscow, Russia, that "there will be no peace as long as Palestine is under Israeli occupation."

Al-Habbash stated that although more than 120 countries have supported UN resolutions on Palestine, they have not yet been put into effect.

As reported by the Anadolu Agency, the health system in the area has been severely damaged by the ongoing, lethal Israeli bombardment on Gaza, particularly in the northern section of the country.

The Al-Shifa Hospital's core blood bank was destroyed after 350 days of nonstop shelling, making it practically impossible to supply the critically needed blood needed by the sick and injured Palestinians.

This situation is made worse by the fact that even individuals who would be ready to donate blood are unable to do so because of malnourishment brought on by the region's prevalent hunger.

Concerned about possible threats to a Turkish vessel performing energy research and exploration in Somali waters, Turkiye is apparently preparing to send frigates there to defend it.

Turkiye is reportedly exercising extreme caution when it comes to the safety of its "Oruc Reis" vessel, especially because it is meant to operate in open waters off the coast of Somalia, according to a report by Middle East Eye that quoted two people with knowledge of the situation.

The vessel is scheduled to carry out a 3D seismic survey in the region, which Turkish Energy Minister Alparslan Bayraktar stated last week "had never been done before." Turkish Petroleum holds a license for three areas in Somali waters, each field covering 5,000 square kilometers.

An Israeli airstrike killed at least five people in the West Bank city of Tubas, Palestinian emergency services said, as Israeli forces continued an operation targeting Iranian-backed militant groups. The strike was part of a series of operations in the northern West Bank, where violence has surged since the start of the war in Gaza. Palestinian health authorities report over 680 Palestinians killed in the West Bank since October 7, including fighters and unarmed civilians. The Israeli military says the operations aim to counter terrorism, but critics argue they only fuel more violence and instability.

Germany has suspended new war weapon sales to Israel while it resolves legal challenges, a source close to the Economy Ministry and a Reuters data analysis reveals.

According to data from the Economy Ministry, which authorizes export licenses, Germany authorized arms exports to Israel last year totaling 326.5 million Euros ($363.5 million), including military hardware and weaponry. This represents a ten-fold increase from 2022.

But this year, permissions have decreased; from January to August 21, only 14.5 million euros' worth of approvals were given, according to statistics that the Economy Ministry gave in response to a parliamentary query.

Moscow has blocked access to 81 Western media sites from 25 EU nations, accusing them of spreading false information about its "special military operation" in Ukraine. The term "war" or "invasion" is criminalized in Russia. This move follows the EU's decision in May to ban four Russian media outlets, which Brussels labelled as Kremlin propaganda. The blocked Western outlets include AFP, Der Spiegel, El Pais, and state broadcasters from Austria, Ireland, and Italy. Politico was also banned. European Commission Vice President Vera Jourova condemned Moscow's action as "nonsense" on social media.

Russia's Foreign Ministry stated that the ban would be reconsidered if the EU lifted its Russian media restrictions, which they described as politically motivated. The escalation in media restrictions comes amid heightened tensions following Russia's 2022 invasion of Ukraine. Many Western media organizations had already withdrawn staff from Russia to avoid repercussions under new laws against "discrediting" the Russian military. The latest ban coincides with the espionage trial of Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, who has been detained for a year. Russia's ranking on the Press Freedom Index remains low, with frequent reports of journalists being jailed, harassed, or killed.
Source: AFP, AP, Reuters

So what
Russia is well aware that they are currently in an information war, and they have a long history of using propaganda dating back to before the soviet revolution. While the internet has allowed people to get their media from various sources, it has also allowed state actors to flood the information space with competing narratives to sow confusion (one of Russia's favoured tactics). It is possible that this move comes due to Western governments finally taking note of the information war and looking to put more effort into winning it. Additionally, it is likely that as the conflict in Ukraine drags on, Russians have looked for alternative narratives around what is happening, something the Kremlin will want to subdue.

Hamas Picks New Boss: Because Even Terrorist Groups Need New Management Sometimes
*
Over the past week, top Hamas leaders gathered in Qatar to pick a new political head after Ismail Haniyeh was killed. They arrived from across the Middle East, some still shaken after fighting Israel in Gaza. Haniyeh, the group's previous leader, died in a blast in Tehran allegedly by Israel. Talk about a hostile takeover!

At the mourning ceremony in Doha, leaders lined up to pay their respects, but really, they were eyeing his vacant position. One man stood out‚ÄîAbu Omar Hassan, head of Hamas's Supreme Shura Council. No, he's not a Bond villain...yet.

After two days of intense meetings, they went with Yahya Sinwar, who‚Äôs been leading Hamas in Gaza since 2017. He's close to the militant wing‚Äîbasically, he's their LinkedIn top candidate. Israel believes he planned attacks on southern Israel and now he's top of their hit list. Some Hamas leaders wanted a more moderate leader, but apparently, extremism got the majority vote.

'Chinese reactions to Modi‚Äôs visit to Ukraine reflect a range of perspectives. 

One analysis provided three key reasons for Modi‚Äôs Ukraine visit. First, it suggests that Modi‚Äôs visit aligns with a utilitarian approach to diplomacy: while Russia offers valuable resources and technology to India, the West provides markets and investment opportunities. Thus, Modi‚Äôs trip can be seen as part of a strategic effort to balance these interests.

Second, by engaging directly with Ukraine and trying to mediate the conflict, Modi aims to bolster his image as a prominent global leader, enhancing India‚Äôs stature on the world stage.

Third, the visit is viewed through the lens of competition with China. The commentary highlighted that India‚Äôs desire to match China‚Äôs diplomatic moves is evident, especially following Beijing‚Äôs recent invitation to Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dymtro Kuleba. Modi‚Äôs visit, announced shortly after Kuleba‚Äôs departure from China on 26 July, seems strategically timed to capitalise on this competitive dynamic.'

Link in bio to complete column by Sana Hashmi, fellow at Taiwan-Asia Exchange Foundation.

"It is horrified by the unfolding pattern of Israeli strikes on schools in Gaza, killing internally displaced Palestinians seeking shelter there," the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) stated yesterday.

"Strikes on at least 17 schools just in the last month reportedly killed at least 163 Palestinians, including children and women," the OHCHR noted in a statement.

"At least seven schools were targeted in the last eight days," the UN Human Rights Office continued. which served as both a field hospital and a place of refuge for the displaced people at Khadija School.

Tensions in the Middle East are at a breaking point as Israeli airstrikes have targeted multiple locations in Gaza, killing a senior rescue service official, and in Syria, where 14 people have lost their lives. 

The escalating violence has extended to Jordan, where an armed assailant fatally shot three security guards at the King Hussein (Allenby) Bridge border crossing. In response, Israel has closed all border crossings with Jordan, heightening fears of further regional instability. This surge in violence marks a critical point in the ongoing conflict, with broader implications for neighboring countries and peace efforts in the region.

According to Reuters, Saudi Arabia's Dunya Abu Talib defeated Israel's Abishag Semberg in the women's flyweight taekwondo round of 16 at the Olympic Games in Paris today.

After winning 2-6 5-4 10-0, Abu Talib‚Äîthe first Saudi woman to receive straight qualification to the Olympics‚Äîfinished the match with two head and two body kicks.

The spectators cheered both fighters on with loud voices.

Semberg expressed her disappointment with her performance, citing the significance of representing Israel on the world's largest sporting platform.

One of Gaza's last functioning hospitals has been emptying out in recent days as Israel has ordered the evacuation of nearby areas and signaled a possible ground operation in a town that has been largely spared throughout the war, officials said Monday.

The Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah is the main hospital serving central Gaza. The Israeli military has not ordered its evacuation, but patients and people sheltering there fear that it may be engulfed in fighting or become the target of a raid.

At a Yad Binyamin conference organized by Israel Hayom today, Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich declared that halting humanitarian aid to the Gaza Strip might be ‚Äújustified and moral,‚Äù even if it means that two million Palestinians will go hungry.

"We are importing aid because we have nowhere else to go. In the world we live in today, we are unable to conduct a war. Until our captives are released, no one will allow us to inflict the deaths of two million civilians from hunger, even though it could be morally and legally justified. It is morally acceptable to swap humanitarianism for humanitarianism, but how can we act? We need worldwide legitimacy for this conflict because we are living in a specific context today," he declared.

In the men's javelin throw final of the Paris Olympics 2024, top athlete Arshad Nadeem broke the Olympic record with a throw of 92.97 meters, helping Pakistan win its first Olympic gold medal in forty years.

Pakistan last won gold in 1984 and had not won a medal at the Games since 1992. The hockey squad took home these two medals.

Another person was identified by a relative as one of the leaders of al-Quds Brigades, the armed wing of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad group.

The Israeli military said the car contained a ‚Äúterrorist squad‚Äù that was on its way to carry out an attack, without providing evidence.

A few hours later, a second air attack on a vehicle in Bal‚Äôa, east of Tulkarem, killed four people, according to Wafa news agency.

Shortly after the initial attack, Israeli forces launched raids in Tulkarem, resulting in confrontations with Palestinian fighters. Israeli forces also fired tear gas at journalists who were covering the raid.

What Happened: Turkey to submit declaration to International Court of Justice intervening in South Africa's case against Israel over alleged genocide in Gaza.

What you need to know: Turkey will submit a declaration to the International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Wednesday, intervening in a case against Israel regarding alleged genocide in Gaza. The declaration aims to bring attention to the humanitarian crisis in Gaza and support South Africa's case. 

More: Turkey's move follows Spain's similar intervention in June. Israel has denied the genocide accusations, claiming its actions in Gaza are self-defense measures targeting Hamas militants. The ICJ, established in 1945, will consider the declarations as it reviews the case. 

Also: Turkey's foreign minister announced the move, which comes after Turkey increased measures against Israel over the Gaza assault. The submission will take place at 1330 GMT on Wednesday.

Report By: News Desk

New course topic coming fall 2024! This fall, HIST 153 will feature an additional theme: Israel, Palestine, and Christianity: A Historical Perspective.

In this 2-hr half-semester core humanities course, Professor Martin Spence and his students will explore the historical roots of the Israel-Palestine conflict. Topics covered include the decline of the Ottoman Empire, the development of Jewish and Arab nationalism, the two World Wars, British imperialism, and the causes, character, and consequences of the foundation of the modern state of Israel in 1948. The class will also explore the historical forces that have shaped western Christian perspectives on the topic, including Christian Zionism, end times theology, and religious nationalism.

This course is being offered for both the first and second halves of the semester. Register soon‚Äîseats are limited!

Russia has strongly condemned the killing of a senior Hamas leader, calling it a "political murder" and a "gross violation of international law". The Russian Foreign Ministry stated that the killing was a deliberate attack on a political figure and a blatant disregard for Palestinian sovereignty.

The Hamas leader, who was not named, was killed in an Israeli airstrike on Gaza. Israel has not commented on the incident, but it is believed to have been a targeted killing. Russia's condemnation of the attack reflects its support for the Palestinian cause and its criticism of Israel's actions in the region.

Russia's Foreign Ministry also called for an international investigation into the killing, stating that those responsible must be held accountable. The ministry expressed its condolences to the family of the deceased and the Palestinian people, and reiterated its support for a comprehensive and just settlement to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

The incident has sparked widespread outrage and condemnation from across the globe, with many countries and organizations calling for restraint and an end to the cycle of violence in the region. The killing has also raised tensions between Israel and Hamas, which has vowed to retaliate for the attack.

With the fall of the Ottoman Empire, the League of Nations assigned Palestine to a British mandate in 1920. This 1935 Palestine coin features ‚ÄúPalestine‚Äù written in British Mandate Palestine‚Äôs three official languages: English, Arabic, and Hebrew. Article 22 of the 1922 Palestine Mandate states: ‚ÄúAny statement or inscription in Arabic on stamps or money in Palestine shall be repeated in Hebrew, and any statement or inscription in Hebrew shall be repeated in Arabic.‚Äù The British administration at times supported creating a ‚Äúnational home‚Äù in Palestine for Jewish people as stated in the 1917 Balfour Declaration. This support was echoed in the language choices the British Mandate enforced on the coins.

Rocket Attack in Israel‚Äôs Golan Heights Kills 12: Tensions Escalate

On July 27, 2024, a rocket fired from Lebanon struck a soccer field in Majdal Shams, a Druze town in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, killing 12 children and teenagers. The attack, described as the deadliest on civilians since October 7, 2023, has heightened fears of a broader regional conflict, as reported by AP. 

The Israeli military reported that the rocket caused extensive damage and that 20 others were injured. Residents described the scene as horrific, with many expressing a deep sense of loss and anger. Israeli officials are investigating why the rocket was not intercepted by defense systems.

In response, Israel has conducted airstrikes on targets in Lebanon, marking an escalation in the ongoing cross-border conflict with Hezbollah. Despite these strikes, Hezbollah has denied responsibility for the attack, while the U.S. and Israeli officials point to indications that it was involved.

The incident comes amid stalled negotiations for a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas in Gaza. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has vowed that Hezbollah will face severe consequences. The Israeli security cabinet is deliberating on further actions, while international efforts, led by the U.S. and Egypt, are pushing for de-escalation.

This escalation threatens to further destabilize the region, already tense from the ongoing Gaza conflict and frequent border skirmishes. The White House National Security Council is engaging with Israeli and Lebanese counterparts to seek a diplomatic resolution and prevent further violence.

British Prime Minister Keir Starmer met with Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani in Paris on Saturday, according to a statement from 10 Downing Street.

The two leaders recalled their meetings from December when Starmer visited Qatar as opposition leader.

"The two leaders pledged to build on the existing partnership, particularly in areas of mutual opportunity including education, business and energy," according to a statement.

"The transition to clean energy and the opportunities it brings for jobs, lower bills, and energy security was discussed extensively," according to the statement.

Israeli Army Steps Up Attacks Across Gaza Strip

The Israeli army is intensifying its attacks across the Gaza Strip. In the past hour, new airstrikes have targeted the northern part of the Nuseirat refugee camp, located in central Gaza.

One Palestinian has been killed in an attack on a residential flat. The assault caused extensive destruction to the residential tower that was targeted, leaving many residents in despair.

The eastern areas of the Bureij refugee camp, also in central Gaza, are now under bombardment. Civil defense crews report they are unable to access the area due to the presence of Israeli ground forces, further complicating rescue efforts and aid delivery.

Amid the ongoing Israel-Palestine conflict, Hamas chief Ismail Haniyeh and one of his bodyguards have been killed in Tehran.

Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) has confirmed the killings in a statement.
The statement adds that Ismail Haniyeh, the leader of the Islamist group Hamas that runs the Palestinian territory of Gaza, was "assassinated."

"With condolences to the heroic nation of Palestine and the Islamic nation and combatants of the Resistant Front and the noble nation of Iran, this morning [Wednesday] the residence of Ismail Haniyeh, the head of the political office of the Islamic Resistance of Hamas, was hit in Tehran, and following this incident, he and one of his bodyguards were martyred," the IRGC statement read.

The Islamist outfit has blamed Israel and claimed that Haniyeh was killed in a "treacherous Zionist raid on his residence in Tehran." The group said an investigation is ongoing to find out more details about the attack.

Dia menegaskan bahwa AS tidak akan tinggal diam terhadap penderitaan yang dialami oleh rakyat Palestina.

Harris mengkritik pendekatan Presiden Joe Biden yang mendukung Israel dan menyoroti penderitaan yang terjadi di Gaza selama sembilan bulan terakhir. Dia menggambarkan gambar anak-anak yang tewas dan orang-orang yang putus asa serta kelaparan yang terus berusaha melarikan diri demi keselamatan. Harris menegaskan bahwa dunia tidak bisa berpaling dari tragedi ini dan bahwa dia tidak akan tinggal diam.

Dalam pertemuan tersebut, Harris menekankan kepada Netanyahu tentang skala penderitaan manusia di Gaza dan kematian warga sipil yang tidak bersalah. Dia juga menyatakan keprihatinan serius tentang situasi kemanusiaan di sana. Selain itu, Harris menyerukan gencatan senjata antara Israel dan Hamas serta pembebasan sandera untuk mengakhiri perang yang dimulai pada Oktober 2023.

Pernyataan Harris ini sangat berbeda dengan pendekatan ramah antara Biden dan Netanyahu sebelumnya. Sikap tegas Harris menunjukkan bahwa dia mungkin mengambil pendekatan yang lebih keras terhadap Israel dibandingkan Biden. Harris juga mengutuk anti-Semitisme, Islamofobia, dan segala bentuk kebencian, serta menyerukan persatuan dalam menghadapi situasi ini.

Menurut Kementerian Kesehatan Gaza, sebanyak 39.175 warga tewas karena serangan Israel, dengan 90.000 \orang lainnya terluka. Harris menyampaikan bahwa gencatan senjata dan bantuan kemanusiaan sangat dibutuhkan untuk mengurangi penderitaan warga sipil yang tidak bersalah di Gaza.

Multiple rockets were launched at Iraq's Ain Al-Asad Air Base, which houses US-led forces, late yesterday, according to US and Iraqi sources. No damage or deaths were reported, according to Reuters.

Two US officials stated that the base itself was not targeted in the attack.

The incident occurred two days after a military summit in Washington, where Iraqi and US officials discussed winding down the coalition's operations a decade after it was created to combat Daesh in Iraq and Syria.

There was no dramatic statement at the end of the negotiations, but US and Iraqi sources suggest it will begin to wind down gradually in the coming weeks.

Nel suo libro, Srour esplora l‚Äôessenza dell‚Äôamore e della resistenza attraverso le sue esperienze di prigionia nelle carceri israeliane. Arrestato nel 1993 e condannato all'ergastolo, Srour trasforma il muro della sua cella nel simbolo di un dialogo paradossale, all‚Äôapparenza impossibile.

Diviso in due parti, il libro narra inizialmente la storia di Srour e della sua famiglia, riflettendo sulle sofferenze dei profughi palestinesi e sulle lotte della Prima Intifada. Nella seconda parte, invece, ci immergiamo nella sua intensa relazione epistolare con Nanna, un amore che sfida le barriere fisiche e temporali, valicando le anguste mura carcerarie.

L‚Äôappassionato racconto di Abu Srour non si riduce al solo memoir, ma √® anche un profondo trattato filosofico che intreccia politica, storia e letteratura, offrendo una visione unica del conflitto israelo-palestinese e della resilienza umana in condizioni estreme. Un libro che invita a riflettere su come l‚Äôamore possa realmente trascendere ogni limite, facendosi mezzo privilegiato di liberazione.

Che ne pensate di questo aforisma di Nasser Abu Srour? Ha colto il senso e la pienezza dell‚Äôesperienza amorosa?

Hamas chief Ismail Haniyeh was killed in an attack on his residence in Tehran, confirmed by Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC).

If Israel is blamed for this, Hamas could significantly escalate its response. This comes right after Israel struck the capital of Lebanon to target Hezbollah.

It creates a leadership vacuum in Hamas as no successor has been announced yet.

In April, his video of reacting to the deaths of three of his sons and other relatives in an Israeli airstrike went viral after he said they were 'awarded this honour.'

Hamas chief Ismail Haniyeh and one of his bodyguards were killed after their residence was targeted in Tehran, confirmed by IRGC in a statement.

Haniyeh had attended the inauguration of Iran's new president and met Iran's Supreme Leader the day before the attack.

‚Ä¢ The attack on Haniyeh's residence is being investigated, and results will be announced later in the day.

‚Ä¢ The IRGC's Public Relations Department stated that the attack was carried out early Wednesday, and a probe is underway to find the cause of the incident.

‚Ä¢ The IRGC extended condolences to the people of Palestine, the Muslim world, and the Resistance Front's fighters.

‚ÄúThe myth of Israel as a democracy has no factual basis, yet it, too, has become an indisputable fact. Israel has from the very beginning defined itself as a racist apartheid state that prefers Jews. No attempt has been made to hide this fact, and for almost seven decades Israeli lawmakers have made it their business to develop the state for the Jewish population at the expense of the Palestinian population, be they citizens, residents or simply people living without any legal definition at all. Palestinians have been pushed out of every aspect of the life of the state from the very beginning, not to mention the fact that they were pushed out of the country and not allowed to return. The web of laws that govern the lives of Palestinians, whether they live in Jaffa, Haifa, Jerusalem, the Naqab desert, Ramallah, Jenin or Khan Younis, is too complicated to even attempt to understand, yet regardless of where in Palestine Palestinians reside, they are governed by the state of Israel under laws that are vastly different than the ones that govern the lives of Jewish Israelis.‚Äù
--Miko Peled

Stop then and there!

You may be in some place when suddenly you have a thought of Teshuvah and a deep longing for God. Stop then and there in that very place and take a moment to focus on the thought and the feeling of longing. Turn them into a prayer. Put your longing into words straight from your heart. Don't wait or move on, even if you are not in your usual place of prayer and study - even if you are going on your way - because if you move on, it could interrupt your train of thought.

Likutey Moharan II, 124

JERUSALEM: Facing intense pressure to quickly cut a ceasefire deal with Hamas in Gaza, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is to deliver a landmark speech to the US Congress on Wednesday.

While Netanyahu will become the first foreign leader to address a joint meeting of the two chambers four times, pulling ahead of Britain‚Äôs Winston Churchill on three, an expected meeting between Netanyahu and US President Joe Biden is still not confirmed.

Publicly, Biden has voiced strong support for Israel, but he expressed concern over an offensive on the southern city of Rafah in May and for a while suspended deliveries of heavy bombs to Israel.

‚ÄúNever before has the atmosphere been so fraught,‚Äù said Council on Foreign Relations Middle East specialist Steven Cook. ‚ÄúThere is clearly tension in the relationship, especially between the White House and the Israeli prime minister,‚Äù Cook said in a commentary.
One Jewish senator, Democrat Brian Schatz of Hawaii, announced he would boycott Wednesday‚Äôs speech, saying he would not listen to ‚Äúpolitical rhetoric that will do nothing to bring peace in the region‚Äù.

On July 19, the International Court of Justice found Israel‚Äôs occupation of Palestinian territories ‚Äúillegal‚Äù, months after it called for the country to stop genocide in Gaza.

The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) committee saw India articulate a neutral stance, refraining from taking sides in the Israel-Palestine conflict. Palestine issued a strong condemnation of Israel, accusing it of bombing refugee camps and hospitals, and called for adherence to international law. In response, Israel asserted that Hamas is exploiting civilian groups. Denmark voiced support for a humanitarian ceasefire, emphasizing the urgent need to address the humanitarian crisis. The debate highlighted the complex dynamics of the ongoing conflict, with nations expressing diverse perspectives on the situation. As discussions continue, the committee seeks to navigate these challenging issues while working towards a resolution that prioritizes civilian safety and international cooperation.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's combative speech to the US Congress sparked protests and highlighted divisions in American society over the Gaza war.

Kamala Harris, believed to be the Democrats' presidential candidate did not attend Netanyahu's speech, signaling solidarity with the protesters, which would be a tricky position for the Democrats' foreign policy, if she were to win the elections.
She was attending a campaign rally in Indiana instead.

Netanyahu emphasized the close ties between the US and Israel, calling for unity in their fight against Hamas and other Iran-backed groups.

His speech was met with applause from many lawmakers but also boycotts by over 60 Democrats and political independent Bernie Sanders, as per News18.

Netanyahu did not directly address ongoing US-led mediation for a cease-fire and hostage-release, showing no eagerness for such a deal.

Meanwhile, Thousands of protesters gathered near the Capitol, calling for a ceasefire and condemning Netanyahu, with some protesters burning the American flag too.

Sheikh Mohammed Bin Zayed, the president of the United Arab Emirates (UAE), declared that his nation supports any efforts and solutions aimed at putting an end to the escalation between the parties in Sudan.

This occurred during the first phone conversation between Bin Zayed and Lieutenant General Abdel Fattah Al-Burhan, the chair of the Sudanese Sovereignty Council, since tensions between the two nations arose due to Sudan's accusations that the UAE was supporting the Rapid Support Forces (RSF).

The president of the United Arab Emirates and the head of the Sudanese Sovereignty Council spoke about their countries' bilateral ties, recent changes in the country's circumstances, and strategies for helping Sudan get out of its current predicament.

The Israeli army attacked the Nuseirat refugee camp in the central Gaza Strip 63 times in a week, killing at least 91 people and injured 251, local officials claimed on Sunday.

The Nuseirat refugee camp is one of Gaza's most densely populated, with 250,000 residents and displaced refugees.

üìå Adidas recently launched a campaign featuring model Bella Hadid to promote the relaunch of their classic SL72 sneaker, which was originally released in 1972 - the same year as the Munich Olympics. However, this collaboration has sparked significant backlash due to the tragic events that occurred at those Olympics.

üìå In 1972, Palestinian militants from the group Black September attacked and killed 11 Israeli athletes during the Munich Olympics. Bella Hadid, who is of Palestinian descent, has been an outspoken critic of Israel's actions in Gaza. Her involvement in promoting a shoe tied to the Munich massacre has angered many, including the American Jewish Committee (AJC) and the Israeli government.

üìå The AJC stated that Adidas' choice of Hadid, a "vocal anti-Israel model," to represent a shoe commemorating the Munich Olympics was either a "massive oversight or intentionally inflammatory." Israel's Foreign Ministry accused Hadid of "spreading antisemitism and calling for violence against Israelis and Jews."

üìå In response to the backlash, Adidas issued an apology, stating: "We are conscious that connections have been made to tragic historical events - though these are completely unintentional - and we apologize for any upset or distress caused. As a result we are revising the remainder of the campaign."

üìå The company also emphasized its belief in sport as a unifying force and its commitment to championing diversity and equality. However, the incident has highlighted the ongoing tensions and sensitivities surrounding the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, even in the context of sports and advertising.

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) has issued a significant advisory opinion declaring Israel's presence in the Palestinian territories illegal. 

This ruling, released on July 19, 2024, emphasizes that Israel must cease its occupation and dismantle settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which the court deems violations of international law. 

The ICJ's opinion stems from a request by the UN General Assembly following a Palestinian initiative.

KEY FINDINGS OF THE ICJ RULING:

üìå ILLEGAL OCCUPATION: The court stated that Israel's ongoing presence in the Palestinian territories is "unlawful" and must be ended "AS RAPIDLY AS POSSIBLE." It highlighted various policies, including the expansion of settlements and discriminatory practices against Palestinians, as breaches of international law.

üìå CALL FOR REPARATIONS: The ICJ also called for Israel to provide reparations for damages inflicted on individuals in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, although the specifics of these reparations remain to be determined. This includes RESTITUTION, COMPENSATION, AND SATISFACTION FOR THE AFFECTED INDIVIDUALS.

üìå GLOBAL IMPLICATIONS: The ruling urges all nations to collaborate with the UN to address Israel's illegal presence and uphold the Palestinian people's right to self-determination. It signals a shift in international attitudes towards the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and could influence future diplomatic relations and policies regarding Israel.

Excavation works began Wednesday in the town of Tal Afar in Mosul, northern Iraq, with the discovery of a mass grave thought to contain the remains of Turkmen victims who were all likely killed by Daesh between 2014 and 2017.

Thousands of Iraqi Turkmen families who have been missing their loved ones for years are waiting for the bodies of their relatives to be recovered from what is known as Daesh's "massacre well" locally.

The well, known locally as "Allov Anter," is about ten kilometers south of Tal Afar and plunges deeper than 100 meters. Daesh dubbed it the "Well of Hell." After capturing control of the region on June 9, 2014, Daesh allegedly killed thousands of people and disposed of their bodies in the well.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and Israeli leader Benjamin Netanyahu have thanked US lawmakers after they voted in favor of new aid packages for their countries worth billions of dollars.

This is not only morally reprehensible and in clear violation of international humanitarian law and US laws, but it has also put a target on America‚Äôs back,‚Äù they continue, arguing that it has put the lives of service members and diplomats at risk. Dr. Alon Ben-Meir, a retired professor of international relations, most recently at the Center for Global Affairs at New York University (NYU), and who taught courses on international negotiation and Middle Eastern studies, told IPS: ‚ÄúI share the overall view of the 12 US government officials who have resigned in protest against the Biden administration‚Äôs policy in connection with the Israel-Hamas war‚Äù.

They wrote in their joint statement, titled Service in Dissent, that ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs diplomatic cover for, and continuous flow of arms to Israel has ensured our undeniable complicity in the killings and forced starvation of a besieged Palestinian population in Gaza. This is not only morally reprehensible and in clear violation of international humanitarian law and US laws, but it has also put a target on America‚Äôs back.‚Äù

Tunisia‚Äôs Prime Minister urged European countries, on Wednesday, to increase financial assistance to his country and others to help tackle the flow of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, Reuters reports.

Tunisia has faced protests by local residents and extra financial costs over migrants arriving from other countries in the hope of traveling on to Europe by sea, risking perilous journeys on what, in many cases, are dilapidated boats.

Thousands of migrants are now concentrated in southern Tunisian towns such as Amra and Jbeniana, many of them fleeing poverty and conflict in Africa and the Middle East in the hope of a better life in Europe.

Digital settler colonialism, defined most recently in Kawsar Ali‚Äôs publication on the integration between technology, race, and cyberspace, is the practice of using the internet to perpetuate the legacy of settler states.

Indeed, studies hinting at digital settler colonialism date back to 1972 when Herbert I. Schiller explored the impact of digital communication tools enhancing Western cultural domination but received little press attention. Attempts to explain relationships between digital platforms and the politics of war have appeared more frequently following Wendy K. Chun‚Äôs characterization of race and technology as not cohabitating factors, but the former as a technique of the latter ‚Äì for the one that uses, it and the one used by it. 

In today‚Äôs context, Big Tech‚Äôs maintenance of the content of Israel‚Äôs latest genocide of Palestinians in Gaza via social media and beyond catches the convergence of Big Tech digital colonialism and Israeli settler colonialism, translating previous suspicions to reality.

The Islamic Resistance in Iraq has warned Arab countries, particularly Saudi Arabia, for allegedly assisting Israel in circumventing Yemen's Houthis' naval blockade of Israeli-linked cargo ships in the Red Sea, according to Lebanon's Al-Akhbar newspaper. The Houthis enforced the embargo in solidarity with Palestinians fighting the occupying state's barbaric attack in the Gaza Strip.

A member of the Hezbollah Al-Nujaba section of the resistance group informed the newspaper that Saudi Arabia has given its territory to send materials to Israel and break the Houthis' blockade. According to Firas Al-Yasser, the Islamic Resistance factions have switched their focus to the kingdom rather than its help to Israel.

At least 292 Palestinians died as a result of Israel's closure of the Rafah Crossing in the southern Gaza Strip, local authorities announced on Wednesday, according to Anadolu Agency.

"Among the victims were injured people who were supposed to receive treatment in hospitals outside Gaza, but died as they waited for the opening of the Rafah Crossing," claimed the communications office for Gaza's administration.

Since Israel's takeover of the terminal in May, the media office believes that over 3,500 patients and injured people have been denied exit through the Crossing.

The Knesset, the Israeli parliament, rejected the establishment of a Palestinian state.

The Israeli parliament passed a resolution against the two-state plan for peace in the Middle East, the first time in Israel's history that the parliament has passed such a resolution.

According to Israeli media, 68 members of parliament voted against the establishment of a Palestinian state in the resolution, while 9 members opposed the resolution.

The Knesset resolution stated that the Palestinian state would remain a threat to the existence of Israel and to Israeli citizens.

According to Israeli media, the resolution has dealt a blow to diplomatic efforts for peace in Israel and Arab countries.

Ethiopian Premier, Abiy Ahmed, met Sudan‚Äôs army chief, General Abdel Fattah Al-Burhan, on Tuesday, becoming the first foreign leader to visit him in his war capital, Port Sudan, since the start of the conflict between the army and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF), Reuters reports.

Abiy, who was previously seen as closer to the RSF than the army and hosted its leader, Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, in Addis Ababa in December, framed the visit as part of a push to bring stability to Sudan after nearly 15 months of conflict.

The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA) announced on Monday that clearing 40 million tons of war debris in Gaza will take 15 years. The estimate is based on statistics from the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP).

According to the agency, such a major clearance program will require over 100 vehicles and cost more than $500 million. It cautioned that the debris poses a "deadly threat" to Gaza Strip inhabitants because it may include "unexploded ordnance and harmful substances."

Greece recognized on Tuesday that its relations with Turkey had improved dramatically since last year.

Speaking at a public debate with former US Ambassador Daniel Speckhard at the Council on Foreign Relations, a Washington-based think tank, Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis stated that after three years of tumultuous bilateral relations, things have improved between the two NATO members.

Mitsotakis stated that, while some fundamental Turkish attitudes on the Eastern Mediterranean remain unaltered despite improved relations, "We are cooperating better in addressing irregular migration." We achieved an arrangement that allows Turkish nationals to travel to (certain) Aegean islands via a visa-easing program. These are some of the beneficial steps.

Colum McCann begleitet mich schon seit ‚ÄûDer T√§nzer‚Äú. Der Journalist schreibt unglaublich dicht erz√§hlte, aufwendig recherchierte Romane √ºber ganz unterschiedliche Themen, die mich bisher (bis auf ‚ÄûTransatlantik‚Äú) immer tief beeindruckt haben. Sie brachten mir einen russischen Ballettt√§nzer, die Erbauer der New Yorker U-Bahn, eine dichtende Roma und das New York der 1970er Jahre nahe. In seinem neusten Werk, das schon 2020 erschien, schreibt der Ire nun √ºber den israelisch-pal√§stinensischen Konflikt. Doch ein bisschen weit hergeholt? Ich finde nicht. Gerade aus der Distanz heraus gelingt es ihm, dieses Thema in unz√§hligen Facetten zu beleuchten, die einen die aktuellen Ereignisse so viel besser verstehen lassen. Neutral ist McCann dabei nicht. Durch die Stimmen seiner Protagonisten, dem Pal√§stinenser Bassam und dem Israeli Rami, √ºbermittelt er eine klare Botschaft: Sie werben f√ºr eine friedliche L√∂sung und das Ende der Besatzung.
 
Die beiden Protagonisten sind reale Personen. Beide verloren ein Kind im Konflikt und schworen daraufhin nicht etwa blutige Rache, sondern schlossen sich der Organisation ‚ÄûParents Circle‚Äú an, um die Geschichte ihrer T√∂chter publik zu machen, gegenseitiges Verst√§ndnis zwischen Juden und Arabern zu vermitteln und f√ºr das Ende der Gewalt einzutreten. Erz√§hlt wird diese Geschichte in vielen kurzen Informationsbruchst√ºcken. Der Name des Romans ist dabei Programm: ‚ÄûApeirogon‚Äú bezeichnet eine geometrische Figur mit einer nahezu unendlichen Menge Seiten. Nicht bei jedem dieser Informationsh√§ppchen wird der Zusammenhang direkt deutlich. Da ist viel von verschiedenen V√∂gelarten die Rede, private Geschichten von Politikern oder historischen Pers√∂nlichkeiten kommen zur Sprache, mathematische Lehren werden wiedergegeben. Sogar den Tunnelbauern aus ‚ÄûDer Himmel unter der Stadt‚Äú und dem Motiv des Seilt√§nzers aus ‚ÄûDie gro√üe Welt‚Äú begegnen wir wieder. 

‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è Weiter in den Kommentaren

Gerade ausgelesen.

tl;dr: Ein im wahrsten Sinne des Wortes facettenreicher, auf einer wahren Geschichte beruhender Roman √ºber den Nahostkonflikt.

President Tayyip Erdogan's abrupt decision to call his estranged Syrian counterpart, Bashar Al-Assad, for negotiations has sparked fears among Syrians in Turkey that they may be deported, a week after a wave of anti-migrant violence left many terrified, according to Reuters.

Ankara severed ties with Damascus in 2011, when Syria's civil conflict broke out and Turkish forces supported anti-Assad forces in the north. However, in the previous two weeks, Erdogan has emphasized the necessity for reconciliation with Turkey's neighbor.

On Sunday, he was quoted as saying he would invite Assad "any time" to work on resuming previous relations with Syria, which had been severed by the war that involved the US, Russia, Turkey, and several armed groups.

text:
United Nations human rights experts have accused Israel of carrying out a ‚Äútargeted starvation campaign‚Äù that has resulted in the deaths of children in Gaza.

‚ÄúIsrael‚Äôs intentional and targeted starvation campaign against the Palestinian people is a form of genocidal violence and has resulted in famine across all of Gaza,‚Äù 10 independent UN experts said in a statement on Tuesday.

Israel‚Äôs diplomatic mission to the UN in Geneva dismissed the statement and accused the experts of ‚Äúspreading misinformation‚Äù and ‚Äúsupporting Hamas propaganda‚Äù.

Gaza health authorities have said at least 33 children have died of malnutrition, mostly in northern Gaza, which had until recently faced the brunt of the Israeli military campaign launched in October.

In recent months, Israel‚Äôs ground invasion has also spread to southern Gaza, reducing aid flows into the enclave amid restrictions by Israel, which has accused UN agencies of failing to distribute supplies efficiently.

The deaths of a baby ‚Äúbarely six months old‚Äù, a nine-year-old boy and a thirteen-year-old boy since May 30 showed ‚Äúthere is no doubt that famine has spread from northern Gaza into central and southern Gaza,‚Äù the experts said.

Israeli and US officials were hopeful last week about a potential ceasefire and hostage release deal between Israel and Hamas. The Palestinian militant group indicated willingness to compromise on a key issue. However, achieving an agreement remains uncertain despite these positive developments.There is optimism that a deal could be reached, especially after a senior Hamas official told CNN that the group is open to reconsidering its demand that Israel commit to a permanent ceasefire in Gaza before agreeing to a temporary truce. This agreement would also begin the process of releasing hostages still held in Gaza.Last week, a US official mentioned to CNN that a basic agreement framework is in place, and talks resumed on Friday in Doha. Egypt‚Äôs state-affiliated Al-Qahera News channel reported that discussions will continue in Cairo this week.However, a statement from the Israeli prime minister‚Äôs office on Sunday suggested doubts about the deal's progress. The statement outlined several principles Israel is not willing to compromise on, including the continuation of military operations in Gaza until all war objectives are met.

We could have been friends: My father and I‚Äù by Raja Shehadeh is a captivating memoir that deeply resonated with me, particularly against the backdrop of current events in Gaza. Shehadeh intricately weaves together the lives of himself and his father, Aziz, offering not just a tribute to their paternal bond but also a profound exploration of the unspoken side of Palestinian history. This memoir sheds light on both personal and legal perspectives, such as the case efforts to reclaim Palestinian frozen money since 1948. It also addresses geopolitical complexities, including the actions of some Arab governments and the enduring repercussions of the Nakba. While the book is a testament of the nagging regret of his failure to understand his father, it also serves as a powerful examination of familial ties, political turmoil, and an unwavering quest for justice. Raja Shehadeh‚Äôs narrative is deeply humane and skillfully captures the resilience and struggles of the Palestinian people, making it a compelling read that leaves a lasting impression.

JULY 8
#IraqHistory 1982- Dujail is a city of 100K in central #Iraq, with its citizens being predominantly Shia Muslims. The Islamic Dawa Party, a Shia political party, had a strong presence in the town. #SaddamHussein, was a Sunni Arab had become the President of Iraq in 1979 and had ordered the invasion of #Iran, a predominantly Shia country, in Sept 1980. #OTD, Hussein visited Dujail to praise men from the village who were conscripted into the #IranIraqWar. During his motorcade‚Äôs exit from the town, a dozen Shia IDP members opened fire from the cover of the date palm orchards lining both sides of the road. Two of Hussein‚Äôs bodyguards were killed but the President was uninjured. Hussein ordered his special security and military forces to round up all suspected members of the IDP along with their families. The round-up resulted in 393 men and 394 women and children from Dujail and nearby Balad being detained. Over 40 of the detainees were killed during interrogation while another 140+ were sentenced and executed. Over 400 more were sent into exile. Following Hussein‚Äôs capture and conviction after the #IraqWar (2003-11), the dictator was hanged for crimes against humanity partially in connection with the #DujailMassacre.

#IsraelPalestineConflict 1972- Ghassan Kanafani was born in Acre, Mandatory #Palestine in 1936. At the age of 12, Kanafani‚Äôs family was forced out of their hometown during the 1948 Palestine #War. The shame Kanafani felt during this time drove his adult life. Kanafani became a political thinker, militant and journalist while also producing several novels, mostly portraying the hardship of Palestinians dispersed throughout the Middle East due to constant war. He was the first #writer to utilize ‚Äúresistance #literature‚Äù in his works from 1966 and 1968 and became considered the leading Palestinian novelist of the Arab world. OTD, Kanafani was assassinated by agents of #Israel‚Äôs #Mossad. Kanafani (and his teenage niece) was killed by a grenade
connected to the ignition switch of his car in Beirut. Israel claimed the assassination of Kanafani (a spokesperson of the PFLP) was due to the Lod Airport massacre (see 30 May).

Five members of Nahdliyin met with President Isaac Herzog in Israel. This meeting has caused significant repercussions because the Executive Board of Nahdlatul Ulama (PBNU) never gave permission for it.

PBNU Chairman Savic Ali expressed regret over the five Nahdliyin meeting with Israel's President Isaac Herzog. Savic stated that the visit by the five Nahdliyin was not in the name of NU.
"The visit was likely made in a personal capacity. We do not know their purpose or who sponsored them. This is a regrettable action," said Savic, as quoted by the official NU website, Monday (15/7/2024).

Savic assessed that the visit by the five Nahdliyin resulted from a lack of understanding of geopolitics and NU's organizational policies, as well as the sentiments of all NU members. He said PBNU does not yet know who sponsored the departure of the five Nahdliyin to Israel.
He added that although the visit was personal, the five are known as NU members and activists. This, according to Savic, worsens NU's image in the public eye. Especially since PBNU and Nahdliyin's stance is in support of Palestine and condemns Israel's military aggression.

"Israel still does not recognize Palestine and continues its military aggression, causing thousands of casualties. Israel continues to drop bombs and bullets on Palestinians. The number of victims is enormous, mostly civilians," he said.
PBNU Secretary General Saifullah Yusuf stated that they would summon the five Nahdliyin who met with Israel's President Isaac Herzog. PBNU will clarify the background of the departure of these five young figures.

"These five individuals did not receive a mandate from PBNU, nor did they ever seek permission from PBNU," he said.

Wildfires in Alberta, Canada, and BC Force Evacuations.

Wildfires raging in northern Alberta have forced evacuations of three communities, according to provincial authorities. The affected areas include John D'Or, Fox Lake, and Garden River, covering approximately 62,000 hectares and impacting 5,000 residents. Alberta is currently battling 158 wildfires, with 55 out of control.
The provincial wildfire service stated, "Fire activity is expected to remain intense throughout the weekend due to hot and dry weather." Over 200 firefighters, 10 helicopters, and 43 heavy equipment pieces are engaged in firefighting efforts, with lightning identified as the cause.

Meanwhile, British Columbia faces 319 active wildfires, prompting evacuation orders and alerts. The BC Wildfire Service reported that thunderstorms are exacerbating fire activity, with nearly a thousand firefighters deployed.

A phrase from Christopher Nolan's 2008 film The Dark Knight might be applied to many political careers: "You either die a hero, or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain." It is a warning, a shot across the bow, that perfectly captures how, in the end, hubris and complacency are intrinsic aspects of the human condition. A person in power for an extended period of time can become the polar opposite of what they previously represented. Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the President of Turkey, is a prime example of this. The recent news that he is working to normalize diplomatic relations with Bashar Assad's Syria is very disturbing.

Israel‚Äôs Organ Trafficking and Legal Immunity

Organ trafficking remains a pressing global issue, with ongoing allegations against Israel regarding the harvesting of organs from deceased Palestinians. The Euro-Med Human Rights Monitor recently accused Israeli forces of stealing organs from Palestinian bodies in Gaza, including livers, kidneys, hearts, cochleas, and corneas. Medical professionals in Gaza have corroborated these claims, despite denials from Israeli authorities.

Recent reports continue to underscore historical accusations against Israel for organ theft. Investigations have documented instances of organ harvesting from Palestinian corpses for medical research and transplants. In 2014, an Israeli television investigation revealed the extraction of skin from deceased Palestinians and African workers for medical purposes. These consistent reports indicate Israel's involvement in the global black market for human organs.

The involvement of Israeli military authorities in organ trafficking has been suggested by investigations, which indicate the participation of medical professionals and students in these activities. Despite persistent allegations and evidence, Israel denies any wrongdoing.

These allegations not only raise serious human rights concerns but also highlight broader issues regarding accountability and the rule of law. The need for international scrutiny and robust legal frameworks is evident to address these allegations impartially and ensure justice.

These ongoing challenges underscore the importance of comprehensive investigations and international cooperation to uphold human rights and the rule of law effectively.

Prince Faisal called for a two-state solution for Palestine and praised European countries that have recognized Palestine as a state. He also reiterated calls for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and humanitarian aid delivery to the population.

On Thursday last week, the US House of Representatives passed an amendment to restrict the US State Department from utilizing Gaza‚Äôs Health Ministry statistics to mention the mortality counts for Israel‚Äôs genocide in Gaza. Israel frequently claims that it has no information on the Palestinian civilians killed or injured by its bombs, preferring to focus the narrative on allegedly eradicating Hamas. The latest pro-Israel gesture by Congress, therefore, means that the State Department is now entirely implicated in trying to erase the truth of genocide from global consciousness. For Palestinians, the act is another step toward their elimination and eradication from both memory and statistics.

Judges at the International Criminal Court (ICC) concluded on Thursday that the United Kingdom can present legal reasons to judges deliberating the prosecution's request for arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, Reuters reported.

Court documents made public on Thursday showed that the UK, an ICC member state, filed a request with the Court earlier this month to provide written observations on whether "the Court can exercise jurisdiction over Israeli nationals, in circumstances where Palestine cannot exercise criminal jurisdiction over Israeli nationals (under) the Oslo Accords".

‚òÄÔ∏èKiddom Summer Camp and the Rotaract Club of Karachi Kolach joined hands to support the *"Stand with Gaza"* initiative, fostering solidarity and awareness among children. 

‚õ∫The camp featured an engaging tableau where teachers vividly illustrated the complexities of the Israel-Palestine, Iran, and Turkey situation. This creative presentation helped the young participants grasp the historical and political context. 

üé®To further immerse the children in the cause, their faces were painted with the Palestinian flag, symbolizing unity and support.

üåéAn informative awareness session educated the children on identifying and avoiding products from Israel, highlighting alternatives they could choose instead. 

üáµüá∏A room was transformed to represent Gaza, providing a small yet impactful glimpse into the lives of those affected. This immersive experience helped the children understand the reality of the situation.

üé®Lastly, a hand-printing activity on a large Palestinian flag allowed the kids to leave their mark, symbolizing their support and hope for peace. 

üòä Through these activities, the camp successfully raised awareness and fostered empathy among the young participants.

In the previous three months, the Nigerian military has killed 2,245 terrorists in operations against Boko Haram and the ISWAP, the West African branch of ISIS/Daesh, according to an official quoted by Anadolu Agency on Friday.

Maj. Gen. Edward Buba, head of defense media operations, stated that operations against terrorist groups were carried out in numerous states across the country between April and June.

Furthermore, Buba stated that 1,993 people kidnapped for ransom were rescued during the operations, and 2,783 firearms and a substantial amount of ammunition belonging to terrorists were seized.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi confirmed on Saturday that "relations between Egypt and the European Union are experiencing positive progress across multiple domains," according to Anadolu Agency.

This came during Sisi's talk at the opening session of the Egypt-EU investment conference, which is slated for Saturday and Sunday and will be attended by European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

Egypt's president noted that "relations between Egypt and the European Union are experiencing positive progress in various areas of cooperation."

Singapore is prepared in principle to recognise the State of Palestine, and it believes such a move should help the progress towards peace and a negotiated 2-state solution, Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan told Parliament.

‚ÄúIn particular, there will need to be an effective Palestinian government that accepts Israel‚Äôs right to exist and categorically renounces terrorism,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBoth sides have legitimate rights, and both peoples have a right to live in peace and dignity within secure borders.‚Äù

Dr Balakrishnan urged both sides to seize the moment to take steps towards a long-lasting peace and put an end to the suffering that has ‚Äúgone on for too long‚Äù.

In line with a report in Yedioth Ahronoth, Avigdor Lieberman, the head of the opposition Yisrael Beiteinu Party, has stated that "Israel is losing the war in Gaza" and warned that "Israeli deterrence has declined to zero." Lieberman also called Defense Minister Yoav Gallant's handling of the conflict a "failure," noting that he is directly responsible after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

He went on to say that without a clear plan for the battle, Israeli soldiers and officers in Rafah are frustrated, and the government is unable to make a choice or win victory in the south or north.

Israel's Walla website stated earlier this week that the Israeli occupation army is experiencing a shortage of soldiers and is attempting to construct a new division that will be established to handle a variety of tasks.

As stated by the World Food Programme, famine is a real possibility in 14 parts of Sudan if the conflict that began in April last year continues, according to statistics from a global hunger monitor released on Thursday. This would make it the world's largest hunger crisis.

According to an update from the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC), the areas are located in Khartoum, the Darfur and Kordofan regions, and El Gezira state.

As previously reported by Reuters, some 755,000 people in Sudan are experiencing "catastrophe," the most severe form of intense starvation. According to the report, 8.5 million people, or 18% of the population, are facing food shortages that could lead to acute malnutrition and death, as well as the need for emergency coping techniques.

The ISRAELI üáÆüá± Government has asked Catholic and Orthodox churches to pay property tax or face legal action.

Israel' targeting Christian presence in Jerusalem: Church heads!

In this time, when the whole world, and the Christian world in particular, are constantly following the events in Israel, we find ourselves, once again, dealing with an attempt by authorities to drive the Christian presence out of the Holy Land," the heads of the Catholic and Orthodox Churches wrote in a letter to Israeli occupation Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

This comes as the heads of the Catholic, Greek Orthodox, and Armenian Orthodox denominations have accused the Israeli occupation of a "coordinated attack" on the Christian presence in Jerusalem due to the decision, by several municipalities, such as Tel Aviv, Ramla, al-Nassira, and Jerusalem, to tax church properties and threatening legal action following failure to do so.

‚ÄúWe believe these efforts represent a coordinated attack on the Christian presence in the Holy Land,‚Äù the church leaders wrote.

Church leaders contend that the policy change, which involves taxing their properties, breaks with the longstanding tradition of exemption, an action that will impact the status quo. They further argued that even commercial properties owned by the church should not be taxed since the proceeds support collective services such as schools, hospitals, and care facilities for the elderly and disabled.

In their joint statement, on Sunday, expressing their concern over Jerusalem Municipality's decision to pursue legal action against the churches, the heads of the church said: "We declare that such a measure both undermines the sacred character of Jerusalem and jeopardizes the Church‚Äôs ability to conduct its ministry in this land on behalf of its communities and the worldwide church."

The conflict has historical roots. In 2018, when the Israeli-appointed Municipality of occupied Jerusalerevealed its intention to levy property taxes amounting to $174.5 million on church properties not designated for worship, it provoked a significant backlash from the churches.

After yesterday's debate, Democrats are getting nervous and exploring ways to replace Biden. However, no one can replace him unless he steps down from the nomination. About 50 Palestinian prisoners arrested during the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestine were released on Monday, including the director of Gaza's largest hospital, Israeli sources confirmed.

An Israeli security official, speaking anonymously to Xinhua, stated that the prisoners were released from various Israeli facilities, including the military detention camp of Sde Teiman in the south, where many Palestinians arrested during the ongoing conflict were held.

The official noted that the release was part of an effort to reduce the number of detainees in Sde Teiman, which is running out of space.

Mohammed Abu Selmia, head of the Al Shifa Hospital, was among those released on Monday. He was detained by Israeli forces in November 2023 while traveling south from Gaza City following an Israeli military raid on the hospital.

When examining the history of the land of Israel, it‚Äôs essential to look at the timeline of significant historical and religious landmarks.

The First Temple, also known as Solomon‚Äôs Temple, was built around 1000 BCE in ancient Jerusalem. 
This temple served as the central place of worship for the Israelites and housed the Ark of the Covenant. 
Its construction marks a significant chapter in the history of the Jewish people, establishing their deep-rooted presence in this land over 2,900 years ago.

In contrast, the Al-Aqsa Mosque, an important Islamic landmark, was constructed much later, in 705 CE.

These dates highlight a substantial historical context. 
The Jewish connection to the land of Israel dates back nearly 3,000 years, long before the advent of Islam. 
This deep historical bond underscores the ancient and enduring connection of the Jewish people to this land.

Satan and Lucifer: The Duality of Light and Shadow

In the shadow of conflicts where hatred is woven, Satan, the horned god, amuses and provokes us, His malevolent grin poisons the hearts, de
The armies tear each other apart under his dark lightning.

On the table of destiny, the figurines fall, Chaos reigns supreme, death in numbers, Souls in suffering, trapped in war, Under the cruel gaze of Satan, the sinister father.

But beyond the darkness, a light rises, Lucifer, the bringer of flame, with a noble dream, On the same table, he watches tenderly, Yesterday's enemies reconcile, in joy.

His face illuminated with divine gentleness, He lights the paths to finer ways, Hearts untangle, hands finally clasp, Peace settles, under his serene gaze.

Thus goes the duality of this fragile world, Between shadow and light, an eternal exile, Satan and Lucifer, two sides of the same mirror, Reveal our choices, our essence, our hope.

In the tumult of conflicts, let us seek clarity, For even in the heart of shadows, hope can shine, May Lucifer's light guide our steps, And may Satan be but an echo of the past, already.

Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, made a resolution on Sunday to pardon or commute the sentences of 2,654 convicts in honor of the Eid al-Adha and Ghadir Khum holidays, state television said.
The Iranian Constitution grants the supreme leader the authority to pardon or decrease the sentences of prisoners at the request of the chief of the court.
Khamenei grants pardons on a variety of occasions, including the anniversary of the 1979 revolution and religious holidays.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is also incentivised individually. His rule as Prime Minister is part of a far-right coalition that wants to continue the war. One party in the coalition threatened to dissolve the government if Netanyahu was to agree to Biden‚Äôs recent peace proposal. It‚Äôs the far-right that typically most strongly opposes a Palestinian state and supports the expansion of settlements in the West Bank. To uphold his political career, Netanyahu has swayed further right. He also is facing corruption charges so prolonging the war could prolong the ongoing trial.

The war as it continues is raising tensions in the North between Israel and Hezbollah, and the international community continues to support the establishment of a Palestinian state, with 145 or 193 UN members supporting it. In 1915, the First World War began, during which the British and the French divided the Middle East between themselves. The British took control of Palestine from 1918 to 1948.

During Hitler‚Äôs rule, millions of Jews were murdered in the Holocaust, leading to a flow of Jewish refugees to Palestine. In 1948, the British withdrew, and the UN proposed a division between a Jewish and an Arab state. The Jews accepted and formed the state of Israel, triggering a war with the surrounding Arab countries.

After Israel‚Äôs victory in the war in 1949, they expanded their territory, while the Gaza Strip became part of Egypt and the West Bank part of Jordan. This left the Palestinians as refugees without their own land, and further conflicts, including the Six-Day War in 1967, led to Israel‚Äôs occupation of the Gaza Strip, the West Bank, and East Jerusalem.

In 1993, the Oslo Accords were signed between Israel and the PLO (The Palestine Liberation Organization), marking a step towards a Palestinian government. Unfortunately, illegal Israeli settlements in the West Bank and extremism on both sides prevented a lasting peace.

After the assassination of Israel‚Äôs Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin in 1995 and the establishment of the militant group Hamas in Gaza, the situation became more tense. Hamas‚Äô victory in the Palestinian elections in 2006 led to internal conflicts between Hamas and Fatah, with Gaza under their control, while the West Bank is governed by the PLO. Israel continued with illegal occupation and settlements in Palestine.

The current conflict escalated after October 7, 2023, contributing to a worsening of the situation in the region.

As reported to the Gaza Strip's Ministry of Endowments, the war in Gaza and Israel's blockade of the Rafah crossing that connects Gaza to Egypt have prevented 2,500 Palestinians from attending the Muslim Hajj pilgrimage this year.

This is a "clear violation of religious freedom," according to ministry spokesperson Ikrami Al-Mudallal, who spoke with Anadolu.

The war has hindered the ministry from completing the customary Hajj preparations, including as negotiating transportation contracts in Egypt and Saudi Arabia and arranging accommodations in Mecca and Medina, he explained.

The Sultanate of Oman said on Saturday that it has assisted the fulfillment of a prisoner swap agreement between Sweden and Iran and that the released detainees would be moved to Muscat, according to Anadolu Agency.

"Those released were transferred from Tehran and Stockholm to Muscat today, 15 June 2024, for their repatriation," said the statement.

Saudi Arabia has conducted its first trial of air taxis in Makkah for future usage during the Hajj pilgrimage, as the Kingdom seeks to further simplify the industry as part of its growing tech-driven modernization drive.

An EH216-S pilotless eVTOL aircraft dubbed the 'World's first air taxi to be licensed by a civil aviation authority,' was successfully flown this week in an inaugural testing that saw the aircraft take off vertically. It was organized by the Saudi General Authority of Civil Aviation (GACA) in partnership with the Ministries of Transport and Logistics Services, Hajj, Interior, and Front End Limited Company.

Josep Borrell, the European Foreign Policy chief, stated on Monday that the turmoil in the Middle East was on the verge of spreading into Lebanon, just days after Hezbollah threatened EU member Cyprus, Reuters reports.

"The risk of this war affecting the south of Lebanon and spilling over increases by the day," Borrell told reporters before of a meeting of foreign ministers in Luxembourg.

Hezbollah launched an attack on Israel shortly after Hamas' 7 October assault triggered the Gaza conflict. Hezbollah has stated that it will not stop until there is a truce in Gaza.

üìå Oxfam has reported that Israel has reduced the amount of water available to Gazans by 94% since the onset of the conflict on October 7, 2023. The organization's analysis highlights that the water supply has plummeted to just 4.74 liters per person per day, which is significantly below the recommended minimum for emergencies and equivalent to less than a single toilet flush.

üìå The report, titled "WATER WAR CRIMES," details how Israel's actions, including the cutting of external water supplies, systematic destruction of water infrastructure, and obstruction of humanitarian aid, have contributed to this crisis. Since the beginning of the conflict, Israeli military attacks have damaged or destroyed water and sanitation facilities at an alarming rate, with five sites affected every three days. 

üìå The destruction of essential infrastructure has led to a catastrophic public health situation, with over a quarter of Gaza's population suffering from preventable diseases due to the lack of clean water and sanitation.

üìå Oxfam has called for urgent international action to address the humanitarian crisis, including a ceasefire and the lifting of the blockade on Gaza to allow for the restoration of water and sanitation services. The organization emphasizes that the systematic deprivation of water constitutes a violation of international law and poses immediate and long-term threats to the health and survival of the Palestinian population in Gaza.

According to the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), Israeli attacks on residential areas in the Gaza Strip since October 7 have resulted in 39 million tonnes of debris. According to the program, the debris is equivalent to 107 kg of rubble per square meter. These horrific statistics were disclosed in a report published by the UNEP on Tuesday on the environmental impact of Israel's military offensive on the Palestinian territory.

Due to the security situation and access constraints in the area, the program generated the report remotely using information collected from UN efforts on the ground. It stated that fieldwork will be undertaken when security conditions allow.

A report from Reuters, Egypt has conducted mass arrests and illicit deportations of thousands of people escaping the Sudanese conflict.

According to the rights group, 12 incidences occurred between January and March this year in which Egyptian officials returned an estimated 800 Sudanese people without giving them the opportunity to claim refuge or dispute deportation decisions.

It further stated that it has thoroughly documented the cases of 27 Sudanese refugees apprehended between October 2023 and March 2024, 26 of whom were collectively expelled. Refugees have been confined in brutal and inhumane conditions prior to their deportation, it noted.

The Palestinian group Islamic Jihad fired a barrage of rockets into Israel on Monday as fighting raged in Gaza and Israeli tanks advanced deeper in parts of the enclave, residents and officials said.

Islamic Jihad said its fighters fired rockets toward several Israeli communities near the fence with Gaza in response to "the crimes of the Zionist enemy against our Palestinian people".

The volley of about 20 rockets caused no casualties, the Israeli military said. But the attack showed they possess rocket capabilities almost nine months into an offensive that Israel says is aimed at neutralising threats against it.

An argument that has arisen since hamas‚Äô brutal October 7th massacre, which saw nearly 1,200 Jews and Israelis dead, & around a further 250 taken hostage. This argument is proportionality and this argument, whether you know it or not, has deep antisemitic roots. Although it is not an argument that has been publicly used before, it is one that seems to have only been used since Israel, retaliated & went to war with hamas. Legally, Israel has a duty to protect its own people from genocide & as hamas have said, given the chance, that they will commit the atrocities of October 7th over and over again, Israel also has the right to defend herself. 

Using this against Israel, when they are fighting a war against terrorists who imbed themselves in civilian infrastructure & use their own as human shields, shifts the responsibility away from hamas and their duty as the elected governing body to protect its own. It also shifts the responsibility away from those responsible for the brutal massacre on October 7th. 

‚ÄúProportionality in war does not mean balancing number of lives lost, or buildings leveled‚Ä¶Proportionality is one of the core principles of the law of war‚Äîto which all recognized states have agreed. Distorting the meaning of the term undermines the values it is meant to protect.‚Äù

The IDF, have gone beyond the lengths taken during any other modern warfare, to protect Palestinian civilians & avoid casualties, which is more than can be said for hamas, who use the deaths of their civilians as a PR strategy.

But if we must talk about proportionality, perhaps we could turn our attention to the first intifada, an almost 6 year long war, which was ignited after an Israeli vehicle crashed into two vans carrying Palestinian workers, tragically killing four of them. Israel have said the crash was accidental, however Palestine saw this as revenge for the death of an Israeli a mere few days before. Whether the car crash was an accident or not, does this response seem proportionate to you?
